DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR H. J. GARRICK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on 6 April 1982 of Mr Horace James Garrick, member of this House for the Division of Batman from 1969- 1977, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

All members of this House will be saddened to learn of the recent death of one of our former colleagues. Horace Garrick was the Australian Labor Party member for Batman from 1969 to 1977. He was born on 26 August 1918 in Melbourne and was educated at the Hawthorn West Central School and Swinburne Technical College. He was elected to Parliament at the general election on 25 October 1969 succeeding the then independent member for Batman, Sam Benson. He retired from the House on 10 November 1977 just before the general election.

In his maiden speech on 11 March 1970 Mr Garrick referred to the problems of urban living and the importance he saw for local government in our three tiered system of government. He was concerned about the quality of life especially in the suburban environment and, of course, was able to speak of this with first- hand knowledge and experience. He became a member of the Collingwood Council in 1957 and Mayor of Collingwood from 1960 to 1961 and again from 1968 to 1969. He therefore made an important contribution to the local government scene in Victoria. Additionally, he was a commissioner with the Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works from 1964 to 1973.

Mr Garrick was re-elected at the general elections of 1972, 1974 and 1975 and throughout this period served the Parliament as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Library from 3 March 1976 to 10 November 1977 and as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works from 18 July 1974 to 11 November 1975. He was a member of the Australian Parliamentary Mission to the United States and Mexico in June-July 1972, a member of the Inter Parliamentary Union spring meeting held here in Canberra in April 1977, and attended the sixty-fourth IPU conference in Sofia in September 1977. I am sure his sporting activities in his electorate will be fondly remembered. He was a keen footballer and athlete himself, as well as being a member of sporting organisations in the area-the Collingwood Football Club and Fitzroy Bowling Club. He was also a member of the Northcote Returned Services League and the Preston Social Club. Members of this House have lost a friend and colleague, one who was vitally interested in civic affairs and who served the electors of Batman well. To his family we extend our deepest sympathies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a melancholy occasion for members of the Australian Labor Party to acknowledge the passing of Horace James Garrick who served in this Parliament as an ALP member and as the member for Batman from 1969 to 1977. Horace Garrick is remembered by those who served with him as a man of infectious personality, with a deep commitment to the cause the Labor Party represents and a determination to serve the people who had sent him to this Parliament. He had a great belief in this country and what it could achieve for its people in succeeding generations. Horrie was a true and sensible nationalist just as he was a loyal and dedicated Labor man.

SPEECH.PARA: Before entering Parliament, Horrie Garrick served the community in local government. He was a professional man by employment and was a caring husband and father. The community is diminished by the loss of a man of Horace Garrick's qualities and standards. I speak for all members of the Labor Party when I express my very deep sympathy to his widow and surviving members of his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay tribute today to my predecessor in the seat of Batman, Mr Horrie Garrick, who died on 6 April. Horrie Garrick was distinguished for his long service to the Labor movement, as a Labor councillor in the City of Collingwood Council for 19 years from 1957 to 1976, as a commissioner of the Board of Works and and as the honourable member for Batman for eight years from 1969 to 1977. Horrie died suddenly at his home on the Tuesday following the great Labor victory in the Victorian State election on 3 April. Fittingly, his last contribution to the movement was assisting John Cain's campaign in the seat of Bundoora, a new outer suburb, where Horrie had resided in the last years of his life.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be as a long-standing Labor man in turbulent inner-city politics that Horrie Garrick will be best remembered. He first nominated for the seat of Batman in 1969 when the electorate was based in the inner city areas of Clifton Hill, North Fitzroy and the Northcote areas, with which he had a great familiarity due to his long-standing involvement with the Collingwood Council. His period coincided with dramatic upheavals experienced in the inner city areas of Melbourne, such as Collingwood. Areas such as Collingwood were the victims of government intrusion through freeway expansion or block clearance. As a local representative Horrie fought to redress the powerlessness felt by inner city residents at the hands of government and often private investors.

Horrie was a socialist and a staunch defender of the Labor movement against the attacks from outside groups following the Labor split in 1955. He was a firm unionist with long-standing membership of the sheet metal workers union and of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia. As a parliamentarian he served on a number of committees to which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has referred. He was a member of the Australian Parliamentary Mission to the United States of America and Mexico in 1972. On his return from that visit, Horrie made a strong call for increased efforts to provide adequate water supplies to the Third World.

Intrinsic to Horrie's character was a great involvement in community affairs. A distinguishing mark of this involvement was his sensitivity to and encouragement of ethnic groups in the community long before multiculturalism became popular. In those days migrants, particularly southern Europeans, Greeks and Italians, were arriving in large numbers in inner city areas such as Collingwood and Fitzroy. The reception that they received was often inhospitable and overcrowded housing, dirty jobs and hostility from the wider community. As a local councillor and then a parliamentarian, Horrie showed a deep concern for the problems that migrants were experiencing. He took up their cause on many occasions. It was not surprising that he should be chosen by the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, to head a task force of migrants in the early days of that Government's first term of office. The work of that task force assisted in laying the groundwork for many of the reforms in ethnic rights, such as the provision of interpreter services and multilingual education.

His community involvement meant that he was extremely well liked as a local figure. He was identified with local sporting clubs, particularly football and athletics clubs. He had many loyal friends at the North Fitzroy Bowling Club. Finally, Horrie was a dedicated and caring family man. He is survived by his wife and three daughters. I am sure that all members of this House will join with me in offering our condolences to them.

—I ask a question of the Prime Minister. I refer to the proposed inquiry into the Bureau of Customs which the Prime Minister foreshadowed in his statement to the House yesterday concerning the resignations of the former Ministers for Health and Business and Consumer Affairs. I ask: Is it intended that the Customs Bureau and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs should investigate themselves? Are the activities of those senior officers who were involved in the six months long chain of misinformation surrounding the former Health Minister's Customs examination on 5 October last to be included in the terms of reference of the proposed inquiry? Are the investigating officers to be empowered to inquire into allegations of intimidation and conspiracy, as supported by the file of documents tabled by the Government yesterday? Will the Prime Minister announce to this House the terms of reference at the earliest opportunity? Finally, will the Prime Minister now reconsider his earlier rejection of the Opposition's call for an open judicial inquiry as the only proper means by which these serious matters can be resolved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a short statement that I issued over the weekend on this matter I indicated very plainly that there needed to be a full disclosure of the facts. Going beyond that, to what the Leader of the Opposition has just said, I did not yesterday reject any particular form of inquiry. I said that there would be an examination; the form and nature of that examination were yet to be determined by the Government. This morning there has been discussion between the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the Attorney-General and other Ministers. Those discussions are not yet complete. We need a further report from the Attorney-General and from the Minister. We will be making decisions about the nature of the examination as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: There is one matter, I think, that I can and should lay at rest. We do not propose to establish an inquiry in which Caesar would be investigating Caesar. In other words, the Department would not be investigating itself in relation to these particular matters. Whatever was done would be consistent with what I said on the first occasion, in a short Press statement over the weekend, that there should be a full disclosure of the facts.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND CONSTRUCTION: DISMISSAL OF FORMER APPRENTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether his attention has been drawn to an article which appeared last week concerning a former apprentice of the Department of Housing and Construction who was reportedly dismissed following completion of his apprenticeship. Will the Minister tell the House whether the circumstances are correctly outlined in that story and, if so, what action has been taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to advise the House that the reports that appeared in the media were inaccurate in several instances. The apprentice concerned, Mr Linterbrink, was advised, like all other people who enter into apprenticeships with the Department, that on completion of his apprenticeship he may not be able to be employed. He understood that. The union to which he belongs also understood that. The Department's policy is not merely to train the number of people that it can employ at the termination of their apprenticeships but rather to use its full capacity to train people. This year the Department employed 75 apprentices. At present 400 are in employment.

ANSWER.PARA: Additionally, the Department's policy is to help people obtain employment when their apprenticeships have been completed. They are kept on for three months after that point has been reached. In this case, the Department obtained a position for Mr Linterbrink at $300 a week but he would not take it. Additionally, private enterprise offered him a position at $325 a week and he said that he couldn't take that job because he needed a little holiday. Therefore, the Press publicity inclines me to the view that he is but a puppet of the union and one questions his integrity and the reason for his statement.

The other inaccuracy in the Press report was that the departmental employees and apprentices are not looked upon with great respect by industry. This is not true. In fact, the Department can produce many examples of recognition being given. One that comes readily to mind is a letter from Mr Schnelle of Chemineer Engineering which states that the Department's apprentices are better educated and have better all-round ability than those trained by private enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer to the documents tabled by the Government in the House yesterday in relation to the resignations of the former Ministers for Health and Business and Consumer Affairs. I ask: Who determined what documents would be released to the Parliament and what documents would be withheld? Is the Prime Minister aware that in the 41 pages of documents tabled yesterday there are included only two documents concerning reports made at the time of the incident itself? Is it a fact that there are no file notes, records of conversation, or other files made during the first 48 hours after the incident at Sydney Airport on 5 October last year? Is it also a fact that eight of the 13 documents tabled yesterday were compiled in the last five days after the matter became public in the Press? Will the Prime Minister now table all relevant documents from the files of the Bureau of Customs and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs so that the Parliament can make up its own mind as to whether there has been a conspiracy to protect members of the Government involved in this matter?

—The head of the Department had been asked to provide all files that were relevant to this particular subject; all files that related to it. That question, as I understand it, was asked more than once. Checks were made in New South Wales because the documents that have been tabled, as I am advised, mostly come from files held in New South Wales rather than head office. Subject to what the Minister may say, it is also my understanding that the files were sent to Canberra so that there could be a double check through head office as to whether there are any additional pieces of paper relevant to the issue. On the advice that has been given to me, all pieces of paper that are relevant to this issue have been tabled in the Parliament.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Telecommunications. Is it a fact that I have made representations to the Minister and to Telecom Australia in relation to the growing number of outstanding telephone applications within the electorate of Lyne, one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, and also that I have expressed concern about the congestion on telephone lines? Is the Minister in a position to say what may be done to overcome the problem?

—There is no doubt that the honourable gentleman has been fairly forceful in trying to persuade the Telecom authorities that the lines presently available out of the electorate of Lyne and the southern North Coast area of New South Wales are less than adequate. There have been a number of major growth areas in Australia, of which the honourable member's electorate is one, and in order to offset those problems the Telecom authorities have been providing an enormous capital allocation to try to ensure that switching gear and new phone installations are able to meet demand. As a result of some reappraisal of funding priorities within Telecom an additional $20m has been provided for capital works in this financial year. With an expenditure of $1,285m throughout Australia, Telecom is hoping to be able to provide the maximum service that it can to meet the exploding communication needs of the Australian population, and this certainly includes the constituents of the honourable gentleman. Indeed, a group of representatives from Telecom recently visited the electorate of Lyne and other areas on the North Coast of New South Wales and met with the honourable gentleman and others to try to identify whether there could be, through the allocation of that additional $20m, some improvement in the facilities presently available. Certainly I recognise that there are major difficulties in respect of the number of lines, the switching gear, people being able to get the numbers they call when they want to and even to get phones installed when they want to, not only in that area but also in other areas of Australia. I have taken up both those matters with Telecom and I shall also pass on to it the honourable gentleman's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is supplementary to that which I earlier asked of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister may have noted in the documents tabled in the Parliament yesterday a letter by the New South Wales Collector of Customs, Mr Kelly, which states:

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in going into discussions that might have taken place through Monday. —My question is directed to the Treasurer. What are the current indications for the outcome of the deficit for 1981-82?
—Tell us about interest rates.

—I would be happy to talk about interest rates. The current indications are that the deficit for this financial year will be in the order of $1,000m. The projection at the time of the Budget was $146m. The House has already been advised in some detail of those matters which have added to the deficit both on the revenue side and on the expenditure side. Naturally, the course of revenue collections during the remaining months of the financial year could have an important bearing on the final outcome. As those who follow these matters closely know, the collection, particularly of provisional tax, can vary somewhat against predictions. As things lie and look at the moment, that will be the general outcome. I think that we ought to put into perspective the fact that, although that outcome will be about $700m to $800m more than what was projected at the time of the Budget, as a percentage of gross domestic product it will be well below one per cent. The Budget deficit of that figure compares with figures of 4.9 per cent in 1975 and 3.3 per cent, 3.7 per cent and 3.4 per cent in the subsequent years. In 1979-80 there was a very major reduction to 1.8 per cent and last year the figure was somewhere just under one per cent. So even that larger figure would represent, in any language, a very responsible outcome and one that is very broadly consistent with the Government's objectives.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to reports that a reign of terror has been imposed by the Ugandan Army in that country and that 'life is far more perilous than it ever was under the rule of Idi Amin'. Is it a fact that a Roman Catholic bishop of Uganda has accused elements of the Ugandan Army of inhuman behaviour and that on 24 February there was heavy fighting in Kampala where four Australian Army personnel are stationed as part of the Commonwealth training team attached to the Ugandan Army? Is the Minister able to assure the House that the lives of the Australians are not in danger and that, given President Obote's rule and the Army's activities, the participation of the Australian team will now be reviewed? Further, is the Minister in a position to say when an officer from the Australian High Commission in Nairobi last visited Uganda?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters of fact which I will need to check. The first relates to the last part of the question regarding the date of the last visit to Uganda by an officer from the Australian High Commission and the second relates to the reference to the Roman Catholic bishop. I am not aware of those matters but I will check them. The continuing allegations of human rights abuse in Uganda are of deep concern to the Government. We have made clear to the Ugandan Government our expectation that it will make the most determined efforts to improve that situation. We have also noted statements by President Obote asserting that his Government has a commitment to the preservation of human rights. A major factor in Australia's decision to join the Commonwealth assistance program was our assessment that it would help the human rights situation in Uganda to which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has referred. The disarray and indiscipline of the armed forces is clearly a contributing factor to these abuses of human rights. Therefore it could be expected that an improvement in military discipline would bring a corresponding improvement in the human rights area.

ANSWER.PARA: Our decision to contribute to the Commonwealth training program was a carefully considered one. We acknowledge that risks are involved but we consider that positive action by the Commonwealth now will make a valuable contribution to the future internal stability of that unhappy country. The Commonwealth Secretariat and the Ugandan Government are jointly responsible for the protection arrangements for the Commonwealth military training team. Whilst the internal security situation there is undoubtedly unsettled at this stage, on our assessment there is not a serious risk to our personnel. Were this assessment to change, the Government would not hesitate to reassess our involvement in the team, in consultation, of course, with the other governments concerned and the Commonwealth Secretariat. In an emergency the senior Australian officer, if in his judgment Australian lives are at risk, has the authority to implement withdrawal as he sees fit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In view of the participation of HMS Invincible in the Falkland Islands task force, will the Minister advise of progress in negotiations for the acquisition of this vehicle- sorry, this vessel-for the Royal Australian Navy?

—I am sorry that the honourable gentleman used such an unfelicitous description of this magnificent ship. The honourable gentleman will be aware that earlier this year a defence mission visited the United Kingdom and completed satisfactorily negotiations for the transfer of the ship from the Royal Navy to the Royal Australian Navy. A draft sales agreement has been prepared, together with a memorandum of understanding. It is my expectation that I will sign both in the very near future. They will then be forwarded to the United Kingdom Secretary of State for Defence, Mr John Nott. It is expected that the ship will be handed over to the Royal Australian Navy towards the end of 1983. It remains for me to say but one thing: I should apologise to the House for apparent transgression on my part yesterday. It was my hope to make a brief statement to the House while Parliament was sitting. For reasons which I am sure would be thoroughly within the comprehension of all honourable members, I was not able to do so.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of anomalies that have arisen following the recent introduction by Australia Post of new parcel rates, in particular the large increase in the charges for residents of Eyre Peninsula who are faced with an increase of 125 per cent in the charge for a parcel of up to two kilograms forwarded to Adelaide; that is, an increase from $1.60 to $3.60 ? Is he aware also that if the same parcel is sent to Mount Gambier, a further 350 kilometres, the charge is only $2? Will the Minister take steps to have these anomalies examined and rectified?

—The honourable gentleman, indeed all honourable members, will be aware that Australia Post is charged with the responsibility of providing its services at a charge which covers the cost of their provision. Consequently, adjustments to charges for parcel post were made by Australia Post taking into account that responsibility. However, recently there has been a realignment of areas within which postal charges are set. No doubt the situation which applies to Eyre Peninsula and the particular instances to which the honourable gentleman 's question was addressed are part of that reappraisal. I am not aware of the particular circumstances of Eyre Peninsula or of postage rates to the two destinations, Mount Gambier and Adelaide, which he instanced. However, I will take that up with Australia Post and refer the honourable member's question to it. I say, however, to all honourable members that it needs to be borne in mind that there have been significant labour disabilities within Australia Post. As I mentioned to this House on another occasion, industrial troubles prior to Christmas 1981 cost Australia Post something like $7m. One of the reasons for the present adjustment in postal charges can be sourced directly to the disruption caused by industrial troubles at that time. Those troubles certainly have added to the postal charges as well as to the parcel charges, the matter to which this question is related.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry conversant with the severe concern of the pineapple industry about pineapple products being imported into Australia under conditions which often closely approximate dumping? Has an agreement for processing of pineapple products involving China and the IXL company been contemplated or concluded? If so, what is the nature of that agreement? Will the product be marketed in Australia? What effect, if any, will that have on the domestic pineapple industry in Australia or on Australian markets?

—I am aware of the concern in the pineapple industry in Queensland about the agreement reached between IXL and the Government of China on what I understand to be a joint venture in the processing of pineapples in China. At this point I am unable to provide the honourable member with details of that agreement or indeed of the impact that it might ultimately have on Australia's trade, other than to say that if there is any concern about the dumping of pineapples on the Australian market procedures are, of course, available to the pineapple industry to seek protection from dumping. Those procedures are well known and can be made available easily to the industry. I advise the honourable member to seek information from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs about them. When I have the final details of the agreement between IXL and the Government of China and the proposed trade arrangements under the agreement, I will give them to the honourable member.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 March this year relating to identical telex messages concerning a Sydney Labor member of parliament and sent to the Sydney offices of the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian Financial Review from the Newcastle television station NBN3 and Phillip Short Public Relations Pty Ltd respectively? The Sydney Morning Herald reported that I could be the sender, which I denied. Will the Minister make inquiries through his Department as to who did send these bogus telexes?
—I think all members of this House are appalled at the machinations of internal Australian Labor Party politics. It is quite true that we have endeavoured to ensure--
—We don't make money out of our machinations the way you do.

—In view of the comment of the Leader of the Opposition I think it might be interesting if I refer to the Age of 25 October 1976, when one of the many left wing socialists of the Labor Party was elected to this place. He was elected as the member to succeed the late Horrie Garrick.
—Order! The right honourable gentleman will remain relevant to the question.

—Mr Speaker, this is very relevant because it needs to be remembered that the honourable gentleman who has asked this question has lost his endorsement as a result of one of these power struggles within the Labor Party. Although Telecom Australia is trying to identify the source of these bogus messages, given the way in which the Left is prepared to play for power, I have little doubt that eventually it will transpire that in some way it has been seeking to portray the honourable gentleman in an unsavoury or unfavourable light. All of us know the honourable gentleman to have been a very effective member of this place. One can only suspect the origins of this message in this instance.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Is he aware of the significance of holding international events in Canberra? I also ask him whether in that context he might be able to inform the Parliament of any movement towards the holding of the World Athletics Cup in Canberra in 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with very great pleasure, which I am sure will be shared by all honourable members, that I inform the House that a few hours ago in Jamaica the Council of the International Amateur Athletics Federation voted to award Australia the 1985 World Cup in Athletics. Canberra will host this prestigious event. This decision culminates years of planning to give Australia an international venue capable of staging athletic competitions of world standard.

ANSWER.PARA: The National Sports Centre at Bruce, in conjunction with the Australian Institute of Sport, is now poised to place Australia on the world map of international athletics. The Government has demonstrated its commitment to the achievement of excellence in sport and the availability of young Australians to compete in prestigious international competitions. The 1985 World Cup in Athletics will focus the eyes of the sporting world on Australia and Canberra. The World Cup, following shortly after the 1984 Olympics, will bring to Australia the top 400 athletes in the world. It will be televised to over 600 million viewers in more than 50 countries and it will attract thousands of visitors to Canberra. It is estimated that a Press contingent of about 1,000 will come here for the event.

The World Cup is a prestigious event and, on behalf of the Government, I warmly congratulate our Australian delegation members now in Jamaica on the success of their representations. I congratulate the Amateur Athletics Union of Australia and its delegation members, the members of the delegation representing the Department of the Capital Territory, and the leader of the successful delegation , Tony Blunn. Further development of the National Sports Centre at Bruce will now proceed as is planned. Jointly, the Departments of the Capital Territory and Home Affairs and Environment will now proceed, in conjunction with support from Australian private enterprise, to plan the administrative arrangements for the World Cup in 1985. I am delighted that Australia has been chosen to host this event.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is related to reports of allegations by the Government of Israel that the Palestine Liberation Organisation in Gaza had been supplied through points in the Sinai. I ask: In view of the Government's statements that Australian Service personnel serving in the Sinai remain under Australian governmental control, what instructions has his Government given to Australian servicemen who may come in contact with or observe PLO operations in the Sinai? In particular, have they been instructed to avoid contact? Further, in view of the fact that our forces are designated to observe only Egyptian and Israeli conformity with the terms of the agreement between Egypt and Israel to limit forces in the area, have our Service personnel been instructed not to pass on to Israel and Egypt information concerning the activities of a group such as the PLO which they may observe but which is not party to the treaty?

—Before the Government agreed to participate in the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers a most careful assessment was made, on the basis of the best advice available to us, of any risks to which they would be subjected. Amongst the matters investigated were allegations that the Palestine Liberation Organisation was smuggling weapons or arms through the area to the Gaza Strip. The official information we had on that matter was that such activity was very minimal and did not constitute a threat to the safety of the Australian forces. The circumstances on which members of the Multinational Force and Observers report is a matter for the Force itself. The documents which have already been tabled in this House will provide the answer to the honourable gentleman's question in that respect. So far as I am aware, and I would need to check this information, no instruction along the lines given by the honourable member-that is, not to report on certain activities-has been issued.

—Is the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs aware that the Metal Trades Industry Association has launched an attack on those who argue the conventional economic view that high prices, whether for motor cars or labour, cost jobs somewhere in society? Is the Government aware of any new economic theory which suggests that international competitiveness can be maintained irrespective of costs in Australia? What has been the recent contribution of the MTIA to reducing costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I can well understand that manufacturers, particularly manufacturers in the metal trades industry, are proud of the continuing contribution they make to providing increasing employment in this country. They have done so for many years and, no doubt, will continue to do so in the future. This has been one of the reasons why Australia has had an employment growth which is very good indeed when compared with those countries with which we normally compare ourselves in these matters. At the same time it should also be said very firmly that we must look to new industries which will be encouraged to be set up in this country and, one hopes, with employees in very large numbers. The Government's policy-recently it was very strongly supported by Ministers of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-is that investment plays a vital part in encouraging and establishing the proper framework for continued employment growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is a prosperous country. It is a country whose people are well educated and it is ideally suited for what I might call new industries- industries where advanced and new technology is at the fore. It should be firmly understood that in those industries there are the seeds for enormous employment growth. We can make our contribution, of course, through the Government's economic policies and, in addition, by means of a recent training committee set up by the National Training Council. The National Training Council has made a very valuable contribution towards training people for industry. There will be a new training committee designed specifically to encourage the training of people in the computer industry and other related advanced technology industries. In order to stir honourable members up a little, I should like to add that while the honourable member for Lalor is writing books about subjects concerning technology we should contemplate the fact that there are countries which employ very large numbers of people in new advanced technology industries. Australia is becoming one of those countries and can do better in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. Have any arrangements been made between the Government of Australia and the State Government of Western Australia for the financing of a proposed power house at Bunbury? If arrangements have been made, when were they made? Can the Treasurer give the House any details of those arrangements?

—I cannot recall any specific arrangements, as such, that have been made between the Federal Government and the Western Australian Government in the strict sense. It may well be that the Western Australian Government has corresponded with me regarding possible borrowing arrangements that might be the subject of Loan Council consideration in respect of that particular power station. I get a large number of letters from State Premiers and Treasurers about borrowing. I will have a look at my files. If I can provide the honourable member with any more detailed and fuller information I will do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What evidence has the Government received of Soviet-backed chemical warfare in Afghanistan and Indo-China? What steps is the Government taking to test the evidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been aware of and concerned, for some time, about allegations in relation to the use of chemical weapons in Indo-China and Afghanistan particularly. On 22 March this year the United States Secretary of State submitted to the United States Congress a report which contained a considerable amount of data collected by the United States on chemical weapons use. A group of United States experts in this field is currently in Australia. Those experts have discussed the findings in that report with experts from relevant departments. The team has been assured of Australia's support for efforts to investigate thoroughly any reports of alleged chemical weapons use.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Australian Government itself has agreed to examine reported evidence of chemical warfare use in South East Asia. Samples of vegetable material said to have been contaminated by chemical weapons attack have been obtained by our embassy in Bangkok from the Thai-Lao border region. Arrangements are currently being made to transport these samples to Australia for scientific analysis. In addition, Australian experts currently in Bangkok have examined a rocket grenade which is said to be a chemical weapon. A report has been received from that examination and it is now under consideration.

More generally, it should be remembered that Australia was a co-sponsor of the resolution which established the United Nations committee of experts which examines the alleged use of chemical weapons. We have played a very active part in that field, and the findings of any Australian investigations which I have just mentioned will be conveyed to the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the 190th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which stated that up to $100m was lost in revenues not collected from Bass Strait oil companies. Can the Minister confirm that the Federal Government relied on officials of the Victorian Government to measure the quantity of oil and that that Government did not have the computer facilities to do so? Secondly, can he further confirm that these Victorian officials were relying on the measurements of the quantity of oil given to them by Esso Australia Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-the very companies paying the excise tax? Thirdly, what action has the Government taken, since the report appeared last year, to ensure the introduction of an efficient and reliable measuring mechanism under the control of the Federal Government?

—I guess that I am the fall guy in that my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister is away, and he represents Senator Sir John Carrick in this place. I shall ask the Minister in the other place to provide me with an answer to the honourable gentleman's question, and I suggest that the question be placed on notice for that purpose.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industry advise on the progress of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication program? Is it a fact that the Commonwealth's contributions to the program are currently running $20m short of its initial undertaking? Can the Minister give an assurance that cattle producers in northern Australia will not be adversely affected by cuts in Commonwealth financial support for the scheme or by any reduction by primary industry in its future participation in this vital program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to report that the brucellosis and tuberculosis campaign is progressing very satisfactorily. I think that it is up to, or even ahead of, schedule. Many areas in southern Australia are provisionally free of both brucellosis and tuberculosis, and the campaign is now being carried out mostly in the northern parts of Australia. As the honourable member will know, the Northern Territory is very much a central part of that campaign. It is imperative that the campaign be continued and finalised. There is no doubt that the future of cattle markets and of the cattle industry in the long term is dependent on that campaign being appropriately completed.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member talked about the Commonwealth Government's contribution. I think there is a misunderstanding throughout the industry that the Commonwealth has a commitment to provide some 15 per cent of funds for the campaign. I have checked the record and am unable to find any such commitment. Nevertheless, the volume of money that the Commonwealth has paid to this point- some $32.6m-is about 12 per cent of the cost of the campaign to this point. In the three-year period that the recent announcement covers-from 1984 to 1987-it is anticipated that the Commonwealth Government again will be called upon to provide about $12m out of an estimated expenditure of somewhere between $54m and $84m. So, the Commonwealth's contribution will be in the range of from 22 per cent, at its highest, to 14 per cent, at its lowest.

As the honourable member will know, the campaign has been funded by a levy on the industry. Because of a variety of circumstances not enough funds have been available to meet the demands of the campaign. Therefore, the Commonwealth has on-lent funds to the industry, to the tune of some $16m, to keep the campaign up to its program. There is now a debt of some $22m, made up of that $16m plus interest. This is of major concern to the industry. It is concerned that it is unable to meet its commitment to repay the loan and meet the interest payments as well as maintain the campaign as it ought to be maintained. The Cattle Council of Australia met with the Prime Minister and me last night and put its concerns to us. We recognise, as it does, that the campaign is an important and imperative one and we recognise the difficulty that will be caused to the industry in meeting its commitments totalling approximately $22m. The Prime Minister and I gave a commitment that we will look at the matter in the Budget context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Treasurer been drawn to the submission by the National Employers Industrial Council in the recent national wage case to the effect that the Government's extremely tight monetary policy is forcing employers to concede union wage claims because of the crucial need to maintain cash flow? In view of the fact that the Government claims that it needs to maintain a tight money policy to control inflation by containing wage increases, is the Treasurer concerned that his monetary policy is apparently having the completely opposite effect to that which he intended and, if so, has he considered changing it?

—I inform the honourable member for Gellibrand that we on this side of the House do not automatically adopt the views of the National Employers Industrial Council or indeed any other group in the Australian community. Unlike some of his colleagues who automatically adopt the views of other sections of the Australian community without query or interrogation, we form our own assessments. I do not accept the submission put by the Council on that occasion. I think it was put to explain away the conduct of some of its members. I do not think it is a valid analysis of the situation. We have never argued that monetary policy is the only policy that can be used to bring about wage restraint. Obviously other elements can be introduced; but any climate of successful wage restraint over a period must include a monetary and fiscal policy which is not accommodating to excessive wage settlements.
