DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's inadequate response to the grave problems of the Australian steel industry.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian iron and steel industry is in a state of shock and depression. Production of pig iron in the three months to February was 12 per cent down on the equivalent period of last year. Production of raw steel fell 16 per cent over the same period. Steel plants have been closed or reopenings deferred, in Newcastle and Port Kembla in New South Wales and Kwinana in Western Australia. Four hundred workers are being laid off in Kwinana. Recently one hundred and fifty jobs were lost in Newcastle and the work force in Port Kembla is falling by an average of 30 every week. My colleague the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), who will follow me in the debate, will say more about the problems in the Port Kembla district, but I am informed by Mr Lloyd O'Neill, the Australian Labor Party's successor to Mr Laurie Wallis in the seat of Grey, that management expects to reduce from 6,300 to 5,000 the work force in the steel industry of Whyalla-a shattering reduction for such a regional centre.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I have been reminded that a question upon notice by the honourable member for Grey goes further and expresses concern that statements by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd indicate that 3,000 jobs could become redundant in the Australian steel industry generally, thus affecting the steelmaking centres of Whyalla, Newcastle, Port Kembla and Kwinana. From what I have said already, and from other indications, over the course of 1982, 3,000 of Australia's 60,000 steel industry jobs appear certain to be lost. The social and economic consequences of this industrial decline are, of course, concentrated on Australia's four regional steel centres of Newcastle, Port Kembla, Whyalla and Kwinana.

The medium and longer term future appear just as bleak, as BHP has apparently made the strategic decision to halt expansion in steel and put all the emphasis on job-displacing productivity improvement. It is virtually surrendering a long- term export capacity. Already, for the first time in several decades, our imports of iron and steel actually exceed our exports. Trade statistics released only last week show in the last half year a 9 per cent fall in the value of iron and steel exports and a 27 per cent rise in imports. These trends in the industry are catastrophic. They are an indictment of both the monetarist philosophy and the failed manufacturing policies of this bankrupt and increasingly talentless government. No wonder there is an overwhelming perception of a smell of decay pervading this Government as it lurches from one crisis to another.

In the immediate future the problems of the industry can be seen to arise from a failure to maintain international competitiveness, plus the depressed condition of the domestic market. Each of these problems can be substantially blamed on the economic incompetence and stupidity of the Fraser Government. As the Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd has been repeatedly stressing, the Government has maintained an exchange rate for the Australian dollar which bears no sensible relationship to our recent dismal trading performance. Even with the devaluation of recent months there remains a market overvaluation of the dollar which is now being supported by Government overseas borrowings and a ludicrously high interest rate policy aimed at forcing the private sector to borrow off- shore. This is the factor which has had the most damaging impact on our steel trade.

Added to this has been the continued procrastination and crisis in Government administration in the long delay for a decision on the BHP and Lysaght ( Australia) Limited requests for temporary assistance and anti-dumping measures. These requests have been circulating in understaffed bureaucratic circles for several months while the industry situation has slipped from bad to worse. I have learned that some of the fault perhaps is with the management of BHP, but that is no consolation to the workers of BHP. I hope that this debate today will bring forward the Government's excuses for these applications having been lost in the bureaucracy for so long. No doubt the latest loss of a Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs will add to the delay. The Fraser Government has now had five Ministers in this post and presumably we will get a sixth, to be announced in the coming days or weeks. The delay has been despite the disruption caused by dramatically increasing imports which should have triggered at least the commencement of temporary assistance inquiries months ago. These immediate problems in relation to imports should be dealt with promptly.

The same applies to the current Government's monetarist philosophy-a philosophy which is proving universally to be a total failure and little better than a quack cure peddled by simple ideologues. Monetarism, which has seen Australian interest rates reach record levels, is being reinforced further by the Fraser Government. In the year to February money supply growth at 10.5 per cent fell below the rate of inflation. Inevitably, a critical squeeze has been imposed on the economy as the real volume of money falls. Business confidence has collapsed . A recent survey by the Metal Trades Industry Association, which comprises the main customers of the steel industry, confirms this crisis. The reason given for the reduction in expectations was overwhelmingly a 'lack of demand'-a lack of demand resulting from deliberate Government policy.

Apart from the direct production and employment consequences of this recessionary monetarist approach, the high interest rates have dampened BHP's ability and motivation to invest in new plant. A recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development steel industry symposium was told by American representatives that it is difficult to contemplate modernisation with interest rates at 17 per cent and 18 per cent and higher with below average profits. BHP's circumstances and environment are very similiar to America's, and largely because our governments are each blindly pursuing the monetarist path. But these immediate problems are not the only ones for which this Government must stand condemned in relation to this basic and vital industry for Australia' s economy.

For decades the Australian steel industry has been the exclusive province of a single, monopolistic company. In the past, the management of that company has served Australia reasonably well, and I fully expect that it will continue to do so. However, the Australian Labor party is concerned that the strategic decisions being taken in relation to the BHP steel division may not optimise the potential benefits which can be gained through this industry. We believe that the national Government has a role, indeed a responsibility, to involve itself more fully in such strategic decisions of such great importance to the Australian national economy.

There are several reasons for the Government taking a role in the longer term planning of this industry. I want to go through those reasons. Firstly, the steel industry already receives special assistance from the Government in the form of accelerated depreciation and protective tariffs. The Labor Party supports these assistance measures but considers that, as they are provided on the basis of national interest objectives, the Government should seek to ensure that the industry does meet national objectives. Secondly, we believe that a system of national economic planning would assist in the task of moving Australia to a higher growth path. Obviously the steel industry would benefit from and be a major part of such a higher growth strategy. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), who is sitting at the table, was seeking to interject. I only wish that a Minister would take part in this debate but I have my doubts about whether one will. It ill becomes him, a senior Government Minister handling an economic portfolio, to sit there half listening to this debate and not enter it and defend the Government's poor record in relation to the steel industry in particular and the national economy in general.

I am going through the list of the several reasons for the Government taking a role in the longer term planning of this industry. The third reason I give is that we note that there is heavy government involvement in the steel industry in many other countries. The European coal and steel community has for many years pursued the restructuring of its steel industries in order to meet increased competition and the more exacting quality requirements of customers. A tripartite consultative committee has operated to assist this process in Europe. Governments have been involved in trading arrangements to avoid disruption. In many other countries, including those competing with Australian steel, the governments have owned or substantially influenced the development of steel industries, often giving them a competitive advantage. In these circumstances we in the Labor Party believe that the Australian steel industry deserves much closer attention and help from government. We do not accept that because BHP has a pessimistic outlook the local industry must fall by the wayside, which it is in danger of doing.

We observe that in other countries very different strategies are being pursued. Following entry to the European Economic Community the Irish steel industry fully restructured and maintained its competitiveness. Malaysia is now building two medium size steel plants, each with an annual capacity of about 600,000 tonnes. They will open in 1984-85 and will probably use Australian raw materials . Although developing countries are expanding their capacity it is expected that the more rapid growth of these countries will mean they have a continuing need to import steel in net terms. The long term future of steel has been assessed as bleak by BHP. But in many other countries expansion and restructuring are being pursued.

It is true that as many as a quarter of a million jobs in the steel industry have been lost over the past decade in the industrialised countries. But Australia has unique advantages in terms of energy, iron ore and its location adjacent to the most rapidly growing industrial zones of the world. With all those advantages there is no reason for our record to be the same as other countries. It is the responsibility of the Government to fully assess whether these advantages lead to a conclusion that the industry should be expanded rather than diminished, as BHP believes. If, after proper and exhaustive study, it is found that BHP's assessment is right, then the Government's responsibility shifts to preserving the rights and opportunities of the people in our four great steel cities.

The European and Japanese industries have rationalised in the context of measures to secure the livelihood of those affected. Social policies provide for readaption of workers, early pensions, income maintenance, the creation of alternative jobs and the training of workers to fill them. Whatever strategy is found appropriate for Australia, the Government must accept the responsibility to ensure that it is a correct decision and one that leads to security for those affected. Instead, at present we face uncertainty and crisis. The workers laid off at Kwinana believe they have have not had a satisfactory redundancy scheme. This threatens industrial trouble in many other centres as well. We have not seen for many years an adequate effort to improve competitiveness and efficiency in the Australian steel industry.

The Opposition is very concerned to note that the price of steel used in metal fabrication manufacturing industry has accelerated more rapidly in recent years than has the consumer price index. Prices rose by 11.1 per cent in 1979-80 and 14.1 per cent in 1980-81. The price in March this year was a further 11.6 per cent above the previous year's figure, despite the recession and despite increased imports. These figures suggest that steel is a serious scource of cost pressure in the Australian economy. This is of very great concern to us.

The Government should establish immediately a tripartite task force to review the future of the Australian steel industry. Company, trade union and government representatives should jointly review strategic options for the industry indicating what the requirements are for a wide range of alternatives. This industry has no effective liaison with Government. There is no equivalent to European joint consultation. There is no industry advisory council. A dumping evaluation committee was established last year but this has a very narrow focus and we have yet to see any tangible benefit from it. While a steel industry task force will help devise a more growth-oriented and socially responsible strategy for the industry, it will continue to face a slump in demand unless this Government also changes its disastrous macroeconomic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) has taken a typical tilt at the Government's industry policy-in this case the steel industry-but the charges he makes and the whole thrust of his criticism of the Government are mischievous and misleading, and based on incomplete information. He charges that the Government is sitting around with no interest in the steel industry and doing nothing about it. I draw his attention to item No. 14 on today's Notice Paper which contains a very important measure to assist the steel industry-a Bill to provide a very favourable rate of depreciation for the industry, the effect of which will be to allow the industry to write off its capital investment over five years compared with a period previously of around 12 years.
—It will make it more competitive.

—It will make it much more competitive-it is the best single measure one can take to make industry more competitive. Yet the honourable member for Adelaide charges, and Australians are led to believe, that the Government is sitting around with no interest in the industry and doing nothing. The fact is that the Government is very well aware of the situation in both the domestic and the international iron and steel industry. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Department have in fact been in very close contact with the industry over recent months. It certainly has to be appreciated that the Australian industry is operating in a world steel industry environment characterised by serious over-capacity and very depressed prices.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, in Sweden last year apparent consumption was down about 8 per cent compared with the previous year. Crude steel production was down 11 per cent to its lowest level since 1965, with 8 per cent of the steel work force permanently laid off. In Japan, crude steel production was down 8.7 per cent. In the United States of America shipments out of the steel works were admittedly up slightly in 1981 but have since declined very sharply and in January this year were 26 per cent below the figures for January 1981. There were 68,000 workers laid off and 22,000 on short time. The European Economic Community would have to go back to the late 1960s to find a comparable year with the extent to which production and employment are down in that industry. Further the general world consensus is that increases in demand in the foreseeable future will be very small. Economic growth generally is likely to be below recent predictions, and growth in steel demand even less than the growth in total production, GDP, due to progressive reductions in steel intensity. For instance EEC industrial production was down 1.5 per cent last year but steel production was down 7 per cent. The usage of steel as against other materials in various products, for instance motor cars, has declined.

I cite those figures because the world steel market situation, together with measures adopted by a number of overseas governments to enable their industries to survive such conditions or at least to adjust more slowly, have resulted in greatly intensified import competition for the Australian industry. Also, naturally, Australian export markets have been affected. The Australian industry has traditionally exported upwards of 20 per cent of its output but under current trading conditions such sales have become increasingly unremunerative. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has therefore indicated that it is curtailing its export marketing activities. The closure of the Kwinana blast furnace, for example, reflects directly the loss of export markets. Previously more than half of that furnace's output of pig iron had been exported, mainly to China, but with China now having entered export markets and with other new producers also competing in the Asia-Pacific market I would say that BHP was faced with no real alternative but to close the furnace. Production over the last few months has been stockpiled for future domestic requirements. In that way employees have been given more time to find alternative work.

As I said, the Government recognises the industry's difficulties. Clearly, it did so during its consideration last year of the Industries Assistance Commission report on the industry. I have already referred to the fact that we have a specific measure to allow for a faster write-off of new investment. It was introduced in the last Budget. It is applicable from the date of presentation of that Budget-that is, 18 August last year-and will apply until 1991. This measure was introduced to provide an incentive to the industry in terms of improved cash flow to introduce modern technologically advanced plant and equipment. As the BHP Executive General Manager for Finance, Mr Hunter said recently:
If increased productivity is not forthcoming, the group faces a permanent loss of its steel export markets and the further erosion by imports of the domestic market.

A particular initiative taken by the Government-I think this ought to be considered carefully in the light of the remarks of the honourable member for Adelaide-in recognition of the parlous state of the world's steel industry, as I have outlined, and in conjunction with the decision to which I referred on the IAC report, was the establishment of the iron and steel joint industry dumping evaluation committee. This is a joint industry-departmental committee to facilitate the submission of prima facie cases of alleged dumping in respect of iron and steel mill products.

Following reports from the committee the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has carried out a number of dumping investigations and is continuing its activities in that area. Since the Government announced its decision on the IAC report last April and it introduced the accelerated depreciation provision in the August Budget, as I have said, the world steel market has continued to deteriorate. Consequently we have a situation in which more overseas producers are looking to export to the Australian market. Countries which previously did not do so, such as Brazil, South Africa and even Spain are now doing so, as are established exporting countries such as Japan and Korea, which have more product available. The inevitable end effect in the market-place has been depressed prices, price cutting and very intense competition. The honourable member for Adelaide referred to two requests for temporary assistance; one from John Lysaght (Aust.) Ltd covering a variety of flat steel products and the other from BHP covering certain hot rolled flat steel products, pipes and tubes. The John Lysaght request was notified publicly by the Department of Industry and Commerce on 4 January this year and the BHP request was notified by the Department on 30 March this year.

As all honourable members will be aware, there are established procedures for industries wishing to have their level of assistance against import competition reviewed. Part of that procedure is for them to demonstrate that a prima facie case exists for a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission or to the Temporary Assistance Authority.

As part of that process the Department publishes details of requests for temporary assistance and provides them to all interested parties to give them the opportunity, firstly of knowing that such a request has been made and, secondly, of submitting their point of view to the Department. Discussions have also taken place between the Department and steel users, processors, importers and representatives of overseas suppliers. These discussions have assisted in gaining a more detailed appreciation of the market situation and outlook, the factors which have contributed to the present situation as well as the implication of any change in assistance levels.

The Government did not take a decision separately on the John Lysaght application quite deliberately as it had become known that BHP was considering making an application covering different but related products. It should be remembered that a number of sectors of the industry were under pressure at the beginning of the year, not just the John Lysaght product range. So the position is that the Department of Industry and Commerce is at the moment awaiting receipt of essential statistical information from sectors of the industry itself . I do not know why the Labor Party has raised this matter of public importance at this particular moment. However, the position is that the Department has to await receipt of essential statistical information from sectors of the industry itself before it is able to finalise its report to the Minister. I let that be known for the information of the honourable member for Adelaide.

The truth is then that there has been continuing contact between the industry and the Department to facilitate the preparation and submission of the requisite data. Until the industry provides this data the Minister is unable to determine whether a prima facie case exists for the reference.

I submit that decisions taken by the Government so far-I have referred to the accelerated depreciation and the setting up of the committee-and the urgency being given to reviewing the industry's present difficulties clearly illustrate the Government's concern for the continuing viability of this industry which is very important in both an economic and a strategic sense. The House can be assured that the Minister for Industry and Commerce will make his decision as a matter of urgency as soon as this information is forthcoming and the report is received.

I want to say something about the provision in the Bill before the House. I previously referred to accelerated write-off to encourage new investment in the iron and steel industry. I take this opportunity to suggest to the Government that there is in fact an urgent need to achieve faster capital recovery in other industries-indeed, in all industries-as perhaps a key element in meeting the urgent need to regain, maximise, our international competitiveness. Indeed, this should be a key feature of a positive industry strategy for Australia. The difficulty with the existing pattern of write-off provisions is that there is a bias towards repair and maintenance expenditure on equipment which is deductible in the year of expenditure. But that bias has a very serious long term impact on the modernity, the extent of modern plant and equipment in industry. That, of course, has serious implications in terms of reduced competitiveness and profitability. I venture to say that the ideal would be to adopt the British system of free depreciation. I suggest to the Government that while that is a long term ideal objective towards which we might work, a start might be given by having a shorter write-off period than now exists, such as the five-year period provided in the legislation of the steel industry.

In conclusion, I ask: What positive suggestions for this industry, for industry policy generally or for economic policy generally have we had from the Opposition in this debate today? In listening to the honourable member for Adelaide I detected a suggestion that yet another authority should be established. The honourable member has a great penchant for suggesting the establishment of additional regulatory authorities. A suggestion was recently made for the establishment of an Automotive Industry Authority. The Opposition's formula is always for more planning, more control and more smothering bureaucracy. I should like to quote the key passage of a statement made by the honourable member for Adelaide. He said:
In the context of substantial Government support for the industry,
In that case, the motor car industry--
it is essential that the Government be involved in the formulation of plans--
Note the small 'p'; in short, planning--

for the industry's future structure. It is also necessary that the Government monitor and regulate to the extent necessary, pricing and component sourcing decisions of the major vehicle assemblers. A Labor Government will establish an Automotive Industry Authority to achieve this planning and regulation of the industry.

The honourable member for Adelaide said the Authority would 'regulate pricing decisions' of the major companies. We might as well nationalise the industry straight out. If this were done perhaps we would see a repetition of what happened to the vehicle and other industries in the United Kingdom. As I said at the outset, it is totally misleading of the Opposition to use the words it has; its argument is based on inadequate information.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I want to put it on record that the Opposition is most disappointed and wants those involved in the steel industry- both corporations and labour-to know that we are very sorry that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), although he is in the Parliament somewhere today, has not seen fit to come into the chamber to debate what is undoubtedly a developing situation of relative crisis in the steel industry. There is no argument about that. The Government, the Opposition and the unions involved in the steel industry may differ on the facts, on the course the industry is taking and on the policy requirements, but in my view there is no argument about what are the problems. The problems in the Australian steel industry centre upon falling production; slack domestic demand caused mainly by the economic failures of this Government, by rising imports, an erratic export market, a declining return on investment of funds employed; and a very poor industrial relations record.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very difficult to assess the basis accurately. The Opposition has put in a lot of work, in contrast to the Government, on establishing exactly what is going on in the steel industry. There are a number of reasons why this is difficult. The Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd steel division and Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd traditionally run a closed shop. They generally scorn public accountability and they generally run a very rigid industrial relations system. They are inclined to deal formally with government and government bodies such as the Industries Assistance Commission. This can make the situation very difficult .

I should like to indicate to the House the position in terms of actual statistics and facts so far as I have been able to ascertain them. I refer to production. In the year ending May 1976, steel production at the biggest plant in the country, Port Kembla, was 4.7 million tonnes, raw steel weight. Last year , at the end of May 1981, it was only 4.8 million tonnes. The yearly figure six months later, to the end of November, was 4.5 million tonnes only. At the end of November last year, on an annual basis, less steel was being produced at Port Kembla than in 1976. So far as imports are concerned, in 1976 504,000 tonnes were imported into Australia in terms of ingot equivalent. Up to May 1981 the figure was 914,000 tonnes. In areas directly competitive to BHP, 760,000 tonnes of raw steel equivalent were imported into Australia to the year ended September 1981. That was an increase of 40 per cent over the figure for the preceding 12 months.

It is a source of great concern and worry to us that the proposed new gas pipeline from the North West Shelf development to Perth will not contain, at this stage, one single tonne of Australian steel. Yet imports have risen by 40 per cent over the past year. The figures show that 210,000 tonnes of pipe will be used-100,000 tonnes will be supplied as finished pipe from Japan, 70,000 tonnes of pipe will come from Italy, and 40,000 tonnes will be supplied by Steel Mains at Kwinana. But that is to be manufactured from Japanese plate. BHP and the steel division of Australian Iron and Steel have informed me that they had the capacity to supply that steel but because of a lack of government intervention to help them not one single tonne of Australian steel will be going into the North West Shelf pipeline to Perth.

Steel exports are very erratic and are difficult to assess. In the year ended 31 May 1972, 280,000 tonnes were exported from Port Kembla. By 1978 that had risen to 1 1/2 million tonnes but by 1981 it had dropped to 761,000 tonnes for the comparable periods. Since July last year there has been a blip in exports. About 660,000 tonnes have been exported from Port Kembla in the months July 1981 to February 1982. That is an increase of 280,000 tonnes on the comparable period a year before. But the company says that the export market is significantly weakening once again. Two points need to be made here. There has been a very rapid decline over 4 years. In 1978 the export component of production was 35 per cent from Port Kembla. It had declined to 16 per cent of total production up to May last year. It can be said that although there has been an increase in exports over the last few months the company has been selling at a very marginal profit mainly to keep production rolling and employment stable. But, as I will show, that has not actually occurred. Profitability in the industry is well down in terms of funds employed. BHP indicated that in the year to November 1981 its steel division made a loss of $139m. Two points should be made about that. BHP employs an accounting method known as fixed asset utilisation. Using normal accounting procedures it made $128m profit to November 1981. However, $105m of that was made up till May, and in the next six months it made only $23m profit. I am sure this House will agree that that is not very much profit to make on funds invested of between $2 billion and $3 billion.

The points I want to raise are: Where is this industry going? What is the Government doing about it? Where are the industry policies? What is the situation as a result of the facts and figures I have just outlined? At Kwinana, steelmaking has shut up shop. The blast furnace has closed and over 400 jobs have gone. In Newcastle one blast furnace is out of action and one coke oven battery has been closed down. At Port Kembla two blast furnaces are out of action. The No. 2 blast furnace has not been brought back on line since an expensive reline. I refer now to employment. At the Port Kembla steel division of Australian Iron and Steel 19,900 people are employed. That labour force is down-by attrition; that is non-replacement-by 682 since September last. That attrition is continuing at the rate of 30 people per week. If it continues, this means that in Port Kembla alone, the biggest steel mill in the country, there will be a decline in the labour force of 2,200 permanent jobs just in Australian Iron and Steel, without taking into account the multiplier effect, in one and a half years. Mr Burgess, the General Manager of the AIS Steel Division, said recently-this received some national publicity-that 3,000 jobs would go in the steel industry over the next 12 months.

If this were happening in the car industry, in textiles or in footwear, the protests would reverberate around the country. But because it is happening in steel, there is silent attrition, the silent loss of employment, and this Government is lamentably silent. We are faced with the loss of 2,200 jobs in one particular area, the Illawarra district. I hope that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) will make some protest about that. I see that he will be speaking next in the debate. The Minister has not done so. In the area of Warilla the Commonwealth Employment Service private statistics show that in February of this year the unemployment registrations for people under 21 were up by 66 per cent on February of last year, and yet we shall have there a situation in which up to 2,200 jobs could be lost, over the 18 months.

Regrettably, Australian Iron and Steel is looking at this from a purely productivity point of view and is saying that this will continue unless it can improve productivity per capita by about 50 per cent. As I have said, that is pretty hard on the workers, because the figures that I have just given are indisputable. There should be means, other than shedding labour, by which productivity can be improved, and that is by the introduction of new technology. The record there is not very good, because at Port Kembla we have seen a new coke ovens battery undertaken for $140m and new extensions to the basic oxygen plant for $150m, but that is not really adequate investment in the biggest steel area in the country when one considers that last year this Government made available $54.4m to the AIS Steel Division in terms of the investment allowance and the depreciation allowance.

We want to know what is going to happen. Obviously, the steel industry waits on domestic economic recovery. Under this Government it will wait a long time. It is worried because the share of the construction phase of the resources boom that never was has not eventuated, yet this Government still remains silent. We still want the Government to come up--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume).
—With its decision on the temporary assistance application and set up a task force to investigate the problems in the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity of following my next door neighbour--
—I hope that the honourable member will be constructive about it.

—I hope that the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) will be quiet for a while. He kept on talking when it was my turn, anyway. The honourable member, who is my next door neighbour electorally, naturally is expressing the sort of concern that he should express-I express it also-about the decline in employment in our region as a result of what is happening in the steel industry. The difference between us, of course, is that he, like the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), found the reason for this downturn in employment and production in Port Kembla and other steelworks around Australia as being due to-and I quote the honourable member for Adelaide-'the incompetence and stupidity of the Australian Government'. I wonder whether the honourable member for Adelaide can explain in the same terms the fact that in Sweden the steel industry has just put off 8 per cent of its steel work force permanently, or that in the United States 68,000 steel workers have been laid off and another 22,000 are on short time. I wonder whether it is due to 'the incompetence and stupidity of the Australian Government'-once again to quote the honourable member for Adelaide-that in the European Common Market there has been a fall in employment of 48,000 steel workers in 1981 as a result of consumption going down 11 per cent. In other words, what we have just listened to from the Opposition is utter bunkum. To try to blame the Federal Government for what is happening in the steel industry around the world is typical incredible nonsense from the Opposition, and I am astounded that that kind of line, from men who know the reality of this industry, should proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall take up a couple of points made by the honourable member for Cunningham . It is intriguing to notice that in his introduction he mentioned that industrial disruption was a factor in what had had happened in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said 'poor industrial relations'.

—Poor industrial relations-I stand corrected. The honourable member shrinks from using the term 'industrial disruption', but that is the accurate description of what has happened. The honourable member for Cunningham, like me, went to talk to the executives of Australian Iron and Steel, in Port Kembla, because both of us are concerned about what is happening there. What interests me is to see that the honourable member comes into the House and curiously decides to omit some of the most significant segments of the briefing that we both received. Let me state what that significant section is. It is that industrial disruption in the six months to last November caused an estimated loss in sales value of $115m from Australian Iron and Steel's Port Kembla plant alone. The tonnage of raw steel lost within the plant itself as a result of internal disputes was 229,581 tonnes. External disputes, such as that extraordinary tug dispute in Port Kembla when the whole port was held up for ages because someone hit someone else on the jaw-they were both employees on a tug; it must have been the most expensive knock to the jaw, including any that Mohammed Ali managed-cost another 230,000 tonnes of raw steel. There was a total loss of production, in the six months only, of almost half a million tonnes of raw steel. Is it not incredible that the honourable member for Cunningham, in joining with the honourable member for Adelaide in saying that it is all the Government's fault, omitted to mention these enormous costs of industrial disruption--
—What have you got to say about imports?

—Which have done so much to damage the capacity of Australian Iron and Steel to produce steel competitively. This is the essence. The reason that this company managed to lose the contracts to supply the North West Shelf was given by the honourable member for Cunningham as 'because of lack of Government determination to help them'. I think that is what he said.
—Lack of Government intervention.
—That is right-because of lack of Government intervention to help them. That is the honourable member's explanation of what AIS told him.
—Don't you think--
—Order! The honourable member for Cunningham will remain silent.
—What AIS said-I have it written down-was this:

SPEECH.PARA: We lost the contract because basically price was the major factor in BHP not achieving any of the tonnage.

It was price. BHP could not compete because of a mixture of things, particularly -I stress this-the incredible volume of industrial disruption which has added enormously to the unit cost of production of steel in Australia.

If only the union movement would recognise, in these areas where there are so many ridiculous disputes, the impact of this kind of industrial disruption on the capacity of Australian firms to compete against imports or to compete in export markets, surely then it would realise that it is costing it jobs. The losses of jobs in the steel industry in Australia are partly due-not entirely; I accept that-to the incredible and unnecessary volume of industrial disruption. I think it worth pointing out that as a result of this kind of activity and as a result of the effective competition that has taken place in nations such as Korea, where there is a will to work and a determination to make the industry succeed-we have at present in Australia a delegation from Pohang Steel in Korea- people of those nations find that they are able to compete with Australia. They come here, and they buy their iron ore here-much of it, by the way, from BHP. They buy their coal here. They take it all away to Korea. But because there is greater productivity and greater determination to work, they can produce steel at a price that is relatively so low as compared with Australia's that they can export the finished product back here and undercut us. Certainly there are allegations that to some extent they have an ability to do this because they are dumping the product; they are selling it at artificially low prices. That is the area in which the Government quite rightly can and does intervene. As the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) said, a reference in respect of that kind of problem quite properly is being investigated and being prepared to go to the Temporary Assistance Authority. That is the area in which the Government can and does help. It is also helping in regard to depreciation rates, as the honourable member for Berowra said, in order to try to make this industry more efficient despite the industrial disruption that persistently goes against it and despite the pressure for shorter working hours. At a time when we are being priced out of markets the union movement is deciding that the way to solve this problem is to hike up wage rates and make it even more expensive to produce Australian steel.

Let us look at how this policy of getting paid as much as possible for, regrettably, very minimal productivity, has proceeded. I have some charts concerning BHP which illustrate this aspect. They were shown to the honourable member for Cunningham but he chose not to refer to them. They show that in Australia, for example, the index of hourly labour costs has gone up from a base level of 100 to a level of 329-there has been something like 230 per cent rise in BHP's labour costs between 1971 and 1980-while the index for productivity has gone up only 8 per cent. That is the worst record of any of the steel producing nations of the world, except, of course, Britain. We should compare it with Germany, where hourly labour costs have gone up from an index level of 100 to 213. However, productivity per man has gone up from 100 to 136. Throughout the world there are incredible increases in productivity whereas in Australia we have a very modest rise and an enormous rise in costs. It seems to me that while many points about the need for some assistance to the Australian steel industry are accurate, they must be seen in the context that the world market for steel is in disarray and the union movement has yet to recognise that every time it adds to the industry's costs by reckless industrial disruption it is helping to sign the death warrant of thousands of jobs in that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned young citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is an urgent need to take steps to terminate the inhumane, random slaughter of baby fur seals in Canada, in order to prevent their eventual extinction.
Your petitioners urge that action be taken to:
(a) inform the Government of Canada of our opposition to the annual slaughter of young fur seals as currently practised in that country;
(b) actively discourage any form of trading that involves goods or products derived (either wholly or partially) from the pelts of baby fur seals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of 129 undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and the responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society' s inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation, and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction, in the provision of accommodation, and the provision of goods and services; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fry and Mr Sainsbury.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett and Mr Burr.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licenced clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett and Mrs Child.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers particularly educational publications and books of a religious nature , is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and
That no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitoners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

1. The proposed two and one half per cent sales tax to be levied on clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and wrapping materials, hand tools, etc. would be regressive and inflationary.
2. The burden being carried by pensioners and other people on low incomes is becoming insufferable, and is sapping the morale and assaulting the dignity of a large and proud section of our Nation.
3. We therefore request that the proposed legislation be not enacted, and further, that existing sales taxes on all household goods be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Milton and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern. We call on the Federal Government not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. It is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resultant from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourble the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty years leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and such plans should be discontinued.
That Federal funding of children's services should be restored to at least 1975 -76 in real terms so that children's services can be more fully provided throughout Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hearing Aids: Import Duty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned individuals concerned with the welfare of the hearing impaired citizens of Australia.
Respectfully showeth: that there are approximately one million people in Australia who suffer severe problems with their hearing.

That the greatest percentage of adults with hearing impairment are not eligible for NAL aids. (1978 Australian Bureau of Statistics. 38.79 per cent of hearing impaired are aged between 45 and 64 years).
That the accepted useful life of a hearing aid is only 3-5 years.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House reject all recommendations that may subject hearing aids to any import duty (IAC propose 15 per cent) and thus ensure hearing handicapped persons be not further disadvantaged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The petitioners' fear and condemnation of Australia's chronic decline from a land of prosperity, generosity and peace to a strike-torn, minority controlled and broken country. This is due to Union corruption and interference which is applied using undesirable methods including black banning and threats.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Prime Minister and the Members of the House of Representatives will introduce legislation to ensure the following:

1. That the Union system is revised to encompass the secret ballot which is the only fair and just indication of what the people really want. Wives or de-facto wives names should be included on their husbands' or de-facto husbands' Union ticket at no extra cost and they should be entitled to a secret vote on all issues which involve their breadwinners. This is a valid request as in a strike action women and children are usually the deprived parties. Household and often financial management is frequently left to the wives and therefore they should be entitled to a vote in any Union dispute directly affecting them before having hardships imposed upon them.

2. That the Unions are restricted to fullfilling their original purpose which is to negotiate fair wages and conditions for their members and not to interfere in external affairs outside their immediate employment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interest of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the budget announcements which include the raising of or imposing of, Sales Tax on the many items which must be provided by parents for their children's schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect Australia's students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading purposes, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential education items.
Your petitioners request that the Government (or Senate) will not impose any further tax on these items which are needed for the educational progress of Australia's students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned, register our strong opposition to the Federal Government's proposed 2 1/2 per cent Sales Tax on books. This proposed tax is a tax on knowledge and communication. We therefore request that books continue to be Sales Tax exempt.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''noninstitutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a ''disability'' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Goverment to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The recent increase of 1 per cent in home loan interest rates will cause intolerable hardship to Australian families struggling to buy or repay homes. This hardship is forcing many people to sell their homes as they cannot meet the repayments due to spiralling home loan interest rates.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament will:
(1) Cancel the recent 1 per cent increase and freeze home loan interest rates.
(2) Index home loan repayments on the cost of the average home to a maximum of 25 per cent of the average Australian weekly wage.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn the Commonwealth Liberal Government for its inhumane policies, implemented in May 1981, of transferring funds for public health to private enterprise.

We point out that resultant severe cuts in funding to Public Hospitals, Community Health and Ambulance Services have caused enormous unnecessary suffering and hardship for people who must use these facilities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government immediately restors the previous level of funding and introduce a genuine National Health Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Mallee respectfully showeth that in respect:
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982/83 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas Subsidy
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Murray respectfully showeth that in respect:
(1) The current electricity supply crisis in Australia, and

(2) the one million household and business Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) users in rural and provincial Australia who are already paying considerably more for their gas than those Australians, mostly in capital cities, who are connected to natural gas and who will be further disadvantaged if the Commonwealth Government does not renew the LPG subsidy of $80 a tonne which expires in March 1983.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will extend the LPG subsidy for a further three years and include a specific appropriation in the 1982 Budget so the subsidy can continue uninterrupted throughout the 1982-83 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,

Queensland has suffered a 15% disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding, and the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon, M.P.

1. That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principle outstanding was $15,005.

2. That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

3. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in Victoria who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria sheweth that the Federal Government intends merging the 'Institute of Early Childhood Development' with another body.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government continue funding the 'Institute of Early Childhood Development' as an autonomous specialist institution, recognising that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and therefore Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr N.A. Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Excise tariff Act 1921 to enact the excise tariff alterations made by Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1981) and No. 1 (1982). Excise Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1981) were moved in the House on 25 August 1981. These proposals, which operate from 1 July 1981, increased the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $174.08 to $177.53 per kilolitre and on naturally occuring liquefied petroleum gas from $36.67 to $37. 07 per kilolitre.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1982) were moved in the house on 17 February 1982. These proposals, which operate from 1 January 1982, further increase the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $177.53 to $186.26 per kilolitre but reduce the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $37.07 to $20.46 per kilolitre.

The alterations accord with the Government's policy of adjusting the price of indigenous crude oil to world parity, as determined by the Minister for National Development and Energy, on 1 January and 1 July each year. This policy is well established and widely understood by the Australian community. It is based upon sound economic and conservation principles.

The crude oil levy is an important aspect of the policy. It ensures that a fair share of the income from import parity price adjustments goes to public revenue. Without the levy, taxation would need to be significantly higher in order to finance the services demanded of government and the gains from import parity pricing would go to the oil producers as a windfall profit. The success of the Government's crude oil pricing policy has been based upon its openness, predictability and equitable sharing of income gains. That policy requires that, in the interests of conservation and responsible management of scarce liquid fuel resources, prices of petroleum products be set at realistic levels. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May 1981, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement on this Bill in light of the fact that it has been lying on the table for some 11 months and substantial amendments are to be made to it by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Honourable members will recall that I introduced the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 on 7 May last year. I indicated then that it was not my intention to proceed any further with the Bill at that stage as I was keen to give interested people and organisations adequate opportunity to study the proposals. I wanted to encourage informed public debate and therefore improved understanding of the intent of this legislation. I believe such debate has occurred and we are therefore in a position to proceed further with the Bill .

SPEECH.PARA: During the time between last May and now I have received numerous letters from a wide cross-section of the community on various aspects of the plant variety rights issue. Furthermore, I am aware that a number of seminars have been conducted, and the matter again considered by the Australian Agricultural Council, at its last meeting in Adelaide on 8 February of this year.

Following that meeting I announced my intention to proceed with the legislation . My decision was based on the fact that nine months had passed to allow for public discussion and that there was general support for the scheme in the Agricultural Council from the States of Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory. There is also general support from all national rural industry organisations with a direct interest in the legislation, including the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation, the Australian United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association, the Australian Seed Producers Federation, the Australian Nurserymen 's Association and the Australian Seed Industry Association. I did give an undertaking at the Agricultural Council that I would take into account the views of the States before proceeding further with the legislation, and this has been done.

The plant variety rights issue has raised considerable interest within the community. I believe a number of points of general concern and misunderstanding remain, on which I would like to comment. Perhaps the most important point to stress about this legislation is that it will be entirely voluntary-in other words, there will be no requirement for a breeder of a new variety to register it under the scheme unless he wishes to do so. Also, the scheme will be open only to new varieties. All existing plant varieties will be ineligible for inclusion. These are fundamental points, which have tended to be overlooked by opponents of the scheme.

Some people believe that plant variety rights will give rise to monopoly control of our food supply and restrict public access to plant material. This is not so. As all varieties existing at present will not be eligible for grants of rights, it can be expected that they will continue to be available for any purpose, so long as there is a demand for them. With regard to new varieties registered under the Scheme, the public will be able to reproduce and sell them for food or fuel or manufacturing purposes or other utilitarian purposes which do not involve the actual growing of the plants. The permission of the owner will be required only for the sale of the variety for growing purposes. There are provisions in the Bill to prevent monopolistic practices, in that the owner of a right will be obliged to supply reasonable quantities of the variety at reasonable prices.

One of the most persistent arguments against plant variety rights is that the scheme may lead to takeovers of Australian seed firms by multinational chemical companies. I can only reiterate what I told the House last May: Take-over bids can occur in any business activity, including the seed industry. There is nothing unusual about that in a free enterprise system. However, I am confident that if any takeovers should occur in the Australian seed industry they will in no way be as a direct result of plant variety rights legislation.

There is the view that the criteria of distinctness, uniformity and stability would encourage the narrowing of the genetic base of commercial plant varieties. Distinctness, uniformity and stability are the universal criteria required for recognition of a new variety irrespective of whether it is a candidate for rights. The same criteria are required by established registers such as the Australian Herbage Cultivar Register, the Oilseeds Register and the Coarse Grains Register. Dependence on uniformity is a trend throughout the world. With efficiency in production being increasingly linked to mechanised handling of a uniform crop and consumer demand for a uniform product, it is a function of modern farming and is not related to plant variety rights.

A related issue concerns the preservation of plant genetic resources for use in future breeding programs. This is certainly an important issue but it has nothing whatsoever to do with plant variety rights. It is a totally separate issue. Gene banks, or seed collections, particularly for the major crops, are already in existence in Australia and are expanding. Work on improving existing collections and establishing new ones is continuing-but, again, quite separate from plant variety rights.
