It is being claimed by some that with PVR public breeding will decline. However , while there has been a tendency in some European countries for public breeding efforts to be directed increasingly towards basic research, information from New Zealand indicates that PVR has increased the effectiveness of State plant breeders, with more and better varieties being released. My view is that Australian agriculture has been well served by the high quality of its public breeding programs and I can see no reason why this situation will not continue.

There is a fear that farmers and consumers will be forced to pay higher prices for seeds and plants registered under the scheme. While it might be expected that the owner of a right will set a premium on his variety, it must be remembered that farmers will still be free to choose the variety they wish to use. Farmers would buy a patented variety only if it were in their interests to do so. Also, breeding firms will not be successful unless they offer a product which is competitive.

It has been said that PVR creates a fundamental injustice toward those countries of the Third World where much of the world's breeding material is derived. This is simply not true. If a Third World country wishes to receive compensation from overseas collectors of wild varieties it is a matter for those countries to pursue. It is not a matter related to the Australian plant variety rights scheme. It should be recognised that the collecting of germ plasm has taken place for years, well before plant variety rights was ever thought of, and is essential to the broadening of the genetic base of our economic plants.

The view has been expressed that Australian native flora should not be subject to plant variety rights. Let me reiterate that no existing variety of plant, native or otherwise, will be eligible for a grant of rights. Furthermore, no variety which is merely discovered will be eligible. Therefore, all Australian native flora varieties will be ineligible for registration. A variety bred or developed from a native plant could be eligible, but then it would not be part of our native flora.

It has been suggested that the establishment of a plant variety rights scheme may not be the best way to stimulate effort in plant breeding. Options open to the Government for stimulating plant breeding have been carefully examined. It was concluded that the most appropriate way to stimulate plant breeding in Australia while also providing access to desired overseas varieties was by the use of plant variety rights which would provide a fair reward for investment by both Australian and overseas breeders.

The question of merit testing has also had some airing over recent months. Some people appear to be of the view that, in considering the granting of a right, the merit or the quality of the variety should be a criterion for the right. However, the granting of a right to a particular variety in no way implies that the variety is better than an existing one-merely, that it is different. To the best of my knowledge, no other countries with plant variety rights legislation include merit testing as an integral part of the Scheme. I believe it is very much up to the market-place to determine whether one variety is better than another. Coupled with this is the question of a national list of plant varieties which are permitted to be sold. Some European countries do have such lists. However, there is no intention to develop a national list for Australia. This means that there will be no list which regulates or stipulates what plant varieties can be legally sold.

There have also been claims that the lack of a PVR scheme in Australia has not prevented plant breeders from obtaining breeding material from overseas. There are many examples where requests for overseas varieties have been refused because Australia has not had a PVR scheme. Varieties of nectarines, peaches, cherries, plums, grapes, ornamental plants and some field crops are some examples. Plant variety rights will enable Australia to have access to a far wider variety of plants from overseas, and this must benefit the local industry. It is also nonsense to suggest that PVR will lead to the production of poor quality farm crops that are more susceptible to pests and disease. Farmers and gardeners simply will not buy varieties which are susceptible to pests or disease, when they can continue to buy existing varieties which have already been proven. Neither are breeders going to develop, register and market new varieties which cannot compete in the market-place against existing varieties.

Claims that PVR will lead to restrictions on public availability of seeds and information are also without foundation. Plant variety rights will encourage investment by breeders in Australia and this must lead to a greater variety of seeds and plants being available. The New Zealand experience in this regard has been an increase in the flow of scientific information and breeding material since PVR was introduced there in the mid-1970s. No decision has been made that Australia become a member of the International Union for the Protection of New Varieties of Plants-UPOV. Its purpose is to assist member countries with the operation of their schemes by exchange of technical information and to encourage reciprocity arrangements between countries. Membership is entirely voluntary, and it is not seen as necessary for Australia to be a member. This, of course, could be considered at a later stage, if State governments and industry thought it worth while.

On the question of funding, it is intended that ultimately income from fees will meet the cost of administering the scheme. In the meantime, the Commonwealth will accept responsibility for funding, which is estimated initially to be $100,000 a year. Registration fees will be set shortly. It is expected that they will be in line with comparable fees overseas, which are mostly less than $1,000.

Honourable members will recall that the purpose of the Bill is to make possible the granting of proprietary rights, somewhat similar to a grant of patent rights , to people who breed or develop new plant varieties. As a result of the consideration and debate that have been undertaken since last May, a number of changes are proposed to the Bill as it currently stands. These amendments have resulted largely from decisions taken at meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council, from consultations between Commonwealth and State officials, and from representations received from the public. Honourable members will recall that I authorised the circulation of the proposed amendments last month.

One of the most significant amendments calls for the deletion of the sub-clause which currently provides for the scheme to be restricted to cover only horticultural, ornamental and other selected pasture and fodder species. The intention now is that the scheme will be open to any new plant species approved by the Australian Agricultural Council. At the outset no species will be included in the scheme. The fundamental aim of the Bill, nonetheless, remains as it was when initially introduced. That is to say that the scheme, as set out in the Bill, will permit a plant breeder who has developed a new plant variety to apply to a registration authority for the grant of a right to confer sole ownership of that variety on him, if he so wishes. Such rights will allow plant breeders to collect royalties.

The detail of the amendments can be dealt with individually during the debate and I do not propose to go further into them at present. I thank the House for allowing me to make this statement. I believe this Bill opens up prospects for encouraging greater development of small plant breeding firms in Australia and, therefore, an increase in the number of new plant varieties available and improvements in the efficiency of Australian plant industries.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 10 and 11 (1982).

May I at the outset thank the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) and the House for their indulgence to enable me to move these Customs Tariff Proposals. I am indebted to the honourable member for his assistance. I have moved the Proposals described as Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 10 and 11 (1982) in the terms of the printed proposals which are now being circulated to honourable members.

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 10 (1982) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff changes made by Gazette notice during the last recess. These Proposals, which operate from 1 April 1982, contain changes resulting from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on works trucks, certain mobile machines and pallet trucks. The Government has accepted the broad thrust of the IAC recommendations contained in this report.

The Government did not, however, accept the long term duty rate of 20 per cent recommended by the IAC for most of the goods under reference. The Government preferred the slightly higher rate of 25 per cent because it will allow for more significant local manufacture with very little resultant cost burden for users; and it is more consistent with the duty levels applying to other goods with similar inputs, technical skills and production processes. In addition, the Government did not accept the recommendation by the IAC to cease licensing restrictions on imports of second hand goods, because of the uncertainty and disruption this could cause to the Australian industry.

The overall effect of the Government's decision is that tow tractors remain dutiable at minimum rates; fork lift trucks, manual stackers and pallet trucks will be dutiable at 30 per cent for one year before reducing to the long term rate of 25 per cent; other works trucks under reference will be dutiable at 25 per cent on implementation; and import licensing ceases for battery electric works trucks but will continue on used, secondhand and disposal equipment.

Proposals No. 11 (1982), which operate from tomorrow, are new and arise from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the IAC in its reports on fruit and fruit products; miscellaneous edible foodstuffs; and miscellaneous manufacturing (Group G)-Writing and marking equipment.

In respect of fruit and fruit products, the Government has accepted the recommendations by the IAC except in respect of cherries preserved in sugar, for which the period over which rates are to be reduced has been lengthened to allow a more stable adjustment within the industry. The overall effect of the Government's decision on fruit and fruit products is that certain processed fruit products and passionfruit and passionfruit products will reduce to 15 per cent; fruit preserved by sugar, except cherries, will be dutiable at 15 per cent ; cherries preserved in sugar will be dutiable at 30 per cent initially, reducing to 15 per cent over four years; and other fresh or provisionally preserved fruit under reference will be dutiable at minimum rates. Such duties will simplify the Customs tariff and largely maintain current assistance levels.

In respect of miscellaneous edible foodstuffs, the Government has accepted all recommendations of the IAC, subject to a variation in the rates to apply to canned sweet corn. Imports of canned sweet corn from New Zealand, the main source of import competition, will be dutiable at 10 per cent that being the general rate recommended by the IAC. Imports from general country sources will, however, be dutiable at 20 per cent to allow a margin of preference to New Zealand in accordance with the Australia-New Zealand Agreement on tariffs and tariff preferences.

The effect of the Government's decision on this report is that macaroni, spaghetti and similar products and textured or hydrolysed vegetable protein will be dutiable at 10 per cent; canned sweet corn will be dutiable at 20 per cent; and other foods under preference will be dutiable at minimum rates.

Local production of these goods is currently lightly assisted. The continuation of low levels of assistance is considered adequate to encourage efficient local production. In respect of writing and marketing equipment the Government has accepted the recommendations of the IAC except in regard to the phased reduction of rates for typewriter and similar ribbons of textile materials where the Government has lengthened the period over which the rates will reduce to allow a more stable adjustment within the industry. The Government's decision on this report means that: Typewriter and similar ribbons of textile material will be dutiable at 30 per cent initially, reducing to 20 per cent over two years; pens, penholders, propelling pencils, pencils other than slate pencils, ink pads, typewriter and similar ribbons of other than textile material will be dutiable at 20 per cent; and other goods under reference such as sealing or numbering stamps, sealing wax and copying paste will be dutiable at minimum rates.

The long term rate of 20 per cent for most of these goods will generally maintain the existing levels of assistance. The new duty arrangements will also simplify the Customs tariff by replacing the existing combinations of specific and ad valorem duty applying to some goods and will align assistance levels with related goods. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the reports of the Industries Assistance Commission on Miscellaneous Edible Foodstuffs, Fruit and Fruit Products, and Miscellaneous Manufacturing Group G: Writing and Marking Equipment .

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not implacably opposed to the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981, but we have profound doubts about it. We have doubts mainly for agricultural reasons but for many others as well. We are opposed because we are of the opinion that it does not meet Australia's additional plant breeding needs. We are opposed because it will cause a diminution in, if not complete disruption of, present Australian public plant breeding. We are opposed because it poses dangers to Australia's agricultural producing and marketing systems and institutions. We are opposed because it will subject Australian primary producers to inadequately tested so called 'new' varieties bred either locally or introduced from overseas. We are opposed because it does not meet many contemporary scientific and practical qualifications and objections to PVR. We are opposed because it is being introduced at a time when serious questioning of the various plant variety systems in the world is taking place and reviews are under way. We are opposed because there are some fundamental questions as to the world's food and plant genetic resources that need to be answered.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I gave notice of a motion for the formation of a select committee of this House to examine publicly the pros and cons of this very complex and multifaceted issue. The Opposition welcomes the chance for a long debate in the Parliament on this subject. We will be indicating many of our objections to the Bill by moving amendments when we are in the Committee stage. Quite frankly, I must say that the Bill is a dog's breakfast. The Bill should have been withdrawn and reprinted. I find it very hard to deal with when it has 27 amendments, to which I will be moving another 41 amendments. It shows what a mess the Government is in when it presents a Bill which has been on the table for nearly a year and which comes up for debate as two documents.

The amendments we will be putting are the minimum the Australian Labor Party would accept for this to be a Bill that goes some way to being a Bill that meets Australian agricultural requirements. No doubt most of them will be rejected, but they will indicate very clearly that we are not implacably opposed to any system of plant variety rights. However, the Opposition believes that what we really need first is a proper searching public inquiry-an investigation into Australia's plant breeding needs and deficiencies in our plant breeding organisation, safeguards that will ensure Australian plant growers have a chance of being able to get better seeds and plants and the whole question of alternatives to and the implications of existing PVR schemes. At the outset I must say I have never been so heavily lobbied on any issue in my political life. One or two people have actually written to me in favour of the Bill. I have never spent so much time as I have in reading about PVR, investigating PVR and in talking to people for and against PVR. I am still learning of new aspects to the question and will not cover one-twentieth of what I would like to say on this Bill.

This is not just an agricultural Bill. The groups and individuals opposed to the Bill range from fringe loonies-those people who generally vote for the National Country Party-to alternative lifestylers, theologians, botanists, scientists, ideologists, consumers, conservationists and the Food and Agricultural Organisation of the United Nations. One can have doubts or be opposed to the Bill on ideological, philosophical, theological as well as scientific and practical grounds. I respect most points of view in this category as being as legitimate and valid as I do the ideologies in favour of PVR.

There are many views in opposition that, frankly, I do not understand. Some views are quite crazy. Some views are mistaken. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has spoken of some of those today. Some views are overstressed. Some views are misplaced. Some views reflect ideological or hypothetical arguments which have little to do with PVR per se, but I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the views of the orthomolecular nutritionists who have written to me are just as firmly held as those who want PVR to make more money, and who are not concerned with any wider issue. The views I will be putting by way of opposition or qualification concern agriculture. I will leave it to other honourable members to canvass wider but possibly more peripheral arguments for and against.

The Government cannot deny that there are many people working in agriculture who are opposed to the Bill. The Bill was held up because the Country Party Minister in Western Australia and the Western Australian Department of Agriculture were opposed to it. I have been told that Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia are not really that keen for cereals to be specified species under the proposed Act. Farmer organisations still have strong reservations about the Bill. Many people in the rural establishment are opposed to the Bill-off the record. The fact that the Minister will bring forward 27 amendments to a Bill that has been about 11 years in the making is evidence of the many doubts about the Bill in the Australian Agricultural Council and the qualifications agriculturalists and technicians have seen as necessary before the Bill could even be presented for debate.

The Bill, if amended, will still not meet all the objections of people in favour of PVR. Many more nurserymen have written to me opposed to the Bill than in favour. Of Australia's 28 to 30 public cereal breeders at least 10 are either vociferously opposed to the Bill or have serious doubts for a range of reasons. I can mention names such as Sparrow, Pugsley, Rathjen, Hollamby, Gladstone, et cetera, as public plant breeders strongly opposed to PVR. In the United States, the National Farmers Union and the National Sharecroppers Fund oppose PVR. Norman Borlog, an eminent United States plant breeder and Nobel Peace Prize winner, is opposed to PVR. CIMMYT, the international maize and wheat improvement centre in Mexico, does not recognise the right of any country or organisation to apply for exclusive breeders' rights on material produced in its program. It is only now in the United States that an independent evaluation of PVR is being carried out, by the University of Wisconsin. New Zealand has recently deleted some important items from its PVR lgislation.

People in and elements of the scientific community are both for and against the Bill for a range of scientific, institutional and philosophical reasons. I have had only one farmer write to me in favour of the Bill. Hundreds have written in opposition. Several farm groups have written opposing parts of the Bill, but it is true that most agricultural organisations now accept PVR, even if in a qualified way. No-one disagrees that we need to assess thoroughly Australia's plant breeding needs and that the future of plant breeding in this country is very important. There is great potential and exciting technologies are in the offering. It is a topic that we really do need to take on board very seriously from an agricultural point of view. I have been driven to near desperation by thousands of people writing in opposition-ranging from cliched predictability to tirades of abuse. Only three people or groups have written to me in favour of the Bill. Even then I had to seek out the main proponents.

The Bill is complex but plant variety rights are even more complex and raise fundamental questions which cannot be blandly dismissed by thinking people. I have given all these qualifications to my views because I hope that the Government does not simply label any opposition as being always ill-placed or simply ideological. I put it to the House that the Australian Labor Party has never considered an agricultural issue in as much depth as it has this one. I hope that the Minister will actually enter the debate rather than simply read speeches or repeat his Department's comments. This is a very important issue.

In a nutshell PVR is about giving patent rights to plant breeders for new varieties of plants. The scheme is voluntary and applies only to new varieties. The ostensible motivation behind the scheme in Australia is to encourage private plant breeding. The main difference between the proposal and patents for things such as drugs is that the material is living and one can engage in semantic argument as to what is an invention. As much of the capitalist developed and communist worlds have plant breeders or plant variety right systems, it is held that Australia is being denied access to varieties that grow well in overseas environments and may grow well here. It can be seen that the Bill is about plant breeding in Australia and about plant buying from overseas. On the face of it, it is reasonable to point out that PVR will lead to more plant breeding because a right will grant a quasi-monopoly and therefore there is an incentive for new entrants to enter the plant breeding field despite the very high cost of entry. It is assumed that more breeding equals better breeding. Also, due to the fact that our market is small for many species, little work is being carried out. It will advantage particularly horticulturalists if new varieties can be introduced .

The Opposition accepts that both these propositions may be true. We accept that horticulturalists, floriculturalists and nurserymen are being denied access to varieties due to the requirements and practices of overseas patent rights holders. However, there are several qualifications that need to be discussed with respect to introduced varieties. Firstly, while a variety may grow well overseas there is no guarantee that it will do as well in our environment. For example, there is no sense in growing red chief apple here if it proves to be not as good as other varieties, or it turns brown. A nurseryman is not particularly interested in whether a variety is objectively better so long as it is different; what he is concerned about is diversity. This is not so for people wishing to earn a living from the new plant variety they have bought. In other words there is a need for a commercial and environmental test and in some instances a nutritional test. Also, if horticulturalists such as vegetable growers gain access to a higher yielding variety and it is subsequently shown that it yields higher in the Australian environment, it does not follow that the grower will gain all the potential benefit. Many vegetable growers are bound by contract to processors and any economic benefit will be shared in an economically competitive system by producer, processor, wholesaler, retailer and perhaps the consumer. Also, it is possible that it will be the processor- integrator who buys a right and, for example, by controlling it, denies potato growers, other than those contracted to him, the variety.

There are factors other than variety that affect the commercial situation of orchardists. Even if there are varieties of apples so good that orchardists are unwise not to grow them, it does not follow that they will make more money or that they will be attracted to growing that variety. For example, at present in Australia we are pulling out apple trees due to the fact that previous markets, particularly the European market, are denied to us. As it will take ten years really to test how much better a new unknown variety is, it is uncertain that there will be real benefits. The nursery trade will certainly reap windfall profits if certain nurserymen gain the right to a redder rose or a greener pot plant-or things which I do not think there is any need for a test on. But not all nurserymen will have access as it will be sensible commercial practice to give quasi-monopoly rights to a handful of Australian nurserymen- propagators.

The Department of Science and the Evironment recently investigated the nursery industry in Australia from the point of view of the export potential for foliage plants. The report was brought down quite recently in 1982. At no place in the report were plant variety rights mentioned as a needed incentive for a business which is, fortunately, doing well and has been expanding rapidly. The more evident possible benefits for horticulturalists were the main reason why my colleagues, the Honourable Jack Hallam and the Honourable Dr Julian Amos, were concerned that the Australian Agricultural Council discuss alternatives in more depth. The fact that the original Bill was basically only for horticultural varieties is evidence that the Government-or the Australian Agricultural Council -was of the view that we may have a restricted PVR system and thereby potentially gain most benefit. This would have been a naive approach. I stress that overseas varieties, to be used in commercial Australian agriculture, cannot revolutionise our plant production although many people see great gain from it. Qualifications need to be put forward and I will put forward some of them. We need to have commercial varieties which have determined yield, disease-resistant and environment-specific qualities which meet the demands of our market. For new varieties to meet these criteria they will need testing, either formally or by some reliable procedure. After six years of PVR in New Zealand there were rights for only 23 varieties-17 were for roses and six for barley.

I move on to the Opposition's views on the main purpose of this Bill; that is, plant breeding as opposed to plant buying. When I was in the United Kingdom earlier this year I was told by Mr Murphy, the man in charge of Britain's PVR system, that his country's system was mainly about cereals and that, unlike Australia, most growers buy their seed each year. I might add that the British system covers many of the Opposition's objections to the Bill. But the Government is not proposing the British system which has safeguards and which was designed to guarantee a place for public plant breeding and a proper comprehensive system of performance testing so that farmers know that new varieties are better. If the Government should quote the evaluative work of Silvey on British PVR, there are many qualifications that the Opposition would like to put forward. The fundamental thing is that Britain is different from Australia. When I saw the main proponent group in Australia about PVR I was told that its main motive was to get into open pollinated varieties-cereals and field and pasture species-where large potential markets exist. The Australian market is too small for an intensive breeding effort for species such as, for example, radishes. What the group is interested in is propagation of seeds and breeding new varieties where there is a big market.

The Opposition's most trenchant agricultural opposition to this Bill concerns cereal breeding and our belief that PVR will not meet the needs of Australian cereal growers nor the requirements of our marketing and agricultural institutions as it is now proposed. PVR will probably cause only disruption to our present highly developed and largely successful public cereal breeding institutions. If all this Bill is about is a cynical pragmatic device to gain plant material that we cannot buy-everyone is assuming but not saying that private cereal breeding will not take place-it is a dangerous sledgehammer to crack an indeterminable nut. But I do not think it is just about a cynical exercise. I think some people do think that they can get into the cereal breeding game.

I will set out some of the ALP's more general opposition on agricultural grounds to the Bill as well as the specifics of cereal breeding. No appropriately representative group has publicly deliberated on Australia's plant breeding needs, the deficiencies in our plant breeding effort and how we should best go about meeting those deficiencies. I am told that the matter has been discussed by technicians and public servants for the past 11 years. But it has been almost entirely a private commercial approach to a very complex matter involving governments which want to get out of spending money and technologists who quite sensibly want to experiment with new systems and methods. The public interest has not been involved where it is clearly required to be expressed. We do not know what alternatives to PVR have been debated over the past decade or whether anyone really believes that PVR is the only solution.

The second major qualification is that the public plant breeding programs that have served Australia so well, particularly for cereals, need to be protected and upgraded and guarantees of continued public plant breeding need to be given by the AAC. The State Governments command high ground in plant breeding. Only one Minister, an outgoing one, has given any such guarantee and in conversations I have had with State department officials there is a belief that the tendency is for State governments to want to spend less, not more money. For example, the Tasmanian Government has got out of some species in its breeding programs. An approach recently by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation to levy more funds for wheat breeding research was not reciprocated by the present Government.

I think it is an impossible demand to require any politician or government to give a guarantee to maintain a level of funding. People would be sorely disappointed. But there is a more basic problem with this Government. Who could trust this Government in terms of any guarantee it gives in respect of spending on public programs? It has got out of the soil conservation area. It is getting out of research and extension. It is putting the screws on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. A Senate committee is presently inquiring into spending on research. In any area one looks-extension, science and research and development-the government is trying to get out of any public obligation. Quite frankly, the Opposition probably would not even believe anything said by the Fraser Government on those sorts of things.

Let us get back to wheat breeding. Australia's present wheat breeding programs are very institutionally bound. We have a system of varietal control administered by the State governments that conduct most of our public plant breeding. The breeding is intrinsically bound with performance testing, quantitative and qualitative assessment and comparison with existing varieties. Varieties are bred and adapted for our various environments. For example, one can point to the release of new varieties in Western Australia and to a grain varietal conference in Queensland. The latest edition of Wheat Australia details four new wheat varieties in Western Australia which were registered for sowing in the low rainfall northern, north central and central areas of the State. The varieties developed by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture are wialki, eradu, canna and bodallin. That publication goes on to give their characteristics and variety. It states:

In Victoria, a significant advance in breeding wheat for resistance to cereal cyst nematode (or eelworm) has been made at the Victorian Crops Research Institute with the development and release of the variety katyil.

A conference was recently held by the Queensland growers on new guidelines for breeders. I have an edition of their newspaper of 7 April. Again Queensland farmers have released a set of priorities. The conference took a lot of time pointing out that wheat breeding must be guided by market requirements, that there should be uniform sized shape, that no single variety should dominate and that there should be seasonal tolerance. It also points out what resistances should be desirable. If one looks at the present situation and at what a wheat breeder has to go through with the existing system, one sees that a massive document has to be produced containing all the test results before the State Government will release the variety; and then only for certain areas. There are virtual monopolies in grain handling which are required to engage in tests of quality and type to make segregations for the monopoly wheat marketer-the Australian Wheat Board. The system is very institutionally bound.

The Government is proposing that a system be set up which will allow private breeders or overseas companies to introduce varieties not necessarily tested in any way but only required to pass criteria requiring the seed to be distinct, uniform and stable. At present wheat breeders in Australia have to submit new varieties to very exhaustive tests. I have already pointed to 13 pages of documentation for one such new variety that did not get up. The distinct uniform and stable criteria test discourages diversity and many of Australia's outstanding varieties would not have passed this test. I agree with some of the things the Minister said today about that but I still want to point out that while it can be argued that the scheme is voluntary I believe growers would be reluctant to purchase a variety which is neither distinct, uniform, stable nor properly tested. Testing is essential, as the boil smut incident with maize has demonstrated.

Disruption could be caused to our public plant breeding institutions for a range of reasons. From correspondence I have been given between the Minister and some of these people, I can see that he still does not understand their fears. Disruption can be caused if breeders are approached by private firms and if private breeders take material freely available from public institutions and simply make one small change to it. Disruption could be caused to the present free interchange of plant material, ideas and techniques. There is evidence from overseas that private breeders are reticent to speak at industry, scientific or academic conferences. Industries in Australia that are limited by some geographic, institutional or environmental factor are already well set up for plant breeding by a combination of grower liaison and funding by public and private bodies. For example, the rice, sugar, cotton and tobacco industries have plant breeding systems that meet their needs. Why should a system be imposed that potentially exposes the industries to additional costs?

The people who put it to me that they wanted to get into some of these areas say that if they could get the royalties that would be a real incentive to get into cereal breeding. In Australia about one per cent of the wheat planted each year is bought. It costs about $300 a tonne. If a 5 per cent royalty is put on to that we get about enough to pay and set up one plant breeder. We already have 25 plant breeders. This is the reason why there is so much worry. Public plant breeders are concerned at the effects PVR would have on breeding programs. It is thought it will distort the allocation of breeding resources away from basic research into applied research to give short term results. This would mean a long term loss in diversion in funds away from basic programs, for example, disease and climatic resistance. At present Australian plant growers are obtaining plant varieties by a range of mechanisms besides public plant breeding which allow commercial entrepreneurs to gain profits. The practices of price discrimination, control of outlets, advertising and market lead all allow this. Practices such as certification, royalities and licensing all allow access to material. Hybridisation gives inbuilt PVR. The whole question of the promise of biotechnology is not one that can be properly encompassed by this Bill. But it is important to realise what the potential is and how this may affect future optimum plant breeding systems in Australia.

Many hypothetical economic arguments against the Bill have been put up and they are hard to deal with. However, it is feasible to suggest that monopolisation and denial of choice may occur because existing economic-market pressures are causing this to occur in all other industries. United States experience shows that while there has not been absolute monopolisation a handful of the larger companies gain nearly all the rights for many grain, field and pasture crops. As PVR implies quasi-monopoly, it is reasonable to suggest that if a variety did give a yield increase of 20 per cent and was suitable in every other way a firm would be inclined to make four releases somehow guaranteeing a yearly increase of 5 per cent each time. That would be sensible commercial practice.

The question of consumer protection and the legal position of people contesting rights as well as the legal implications of patent law have been raised with me. The Senate reviewed our existing industrial patent law and raised severe doubts about its advisability. One does not really know what will happen until the Act is in force. But, for example, I would not want to be a small plant breeder engaged in litigation with the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd. The whole question of costs and public plant breeding needs to be addressed. I am of the view that one of the main benefits of the PVR debate may be to highlight the need for a lot more effort in new directions for plant breeding and in the acquisition and holding of more basic genetic material. I think for a long time this has been a suggestion by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The collections Australia holds at present are only large for wheat and a few other crops. At present growers pay levies for some of their public plant breeding programs. If private breeders do provide alternative varieties, why should growers be expected to pay both a levy and a royalty?

While I do not believe that multinational oil, chemical and fertiliser companies will necessarily breed chemical and fertiliser dependent varieties I am sure they will not give pest and disease resistance as high a priority as yield; that is, quality may decline. The Minister has canvassed that today and many arguments have been put forward about the dangers of multinationals, monopolisation and problems for the Third World with PVR. While I hold no great faith in the propriety and humanity of the actions of multinationals-one can instance numerous cases of irresponsibly launched chemical products or the case of the sale and promotion of milk formula which allegedly caused the death of a million children in the Third World-I do not see how Australia's adoption of PVR will necessarily change anything.

I will sum up some of my arguments with respect to plant breeding for agriculture. There is a high potential benefit from plant breeding. For instance a one per cent increase for some crops could bring a 4 per cent increase in profits. But there is a need for careful yield comparisons throughout Australia and wheat gains are more problematical. High rates of improvement are possible at present for oats, barley, rapeseed and lupins. But the gains are not necessarily permanent due to disease or pest resistance breakdown and therefore there is a need for breeding to be carried out on a wide front. That is what our systems have been set up to do. To be fully effective plant breeding has to be conducted as a long term continuing program-up to 10 years to 15 years. For example, the Western Australian varieties I mentioned a moment ago have been 14 years in the making. We do not want cosmetic breeding; we want thorough plant breeding programs. Genetic engineering does not help a great deal. There is a need for varieties matched more specifically to particular environments. The quality, particularly for export, is a major concern for Australian primary production. Therefore, there is not only yield. This Bill emphasises only distinct uniform stable criteria and does not talk about performance testing. I understand the reason for this is that merit testing is not envisaged in Australia because it is too costly and difficult to determine merit under the diversity of environmental conditions in Australia. The State governments do not want to look at it in a formal way and the Federal Government is not going to pick up the can. But I still say that the growers, particularly the cereal growers, want some idea of what they are buying and not just a pig in a poke.

The Minister said today that there is no intention to establish a national list . I guess we will have to wait and see what will happen. But over 90 per cent of seed sold to United Kingdom farmers in 1979 was on the recommended lists. What we are worried about is that farmers will be presented with a plethora of information on varieties which are only marginally different-for example, different coloured flowers. This emphasis on distinctness, uniformity and stability is one of our major worries. We are worried that a lower priority will be given to other characteristics in the breeding program, such as disease resistance or productivity increases. The English breeders have said that the rate of yield improvement has been halved in this way. They also have said that it is easy to produce, in large numbers, new varieties which differ just enough in superficial characteristics to qualify as distinct for plant variety rights purposes and which are at least not clearly inferior to the parent and other existing varieties. They pointed out that much commercial breeding in Europe is of this type. That suffices in Europe because, as I have said, particularly for cereals, most people buy their seed every year.

The uniformity requirement presents a worry with respect to delays in release. Single plant selection has to be continued for two or three further generations. As an example, the release in Australia of Warigal wheat, which is known to be heterogeneous, has been delayed to achieve uniformity. The estimated loss to Western Australian growers in 1981 alone is $6m. The Minister referred to the claim and said that there is no risk of loss of genetic diversity. But it has been said to me that breeders have been tempted to choose for plants they are breeding parent stocks with generally similar characteristics in order to shorten the time of development and to achieve homozygosity more rapidly.

I leave the subject of distinctness, uniformity and stability and turn to the matter of consumer protection. Some elements of this are covered in the Bill, but farmers will receive much commercial information and little real information . I think we can say that no farmer can reasonably expect to evaluate critically a new crop variety in the initial years. For the reasons I have outlined I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the Bill be withdrawn and re-submitted when it and other relevant matters have been considered by a select committee of the House of Representatives because the Bill does not meet Australia's plant breeding needs, will cause disruption to, if not a diminution in, public plant breeding, will pose dangers to Australia's agricultural producing and marketing institutions, will subject Australia's primary producers to inadequately tested ''new'' and introduced varieties, will not meet scientific and practical objections to existing forms of plant variety rights systems and may affect Australia's role in the preservation of the world's food and genetic plant resources'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must initially apologise to the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for missing the early part of his speech. I was not aware that this matter would be debated quite so early in the day. I guess it is true to say that, as was prophesied, in his notice of motion earlier today, he is seeking to employ what we can only regard as another delaying mechanism in relation to the passage of this Bill. The facts are that this Bill has been requested by plant breeding experts and establishments for nearly 10 years. The Bill was introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) some 12 months ago. It has lain on the table for all that time. Many people in the community have pondered on the Government's delay in introducing a Bill so vital to the Australian plant breeding establishment, to Third World countries to which we provide food and to a wide variety of agriculturalists, particularly those involved in the vegetable, horticultural and general pasture seed growing sections of the industry-that is not to omit by any means the cereal growers. Put in perspective, what I say is quite correct.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have to put up with this delaying mechanism. If I understand properly the remarks of the honourable member for Werriwa, the majority of members of the proposed House of Representatives select committee referred to in his amendment are to be Government members. There is little doubt that after a lapse of time this House would come down in favour of the Bill. That, of course, is not the problem. The problem is what will happen to the legislation in another place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be slightly different. It could be a different Bill.

—It may well be. I anticipate that the honourable member for Hunter is optimistic enough to think that some alterations may be made in this House. I do not look on that as a practical possibility. Therefore, what we have before us is what is known in parliamentary circles as a pious amendment. That usually means that an Opposition cannot quite make up its mind whether it is opposed to or supports something. Let there be no doubt that this is what is commonly known in the trade union of parliamentarians as a pious amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not able to note all of the matters at which the honourable member for Werriwa suggested the committee should look. However, the first matter that I did write down was the suggestion that the committee should consider whether this legislation meets Australia's needs. Surely there is no doubt about that. The merit of this Bill to the Australian seed and plant industries and to the Australian community is quite clear. If honourable members care to look at item (i) of the Minister's blue covered brief they will see a list of species of new plant varieties grown in the world today that are not available to the Australian producer and, in many cases, are not available to the Australian plant breeder. That list is growing longer as every day passes.

If this Bill is not passed we will effectively deprive this nation of a right to receive hundreds of new species of crops, grasses, shrubs, flowers and fruit trees from countries that currently have those species and have plant variety rights legislation. Speaking from memory-I have not checked this-22 countries have plant variety rights legislation. Any move to defeat this Bill either in this House or in another place would deprive this nation of very valuable new species and small farmers, big farmers and medium sized farmers would be condemned to the dust bowl, if I might use a slightly exaggerated phrase. There is a great need for this nation, which exports the produce of plants, such as cereals, and animals which are fed on plant species and grasses, to keep up to date with its competitors. Any move to defeat this Bill will affect that objective. There is a lack of plant varieties and, as I have said, the list is growing longer every day.

The second matter that is of prime importance is this: Experience has shown quite clearly that investment in the industry has increased greatly in countries which have plant variety rights legislation. In some cases investment in growing plant seeds is up to three times what it was prior to the introduction of PVR. If we defeat the Bill here we will deprive a new and vital industry within Australia of the ability to grow. Surely that is of great regard to any members of parliament who have the interests of this nation at heart. Overseas experience shows quite clearly that such legislation encourages investment in plant breeding generally, right across the board. The higher number of new species has significantly increased yield and quality, increased disease resistance and increased beauty in the case of roses, shrubs and trees. Furthermore, for those who are interested in indigenous wild flowers and species of that sort, work done in the United Kingdom has increased markedly the capacity of that country to reintroduce reclamation work on its indigenous wild flower species. We do not worry about that at present.

The example of overseas countries shows that the strong-minded environmentalist quite clearly supports added investment in plant breeding activity. I am perpetually asked this sort of question: Will this yield apply to wheat in Australia? Honourable members will recall that a few minutes ago I dealt with wheat at the bottom of a list of species. The answer to the question is quite clear. In this country we grow wheat with a high alkaline pH. At this stage in our development we do not grow wheat with a high acidity pH. Our species of wheat, therefore, are geared to grow in alkaline soil reactions. Our export wheat industry, which is faced with huge costs of transport to overseas markets, does not and, I think, never will reply on huge doses of fertilisers in order to increase its yield. The use of superphosphate and nitrogenous fertiliser in the cereal growing industry in this country is comparatively small. I suggest that it will remain so.

This leads me immediately, of course, to the question of the impetus that will be given to wheat breeding in this country in future, over and above the public sector wheat breeding that currently occurs. This is only a matter of judgment but the answer probably is comparatively little in that major industry. When we move to growing wheat in safer areas, higher rainfall areas-rainfall areas where the soil reaction is inclined to be acid-it will lead possibly to the use of new wheats from Europe and other areas. I think of the more acid soils of Victoria where currently not wheat but oats are grown. Oats have been bred in this country for adaptability to soil type, but wheat has not.

I turn to another question which I am constantly asked: Why are some plant breeders in Australia against plant variety rights? I think the first point I should make is that some years ago the vast majority of plant breeders in Australia probably were against plant variety rights. Today I know of only two. No doubt if one hunted around one would find others. I do not think that plant breeders should be against plant variety rights. A bit of healthy competition will not hurt the better plant breeders. On the experience of other nations it is obvious that new varieties will increase the productivity of Australian farmers. There is little doubt of that. I suspect that some breeders want to protect their own positions. They are funded by the public purse, by the taxpayers, and I think that some of them do not fancy the idea of competition.

The next question I am commonly asked is this: Will worthless varieties be foisted on farmers? All I can say is that those people who ask this question do not have the respect for farmers that I have. The farmers' livelihoods are at stake. Cold, hard judgment will be exercised before any new varieties are planted extensively. Farmers will want to look over the fence before planting or purchasing new varieties. They will probably then plant seed trial strip. One can ignore that type of attack on the legislation. Another question I have been asked is: Will poor varieties of seed be sold to farmers because of the impact of advertising? As I see it, there will be no change in the position after the introduction of plant variety rights. An option to purchase is available now. I hope that option always remains. A former member for Wakefield, Bert Kelly, used to say that he respected the right of his cockies to go broke in any way they saw fit. I do not go so far as that but farmers today have the option to grow what varieties they wish.

At a seminar on Monday which was attended by three members of the Australian Labor Party-I thank those who attended-an Australian Democrat senator and members of the Liberal and National Country parties we heard from one farmer who grows a Tasmanian wheat in the middle of New South Wales. That is his judgment. In his view he does better. Surely, that is what this matter is all about. Farmers and gardeners buy the seed which they judge most suitable to their climatic and soil conditions. In this island continent, we have nearly every possible soil condition and nearly every possible climatic condition. There is need for diversity. If it is rare for a New South Wales farmer to grow a wheat which is bred in Tasmania, does that not point to the need for diversity? Does that not point to the fact that we need a greater number of varieties to cope with the wide scope of environmental conditions in Australia? Of course it does. The experience of every other country, including small countries such as the United Kingdom, is that that is precisely what happens.

The next question I am asked by the growers is: 'Can we buy the seed we used to buy?' The answer is that of course they can. The plant variety rights legislation deals only with new varieties. Old varieties will still be available for anyone who wants them. The next question I am asked is: What happens to wheat farmers when they breed their own seed? I am concentrating on wheat for the moment. I am asked whether a patent right allowed for a new variety prohibits the common habit of Australian wheat farmers of growing the seed for the planting of next season's crop? There should be no such worry. Provision for that situation is built into the legislation if any honourable member wishes to have a look at it. Total approval for that process is written into the Bill.

I turn now to the argument put by various anti-plant variety rights groups that international firms are likely to control food production. There is a dim possibility that that could be so with food genetics-seeds. But to talk of it in terms of food production is surely absurd. It is surely an absurd proposition. We could rephrase that question and ask: Is there any fear that big international firms will control seed distribution and seed breeding? The answer is that there is no evidence from the 22 countries involved that that is occurring. The nearest one could get to that situation is probably in the United States. One could perhaps argue also that co-operative breeding establishments in England have geneticists and plant breeders all over the world working on new varieties. In that case, of course, it is not a multinational involvement, it is not the involvement of a frightful big American company. In fact, a group of farmers is involved. If one looks at the situation right across the world one realises that the greatest involvement is from small nurserymen.

The next question I am asked is: Who is going to pay the royalties that will be given to big firms or indeed to small nurserymen? The straight answer to that question is that, so far as I am aware, under this system there will be no royalties. I think people are confusing royalties with a sum payable by a plant breeder who wants to register a new seed. As I see it, there will be no royalties under the Australia legislation. Quite clearly the process will be as follows: Someone invents a new species. He goes to the Registrar and says that he has a new species that he wants to register. His application is then put before a meeting of the Agricultural Council, which comprises all State Ministers and the Federal Minister for Primary Industry, to see whether that variety, be it apricot or wheat, will be accepted. At this stage this Bill does not register anything. Registration will be done in response to applications as they are received. Those who have studied the New Zealand legislation will know that the New Zealanders started with roses and barley.

What happens is that the plant breeder who has a patent right over a variety breeds it up. He then puts it on the market. He does not put it on the market at a price so high that nobody will buy it. He puts on the market at a price which growers can afford. Growers will buy it only if they know that it has disease resistance. They will buy it only if they know it will give them increased productivity. I refer honourable members to a very good, albeit hard-hitting, speech by Hugh Roberts, a former Nuffield scholar in agriculture from Cootamundra. He cited the example of Brussels sprouts. A farmer in the United Kingdom might pay 20 times as much for a new variety of seed but because the yield is so much greater he finishes up a ton of Brussels sprouts per acre better off than he would have had he bought the normal variety. But that is in the area of the farmer's judgment. The market-place will decide whether the price of some fancy thing is too high, and the market-place will establish whether it will sell.

I have tried to touch on just two or three of the arguments that I have heard. In the last few minutes I should just like to say this: It should be quite clear to Parliament that some of the most exciting prospects in the world in this decade, and in the next one, are in the area of plant breeding. The decades of the 1960s and 1970s were those of chemical control-undue use of weedicides and pesticides. The next few decades will be involved in biological control, and they will be involved in the most exciting bit of plant breeding that we can imagine-new species requiring less chemical control and less fertiliser. It is quite clear from the experience of other countries that plant variety rights is giving impetus to this very trend. We must encourage this trend away from the use of chemical control wherever possible.

What is in the offing? First of all, more species available for a wider diversity of environments; secondly, disease resistance; thirdly, high yields based on that disease resistance and based on higher yielding varieties themselves; and fourthly, a possible saving in fertiliser usage and in chemical treatments, and therefore in costs. Last year for instance, for the first time, there was a cross soya bean-sunflower. It lived for just over two months. It was the first example of a self-fertilising cereal. Does that not mean something to our capacity to feed ourselves and those countries that cannot feed themselves? This will be the most exciting era of innovation, that I believe can materially alter the farming scene in Australian-if Parliament passes the Bill.

If Parliament does not pass the Bill, those voting against it will really stand condemned, and rightly so, by not only the community at large but, more particularly, by those who have been in touch with the sort of reality that I have tried to describe during the last few minutes. If the Bill does not pass, they will condemn small farmers and medium farmers and the type of innovation and technological advance which will keep them abreast of farmers in the rest of the world. I count there cereal farmers, small horticulturists, vegetable growers, nursery men specialising in flowers, shrubs, trees and wild flowers, and the regeneration projects that I have mentioned.

I hope that the debate which will ensue, not only in this House but also in the other place, will not be a debate that becomes fringed out in sometimes irrelevant detail-or as others might say, with relevant detail. I hope that the thrust of the Bill, which is a very responsible Bill and has the enormous weight of evidence on its side, will be rationally accepted by members of parliament in both Houses. I support the Bill and shall vote against the only amendment of which I am aware at this stage, that moved by the honourable member for Werriwa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This very deep and complicated piece of legislation has created enormous interest throughout the whole of Australia. The public debate generated by the legislation is only just beginning. We have just heard the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) telling us how long the legislation sat on the table and that there has been time for public debate. I challenge that view strongly. Clear evidence about this is very apparent when one considers that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has seen fit to put forward some 27 amendments to the original Bill which he introduced on 7 May 1981. It has been argued that sufficient time has been allowed for informed debate to take place. However, the 27 amendments were introduced only in March of this year-only three weeks ago. Every honourable member has been receiving reams of mail from people-some informed, some misinformed. The public is taking an enormous interest in this issue-much more than the farming community has up to the present. It concerns me that the Bill is going through the House at this stage and we appear to have a strong interest coming from the public sector and very little from the farming sector. The farming community is very much unaware of what this legislation really means. In fact, I contend that it is not the farmers who are pushing to have this legislation introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has provided a kit to assist honourable members in the debate on the issue. While the kit has been of some assistance, it has by its very presentation provided a good case on administration grounds for the need to withdraw the Bill and re-submit it when other relevant matters have been considered. The Minister has not even provided a clear one-piece document on the Bill which includes the amendments that he proposes to his original Bill. There seems to be an urgent rush to have the legislation dealt with, even to the extent that we cannot put together one document on the Bill.

Considering the importance and the implications of this Bill for the future, it is amazing that those of us who have to consider the Bill are not even in the position of being able to receive a document from the Government which clearly indicates what it proposes. We have to go from one document back to the amended document to find out just what the Minister is on about. By his own actions he has admitted that the Bill, in breaking new ground, is creating problems. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), in his reply to the Minister's speech, has outlined the major issues which concern the Opposition. Our opposition is not based on way-out reasons which cannot be substantiated. Some of the debate taking place in the community lacks credence, but the majority of it coming through from the public is very good and very solid, and needs to be aired.

I should like to canvass some of the reasons why we on this side of the House wish to see the Bill withdrawn and re-submitted when all the relevant matters have been considered. The first and most logical reason is that we have 40-odd amendments to the Bill based on research that the Opposition has been able to collate. There is every reason why this Bill should be withdrawn and re- submitted in a more logical form in the future. Let me take some points. First, does the Bill meet Australia's plant breeding needs? What are those needs? Are they in cereals, which is a major seed area involving major export products? Or is the Bill designed to help in the areas of vegetables and horticulture and in other areas?

The honourable member for Wakefield clearly indicated that wheat was not the major reason for the Bill. The major export product from this country in the agricultural scene is not the major reason for the Bill being presented. A survey of the varieties of species listed by the Minister in his kit which are at present denied to Australia clearly does not show a deficiency in the cereal growing variety. Our major crops are very well funded with public plant breeding and will continue to be so and should be protected. The honourable member for Wakefield admitted that wheat itself was not to be a major ingredient of the Bill. He said that we would not be going in for strong fertiliser and nitrogenous approaches to our planting of wheat, and he could not see that changing in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not got one irrigated wheat in this country.

—As the honourable member for Murray said, we have not got one irrigated wheat in this country. Looking at the wheat situation and the costs involved, I do not think that expensive irrigation water could be envisaged as being used for wheat at this stage. Plant variety rights, as envisaged by the Bill, by creating a diminution in public plant breeding, particularly under a Liberal Government, could have a deleterious effect on Australia's agricultural scene. There is no clear evidence that PVR as envisaged at present will generate the development of new plant varieties which will benefit Australia or Australians to any noticeable degree. At this stage I should like to take issue with some of the information provided in the information kit supplied by the Minister. I draw attention to section J-the overseas experiences regarding PVR. This section purports to summarise:

SPEECH.PARA: The most recent information concerning PVR provided to the Department of Primary Industry from overseas.

Under the heading 'United Kingdom' reference is made to a report by Mr Murphy, the comptroller of PVR at Cambridge in the United Kingdom, in a 1980 United Kingdom report by a Mrs V. Sylvie. After mentioning the big improvements in yield in wheat in the United Kingdom since 1947, the Minister's kit includes the following:

and of this by far the largest part of increase in yield appears to be the result of improved varieties as opposed to husbandry techniques. It is impossible to say with certainty what the contribution of the plant breeders right system has been but the implication is that it has been substantial.
I turn to the actual statement made by Mr Murphy in his address to the symposium on genetic resources. He said:
It is impossible to say with absolute certainty what the contribution of the plant breeders' rights system has been--

The words which follow in the Minister's document, 'but the implication is that it has been substantial', were not quoted by Mr Murphy but were placed there by the Minister to add credence to his case for PVR. I believe that was a rather shoddy means of providing information to members of Parliament. I now quote from the section of Mr Murphy's paper to which the Minister added his extra wording for maximum effect. Mr Murphy was speaking about the study of Mrs Sylvie of the National Institute of Agricultural Botany in Cambridge, United Kingdom. On page 3 of the document it is stated:
During the last 10 years by far the larger part of the increase in yield appears to be the result of improved varieties--
I must point out that he says 'appears to be'-

as opposed from the contribution of improved husbandry techniques. This is based on England and Wales information but it will be interesting to learn whether there has been a similar phenomenon in other countries, because if this trend is going to continue in the future, I think it does have significant implications in that very much the greater part of the net increase in productivity that we can expect looks as if it will have to come from the improvement of plant varieties.

There is not much doubt. We in the Opposition do not take issue with the fact that the greater part of that increase in productivity looks as if it will have to come from improvement in plant varieties. But that is not the argument before the House. This Bill has been hastily put together and in our opinion it does not do justice to the Australian scene. I strongly emphasise that we do not oppose the need to have a reward system in the development of plants for the future. We do not oppose the fact that we need to encourage investment in the future but we do not believe that this Bill is the ideal way of doing it. I read on from Mr Murphy's document. He stated:

If other countries have information similar to that which Mrs Sylvie has produced they might look at this point because I think we would be interested in the United Kingdom to have a comparison with the experience in other countries.
I repeat:
If other countries have information similar to that which Mrs Sylvie has produced they might look at this point. . . .

There is no doubt that we need to look at this point. From overseas experience there is not enough evidence available to substantiate the type of Bill before the House. We, as perhaps the custodians of the food production future of South East Asia, should not rush in and produce a piece of legislation which has not been completely studied and about which many people are very concerned. Mr Murphy continued:

We know, therefore, from this information what plant breeding can contribute and the UK experience over the past thirty years is quite clear. The important question today however is to establish what role, if any, plant breeders' rights have played in the process. It is impossible to say with absolute certainty what the contribution of the plant breeders' rights system has been.

Regardless of what one might read into it, that is clear from the study he put forward at that symposium. It is not clear what role plant breeders' rights have played in the process to this time. It is clear from this evidence, presented by the Government itself, that there is a need to withdraw this legislation and for Australia to take a position of caution and perhaps even adopt a more conservative approach to this type of legislation.
I now take up another matter. I refer again to the latest information provided by the Government and to Mr Murphy's document. He said:

We now have had 15 years experience with plant breeders' rights but it is only recently that many agricultural and vegetable species have been offered protection. We started in 1965 with just five species.

The honourable member for Wakefield virtually said that this Bill would assist mainly those concerned with agricultural and vegetable species, and the small sectors of the economy. The point I wish to make is related to the fact that whilst the United Kingdom has had 15 years to gain experience, it is only recently that many agricultural and vegetable species have been offered protection. This Bill, if passed, will allow Australia to face the consequences of almost immediate release of some agricultural and vegetable species onto the Australian market. What would be the consequences of this? Have the ramifications been considered?

I highlight a scenario which could occur. A vegetable of great significance, both economically and in respect of our food production in Australia, is the humble potato. The potato industry needs to develop new varieties to suit Australian conditions. There is no doubt about that. However, the market is not large and it is often oversupplied. The industry has become very specialised, with mechanisation and contract growing for big companies. With the passing of this Bill an overseas company or a company with overseas connections could justify the importation of a new variety of potato to serve a particular purpose . However, the granting of sole rights to a company which can control who will grow the certified seed and also issue contracts to growers to plant that seed and produce the product could create serious problems. The potential to build up a complete tier of control is very real and I do not think the Government has considered this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not even accurate.

—The Bill does not provide protection against this type of operation. There is a real need to have a section inserted relating to the appointment of an advisory committee. The Minister says that is not even accurate. I refer him to the amending page-we cannot go to the actual Bill; we have to go to the document added to it-and to the characteristics of plant varieties originating outside Australia. This is what concerns me. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Act, where a plant variety in respect of which an application has been made was originated outside Australia, the variety shall not be taken to have a particular characteristic unless-
(a) a test growing of the variety carried out in Australia has demonstrated that the variety has that characteristic;
That would not take very long in the potato industry; 12 months would be enough to generate that situation. The amendment goes on:
(b) The Secretary is satisfied that-
(i) a test growing of the variety carried out at a place outside Australia has demonstrated that the variety has that characteristic;
It would not take much for the potato industry to put together those two requirements. The legislation continues:
(ii) the test growing of the variety carried out at that place is equivalent to a test growing of the variety carried out in Australia;

That would not take much proving, either. Hence we have a situation where an overseas variety of potato could be brought in by an overseas company which works under contract. Only the company with the licence would be able to get hold of that certified seed. The only people, then, who would be able to plant that seed in this country would be those who received it from that company. It is quite clear in the potato industry that certified seed is the major ingredient to a good crop but there is nothing to stop people growing approved seed or producing just an ordinary run-of-the-mill crop. Under this legislation that would be impossible because such a company would have virtual say over who could use the certified seed. The Minister says that parts of the Bill would rectify that situation in that appeals could be lodged, but there is no doubt in my mind that one of the consequences of this Bill that no one can justify is that a big company could have complete and utter control over that section of the potato industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't need PVR to do that; they do it now.

—They do not need it at the moment because they use a very suspect breed of potato. There is no doubt that they will quickly look to a new breed of potato because they are very concerned about the one they are using now. We do not argue against PVR; we argue against the structure of this Bill. In the way in which it is structured there is no advisory committee to have a look at that problem. I envisage that these plants might not be made available to New South Wales. the particular company concerned is Amatil Ltd, which develops its farm produce in my area in Victoria. It could keep seed strictly for Victoria and Queensland and there would be no way that the seed could be made available to New South Wales. I doubt whether anyone can justify that situation. I do not think it is logical for any piece of legislation to give that sort of power to any company.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the main reasons put forward by the Government for PVR is the restriction of overseas varieties. It can be debated that new varieties of vegetables hastily introduced could have a disastrous economic effect on some of our small industries. New varieties brought in will lead to fewer farmers being required to grow the crops and so we will create more unemployment in rural areas.

In conclusion, let me indicate clearly the position that the Opposition takes. We are quite emphatic that there is a need to encourage plant breeding, but there is also a need to be fully aware of its implications. If there is evidence that all of the implications have been considered, it has not been presented to this Parliament. As I said earlier-and it is quite clear from the mail that parliamentarians are receiving-the public does not consider that all of the implications have been studied.

I support the amendment to the second reading, moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), to the effect that the Bill should be withdrawn and resubmitted when it and other relevant matters have been considered by a select committee of the House of Representatives. The Bill does not meet Australia's plant breeding needs. It will cause a disruption, if not a diminution, in public plant breeding. It will pose dangers to Australia's agricultural producing and marketing institutions. It will subject Australia's primary producers to inadequately tested new and introduced varieties. It will not meet scientific and practical objectives to existing forms of plant variety rights systems and may affect Australia's role in the preservation of the world's food and genetic plant resources. I support the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Werriwa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always considered that it must be a great problem to be a member of the Opposition. I guess Opposition supporters have a responsibility to oppose, but today I do not really think that their heart is in it. That may be some consolation to rurally-based voters who still feel that there may be some benefit to be gained by farmers in having socialist governments. In 1602, in the case of Davis versus Allein, Chief Justice Sir Edward Coke, said:
