SPEECH.PARA: The reason wherefore such a privilege is good in law is because the invention bringeth to and for the Commonwealth a new industry.

There is no doubt that Australia needs new industry at this time, but new industry will not develop without an incentive. Normally in our free enterprise society the incentive is the making of a profit. The time scale and hazards of plant breeding must in the first instance require a stout heart. The incentive of profit opportunity is absolutely necessary before the ordinary individual, outside of a government institution, can enter upon plant breeding. So often the inventor will not have the capital to support himself during the long process of plant breeding. The day of the wealthy patron of science is past. Capital, which is often the property of little people, requires profit. If the inventor wishes to best deliver his skills to the the community in the form of new products he needs to be able to offer the possibility of that profit to capital before it will assist him. Capital and inventiveness have combined over the centuries to create the products and processes that have lifted the world above the subsistence economy. Nothing that I know of has done more in that regard.

The living plant is the basis of our food cycle. In Australia capital and invention have produced major improvements in production; so too has the Government. Capital and private invention have been for years directed their efforts to the field in which profit was available, namely that of fertilizers and insecticides. Government plant breeders have found that part of their time has been taken up inventing plants that are capable of handling new fertilizers and insecticides. The extent to which fertiliser and insecticide can contribute to the increasing of food production or the improvement of plant variety is now limited. Moreover, some side effects of the use of fertiliser and insecticide are not considered desirable. Therefore, improved and resistant plant varieties would appear to be the better alternative.

Capital and the inventor found that, due to the lack of protection, there was no gain in inventing open pollenating varieties. Therefore, they turned to hybrids where the very process, while kept secret, provided protection in itself . Hybrids will not regenerate from the seed that they produce. The hybrid industry grew rapidly without the protection of plant variety rights. That, by the way, is the simple answer to one of the more stupid criticisms that is offered: Once plant variety legislation was in place hybrids would corner the market. Hybrid development, due to its very nature, has never needed PVR protection and, as I have said, has managed to develop without it. Plant variety rights legislation is needed to protect the invention of open pollenating varieties. The invention of such varieties of greater productivity and disease resistance is essential for Australia. Every move that can encourage inventive people to undertake this task must be applauded. The purpose of the Bill is to make one such move. It is a move to provide patent rights. It is not a move to address many of the other issues that also may contribute to greater productivity. The taking of certain action that may further contribute in this regard is the responsibility of other levels of government.

The honourable member of Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has referred to the Bill as a dog's breakfast. If this Bill attempted to address all of the problems that are associated with the general issue of plant breeding it would certainly become a dog's breakfast, and possibly subject to constitutional challenge also. We have to get this point clear: The Bill is to give patent rights in the hope that this will encourage additional resources to be directed to the plant breeding industry.

The Bill is a good clean measure which is designed, as it should be, to achieve a single, prime purpose-to enable the granting of patents for future new plant varieties. Consequently, I commend it to the House and implore honourable members both here and in another place to address themselves to its provisions, rather than to supposition or to other matters. I ask them also not to predict its effect past the point of the granting of patents.

I wish now to address some of the comments that have been made by the Opposition today. I have already implied that the Opposition, by suggesting that there be a select committee, is apparently endeavouring to address in one Bill all of the problems that may exist in regard to plant breeding, rather than the particular proposal that is before us, which is designed to provide an incentive for further plant breeding. I take issue with the honourable member for Werriwa in regard to his statement that the Country Party Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia was opposed to the concept. The honourable member was quite right in that regard but did not tell the House why the Minister was opposed. I have had to deal with the matter in my electorate, which represents by far the greater area of rural production in Western Australia that is affected by this question. The reason for the Minister's opposition was that he acted on the advice of his Department which, plainly, was terrified that its empire was under attack. Let us get this straight: It is clear to me that one of the great worries of the Opposition is that something that has been the preserve of government might be under attack. I say 'might' because I do not see anything in this Bill that suggests that it is under attack. If we have to look under the mattress we had better go to some other place.

Again, the honourable member said that many nurserymen were opposed. I do not know these nurserymen. I have not met any of them, but I must say that the industry body which represents nurserymen has probably been the strongest lobbyist in favour of plant variety rights. Surely its democratic structure is such that if the bulk of its members were against the Bill there would not have been a strong lobby in favour of it from that sector. The honourable member says that farmers are opposed to the Bill. I will deal with that in a moment, as it affects my electorate.

The honourable member says that plant breeders do not really care, that they will produce any sort of product and, having done so, will not worry about the purchaser. That could be the honourable member's opinion of these people. Honourable members are doubtless aware of the huge sums of capital involved. At a seminar the other day an expert told us that it would not be unreasonable to expend $100,000 a year on a plant breeder, but it would be delightful if he got through a breeding program in five years. In other words, it would cost $100,000 a year for a plant breeder and his associates. These programs involve half a million dollars, if we are lucky. At the end of such a program plant breeders would not dump on the market a product that was bad. That is purely and simply because the next time they tried to do that sort of thing their whole organisation would go down the drain. People remember the people who sell them crook things. I think honourable members will find on average that the plant breeder who gets on in the world is the one who does not do that sort of thing and the people who invest that sort of money in plant breeding are not the sorts of people who do that.

I was quite astounded to hear the honourable member for Werriwa express concern that the economic benefits might be shared beyond the producer. I would have thought that was a rather desirable situation. Although the honourable member got around to the consumer later in his speech, he listed first all the people who might profit from better varieties, including the retailers, the wholesalers and presumably the auctioneers. At that point he left out the consumer. Amongst the various occupations I have had have been those of grocer and greengrocer. I knew very well then what happened to prices when there was increased production. When there was greater production, the price fell in many of the retail areas. This did not always worry the grower because if his production was up and the unit value was down he was still doing well. On the other hand, of course, the consumer benefited. Is it not a fact that any legislation which is brought into this House which in any way contributes to higher levels of production and lower prices is to be applauded?

The honourable member for Werriwa also seemed concerned about the risk to growers in taking on a new variety. Maybe he would not be in this place if his ancestors had not taken the risk which many pioneers did in coming to this country. Australian growers will take certain risks. The plant variety rights legislation will not necessarily increase or decrease the level of risk. The legislation will create the opportunity for breeders to profit from their activities. The honourable member for Werriwa also questioned the possible benefits from this legislation. He seems to want us to guarantee a quantum of benefit before this legislation passes the House. To me a small benefit would be a great benefit. Having studied this subject and discussed it with everybody I possibly could, the conclusion I have come to is that the benefits will be great , if only in allowing into Australia many of the already improved varieties that are available throughout the world but are not available to Australia because of the plant variety legislation in the country of origin. If only those varieties come to Australia, even if under the provisions of this legislation we do not invent anything in Australia, that will be sufficient quantum of benefit, but I expect a substantially greater benefit than that.

The honourable member for Werriwa referred to the British system and said that the federal government should introduce an identical system. He might discover that in a Federal system of Government that is not possible. He ignores the responsibilities of State governments in the area of agriculture. The State governments have been looking after this area for years, and I think they have been doing the job extremely well. Through this legislation we are not asking anybody to change those circumstances. The honourable member seems to be completely happy with our institutional breeding mechanisms which exist today, although many of the wheat varieties that are still being grown in Australia were invented probably 20 years ago. He mentioned some new varieties, but they are still in the minority. Nobody is suggesting for a minute that the public sector should not continue to go ahead with breeding programs which will be of benefit to the nation. That will be matter for the State governments to determine by funding. I again add that I feel there is more concern in the Labor Party Opposition ranks about what might happen to some Government employees than there is for the total benefits that this legislation could bring for Australia.

I was interested to hear the suggestion of the honourable member for Werriwa that someone might steal some secrets. He does not have to worry about that at present. There are no secrets because nobody is bothering to create these secrets. He expressed concern that people might litigate with the Shell oil company. There is no worry about that at the moment either because there is no protection. Nothing is happening; it will not happen, so do not worry too much about the Shell oil company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just tell us in plain English: Are you supporting the Bill?
—I am certainly supporting the Bill and I am having a great deal of fun pointing out how the Leader of the Opposition supports the Bill but could not convince his left wing that it should support it.
—You should be in the National Country Party.

—The honourable member should not worry about that. I represent a rural electorate and I take seriously my responsibility for the people in it. He should just go quiet for a while. He could tell me how to shear a sheep, but he would have to improve on what I have heard about him. There seems to be some concern about royalties and levies. I see this Bill giving government institutions the opportunity to benefit also from their inventiveness. They too need not necessarily continue to demand levies. It is possible that they may get some royalties.

SPEECH.PARA: Some other issues were raised by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). He is very worried about the time that has been allowed for debate on this subject. Seldom has there been a Bill which members of the public have been given a better chance to examine. If by now they have not been able to come up with arguments against its passage they never will. That honourable member too got himself bogged down in the amendment, which carries us miles past the provisions of this Bill. Principally the Bill seeks to provide for the granting of a patent, not to get into the matter of growing seed or anything else which is probably the responsibility of other sections of government.

Let me just touch on a few of the other matters that were raised so that I can prove conclusively to the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) that I support the Bill wholeheartedly. Firstly, all sorts of suggestions have been made about what the PVR scheme might cost in terms of royalties. The United States Burpee Seed Co., of all names, listed 11 lettuce varieties, including two protected varieties. The price per lb of the nine openly available varieties ranged from $6.50 to $13.50 and the price for the two protected varieties ranged from $11.50 to $14.65. In other words, it appeared that the royalty was about $1 per lb. Currently the average royalty payment on seed of protected United States wheat varieties is only 50c a bushel, whereas for oats it is 30c a bushel. So much for the rapacious situation that might exist when all these nasty multinationals get into the business. Yesterday I went to some trouble to question one of the members of the Opposition. I asked why the Opposition was so concerned about multinational or big company involvement. I do not think there is any doubt that if there is a sufficiently profitable invention a big company will want to buy it. But I do not say that a company can buy the inventor, unless the inventor chooses to stay. The inventor is a guy who will move on and invent other things. I cited the example of the man called Lear, the American who invented the Lear jet but who also invented the car radio. He lived by invention and by selling out a profitable company and moving on. He did so until his death. There is no suggestion that in our society, government can, until laws are passed, contain inventiveness, be it with money or anything else. If the money is not good enough of if a company takes restrictive trade practices action which does not suit the inventor he will move on; someone else will want his services.

There seems to be some concern-this was mentioned by the honourable member for McMillan-about potatoes and about a big company saying: 'We have the spuds. You will grow them and you will sell them back to us at our price'. Apparently the honourable member has not read clause 33 of the Bill, which provides the Registrar with certain powers. A court case is not needed. The Registrar has the power to issue another licence if he is of the opinion that that sort of practice is going on. The public is protected from that type of activity, which we know might otherwise occur. This Government has recognised that problem and dealt with it.

Great concern has been expressed that we have introduced amendments to the Bill . The principal amendment, of course, converts what was once a piece of exclusive legislation to a piece of inclusive legislation. It was exclusive only because of the original doubts of the wheat industry and the cereal grain industry. Those industries did not want to be included. The Government took notice of what they asked and excluded them. They very smartly came around cap in hand and said: 'Please change your mind; please include us because we see benefits in having this'. That is quite contrary to all the negative arguments that there might not be benefit for wheat growers and barley growers. They said: 'There is a benefit and we want it'. Consequently we have changed the legislation to be all-inclusive. It covers all forms of plants but allows for their introduction by regulation. The regulation will be introduced only after approval of the Australian Agricultural Council, which comprises the various State agriculture Ministers. What is wrong with that? By changing the legislation from exclusive to inclusive we have made it much more satisfactory to the international community. Quite obviously, legislation that will not stand up internationally is of little use in the area with which we are dealing.

There are so many comments that I could make but I sum up with this comment: For goodness sake let us realise that there is benefit in this legislation. Let us realise what it is. It is a patent rights Bill and it has nothing to do with all the other detail and red herrings which the Opposition is introducing. I ask the Opposition to give it a chance. It can do very little harm. It will certainly do some good, as I have said, if it allows only for the introduction of plants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! the honourable member's time has expired .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining this debate on the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 I want to make it quite clear from the outset that whilst I am philosophically opposed to the patenting of any life forms my opposition to this Bill is based on important practical grounds. My abhorrence of the idea that to gain profit from the creation of life, whether animal or plant life, is an inviolable right of a capitalist-free enterprise or private enterprise system is grounded in a morality a defence of which could divert attention from the very real practical dangers of this Bill. Firstly, I wish to deal with two main objectives of the Bill and then turn to the other retrograde effects which will result from the application of this Bill. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has stated that a primary reason for introducing a plant variety rights scheme was to facilitate access to overseas varieties required by Australia by establishing protection for the rights of owners. In support of this statement it is submitted that a number of instances have been reported where Australian breeders have been unable to obtain desired varieties from overseas because of the refusal of the owners to release the varieties without patent protection.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst not denying that certain Australian breeders have been unable to obtain plant varieties from overseas because of the absence of restrictive legislation, it is not true to say that the introduction of the legislation will facilitate access to overseas varieties. Officials of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation-the FAO-are on record as stating quite unequivocally that their experience of nearly 20 years of existing plant variety rights legislation is that there are increasing restrictions on the amount of germ plasm which is not only in circulation but also available to those who wish to use it. It is worth noting that an important restrictive factor will be the need to satisfy the legislative interpretation of a new plant variety in relation to distinctness, uniformity and stability. This interpretation is set out in clause 3 of the Bill.

The requirement that a new plant variety be distinct, uniform and stable has, in the experience of FAO officials, often meant a breeding reliance on genetic characteristics which are secondary in terms of performance but very important for identification purposes. In other words, the need to conform to the requirements of the legislation in relation to identification for the purpose of making a profit becomes far more important than the possibility of improvements in quality and quantity which may not be patentable and, therefore, not become a money spinner for the breeder. In this respect the United States Department of Agriculture has indicated its concern that breeders are paying a great deal of attention to marketable uniqueness but far less attention to performance uniqueness. I reiterate that there is no denying that the legislation facilitates the provision of genetic resources on a person to person basis but the overall effect overseas has been a reduction in the amount of material available. There is no reason to believe that this experience will not be repeated in Australia.

Another stated reason by the Minister for introducing plant variety rights legislation was the stimulative effect it would provide for Australian plant breeding. There is no doubt that plant breeding can be a long and costly process , but I cannot accept the argument that because it is long and costly benefits should be available to private breeders rather than the general public through the efforts of public plant breeding programs at present being undertaken by State government departments, the universities and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Again, officials of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation have stated that many excellent varieties of field and plantation crops, vegetables and fruits which are available to the public have resulted, in the most part, from large inputs of government funding. It is only in recent years, and frequently at the last stage of the development of a new variety, that private industry has joined in to reap the benefit.

Surely the purpose of plant breeding should be to improve the quality of life and it should not exist for the foremost purpose of expanding the profits of private industry, particularly when, as I will indicate later in this speech, the profits become monopoly profits for a small number of huge multinational corporations and, even more importantly, when those corporations are linking the control of food with agricultural inputs in a way which could have grave consequences for the human race. There is no doubt that if plant variety rights legislation is introduced the institutions at present engaged in public plant breeding would come under pressure from State governments and business interests to pay their way through the medium of royalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—The public plant breeders would then be forced to meet the legislative requirements of distinctiveness, uniformity and stability, thus causing a consequential neglect of yield and quality. The Minister says that is nonsense. That has happened overseas. That has been the experience overseas. The basis for the collaboration among public breeding institutions and breeding programs which has grown in recent years in order to provide the most efficient use of limited resources would be undermined and probably destroyed if the institutions were forced to compete with each other for royalties. The result would be a strengthening of private breeding interests which would consider public plant breeding as unfair competition and, in the same way as they are now strongly lobbying for the introduction of plant variety rights legislation, they would lobby for the elimination of public plant breeding. There is no doubt that the lobby would find ardent and enthusiastic supporters from local businessmen and nurserymen who could make profits by holding agencies for overseas private breeders. I emphasise that the consequential result of introducing plant variety rights legislation into Australia will be to reduce and eventually eliminate support for public plant breeding programs.

SPEECH.PARA: As usual, the Federal Government is taking an approach which favours overseas multinational corporations, as I will indicate later in my speech. Surely Australia should be improving and strengthening our present public plant breeding programs. The creation of a public plant breeding corporation which could co-ordinate and support the present programs of State governments, universities and the CSIRO, would provide a valuable catalyst for the expansion of public plant breeding in Australia. The board of the corporation could include representatives of the farming community, private and public plant breeders, the consuming public and Federal and State governments. Of course, it is too much to expect that those Government members described as the 'dries' would support such a proposal. They are the atavists of our Parliament, the throw-backs who hold the quaint view that our economy can be controlled by market forces, unhindered by governments. What they fail to appreciate is that the market economy they are talking and writing about died at the end of the nineteenth century and the market-place is now controlled by multinational corporations. The corollary of small government, which is one of their catch- cries, is big business. For big business the new field for unscrupulous exploitation is the production and marketing of food. In this respect plant variety rights legislation represents one of the greatest vehicles for exploitation and power, a fact which multinational corporations have not failed to recognise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote that?

—Plant variety rights legislation is a form of government intervention in the market which provides for monopoly control and which actively impedes free enterprise activities. The Minister asked who wrote that. If he had listened to previous speeches I have made in this House he would be aware that I have made this point on a number of occasions. As soon as the legislation comes into effect the major multinational corporations will move into the profitable sectors of plant breeding, specifically those sectors which deal with crops whose seeds bring in large sales and large profits, with a consequential large royalty potential. Government plant breeding stations will receive even less funding and will be called upon to undertake the non-productive work in fundamental research. Any potentially large royalty-producing variety-produced often after years of painstaking research by the public breeders-will be snapped up by the private sector for quick profits.

SPEECH.PARA: A typical example of the kind of pirating I have described occurred in France and was cited by Pat Mooney, a well-known food and agriculture consultant. The French Government patents a variety of hybrid corn and a private corporate breeder, having paid a marginal royalty, works on that hybrid and produces a marginally new hybrid variety. The quality and characteristics of the new variety have not changed from the original goverment-produced hybrid corn but, because the private breeder has created a new cross, he is able to patent it. The private corporate breeder markets both the government's and his own variety in an advertising campaign which highlights his own variety and thus he reaps the whole of the enhanced profits. That is how plant variety rights legislation has affected plant breeding in Europe and that is obviously how it will work in Australia. A number of analyses have been carried out which show conclusively that the introduction of plant variety rights legislation leads to an oligopolistic market structure.

There is a continuing takeover of independent seed companies by transnational petrochemical, agrichemical and agribusiness companies. In the United States of America recent corporate takeovers involving 45 seed companies have been undertaken by 24 multinational corporations, including three petrochemical companies, nine agrichemical or pharmaceutical companies and 12 agribusiness companies. Two hundred and forty nine United States patents for soya beans, wheat, cotton, garden beans and peas and lettuce are held by eight corporations involved with seed production, distribution or research in Australia. With some slight variations in any major crop area, the oligopoly situation in Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom and Germany is the same. Essentially, four companies have oligopoly control. For example, in the United States, in the case of hybrid corn, close to 90 per cent of the market is controlled by four companies. To ensure monopoly control of the corn the four companies have divided the United States into geographic regions so that only one company supplies the corn to the farmers in one region.

Analysis of the patents issued under the United States plant variety rights legislation indicates that about half the patents are issued to the 24 multinational corporations that I mentioned previously. The domination of the seed industry by multinational corporations is beyond doubt, as the statistics show. In the United Kingdom in 1964 within one week of plant variety rights legislation having been passed, Ranks Hovis McDougall Ltd took over 84 country seed supply companies. In the United States, after the introduction of a plant variety protection Act in 1970, the demand for quick capital profits by small seed proprietors was so high that the American seed trade association organised a one-day seminar entitled 'how to sell out your seed company'.

In Australia there are a number of grave implications for farmers, market gardeners, nurserymen and food consumers in the overwhelming evidence of the control of the overseas seed market by multinational corporations. In the first place, these huge corporations work only for the biggest markets. The smaller Australian marketplace will in consequence be obliged to accept the varieties produced by overseas research programs. Secondly, the large corporations which are acquiring the majority of the smaller seed companies are those corporations whose bulk profits come from the manufacture of pharmaceuticals or petroleum- based chemicals. Plant breeding has a number of commercial attractions for such corporations, involving vertical as well as horizontal integration, but the one great commercial advantage is being able to sell a package deal to the farmer. Seed can be sold chemically pre-coated or pelleted thus increasing the company's chemical sales. There would not be a great deal of commercial incentive for such corporations to be interested in genetic forms of pest or disease resistance or nitrogen use efficiency. With seed certification requiring certain minimum levels of disease resistance, companies concentrate on major gene resistance which is more easily defined and handled. Varieties with more broadly based, longer lasting resistance, or varieties with resistance to plant parasites, would be more expensive to produce and harder to sell. This is one of the more dangerous commercial effects of plant variety rights for the Australian consumer .

I return now to the creation of a public plant breeding corporation which, in my opinion, would be a satisfactory alternative to the provisions of the present Bill. I have already suggested that the composition of a governing board of such a corporation should include representatives of Government, plant breeders and food consumers. The corporation could provide a much needed co-ordination role between the various public plant breeding bodies throughout Australia. Probably the most valuable function of a public plant breeding corporation would be the formation within its organisation of a national seeds marketing authority. Such an authority would deal exclusively with seeds recommended by State departments of agriculture as being of real benefit to Australian farmers. It would be the sole wholesale distributor of recommended seeds. Farmers would be expected to favour buying the recommended and certified seeds distributed by the marketing authority. Private companies which bred seeds good enough to be recommended by various departments of agriculture could be paid royalties based on across the counter sales. It would be impossible for other companies or institutions to pirate the recommended seed. In order to gain access to the seeds market in recommended varieties, seeds growers would have to sell through the marketing authority since it alone would act as a wholesale agent for recommended seeds. The marketing authority would direct all royalties to the company which developed the recommended seed.

At present the publicly bred varieties are poorly distributed and information about new varieties is communicated through department of agriculture extension officers, local newspapers and by word of mouth. The national seeds marketing authority would provide a co-ordinated sales and promotion network and act on behalf of public breeding institutions. The authority would be of great benefit to the small breeders who lack the sales and promotional network to distribute beneficial seeds because they lack capital, time and other resources needed to set up the operation. A national seeds marketing authority could provide access for the small breeder to the national market once the variety developed by the breeder was recommended by the appropriate State department of agriculture.

There are a number of advantages in a national seeds marketing authority for plant variety rights. In the first place, with a seeds marketing authority, only plant breeding of real benefit to Australian growers and consumers would be encouraged. Plant variety rights encourage cosmetic plant breeding. As I pointed out previously, the legislative requirements of distinctness, uniformity and stability have a detrimental effect on good plant breeding. Secondly, a seeds marketing authority would not lead to the vertical integration of the seed industry as would happen with plant variety rights; nor would private plant breeders be given a right to say where seeds would be sold and which seed growers would obtain contracts to grow them. All seed growers approved by State departments of agriculture would have the right to grow recommended seed for sale as long as they sold their seed through the agency of the seeds marketing authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to raise a point of order. Would the honourable member for La Trobe please indicate whether a national seed breeding authority is Labor Party policy?
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for La Trobe.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. A seeds marketing authority would not lead to the vertical integration of the seeds industry, as would happen under plant variety rights. Nor would private plant breeders be given the right to say where seeds would be sold, and which seed growers would obtain contracts to grow them. All seed growers approved by State departments of agriculture would have the right to grow recommended seed for sale as long as they sold their seed through the agency of the seeds marketing authority. Similarly, seeds handled by the seeds marketing authority would be available to all seed merchants in the regions where the departments of agriculture recommend the seeds for use.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, a seeds marketing authority would be able to negotiate with overseas breeders controlling United States and European patents on seeds of worth to Australian agriculture and would promote the export of Australian developed seeds overseas, ensuring that whenever seeds are marketed they represent appropriate forms of technology. A fourth advantage would be that a seeds marketing authority could ensure the security of the public breeding sector in the face of commercial approaches by the private sector to seeds promotion and marketing; that is provided, of course, adequate government funding is maintained. Fifthly, a seeds marketing authority would ensure the survivability and right to commercial reward for those with little capital backing such as small nurseries, seed growers and plant breeders.

The final advantage of a marketing authority over the Plant Variety Rights Bill would be to ensure free access to genetic materials by paying royalties to only those companies which allowed open access to their genetic stocks. Plant variety rights have encouraged scientific secretiveness and the hoarding of genetic materials. Sources of funding available for a public plant breeding corporation could be commissions on sales-overseas and within Australia-crop levies, and the Consolidated Revenue. I would like to go on and describe further benefits of the National Seed Authority but time is against me. I support the proposal that this Bill be withdrawn and that the whole matter of plant variety rights be referred to a select committee of this House. I hope in particular that such a committee would look at the possible creation of a national seeds marketing authority as being a positive approach by me to this most important matter.
Sitting suspended from 5.57 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very strongly this long overdue legislation to implement plant variety rights in Australia. I do so because of my personal knowledge as a farmer in this country and my experience on farms in the United Kingdom, the United States of America and New Zealand. I have seen the tremendous advantage that the farmers of those countries have over farmers in Australia in terms of variety and yield potential of plant material because of the greater plant breeding that takes place in those countries. I have talked to farmers and plant breeders both public and private in those countries. More and more I am convinced that if Australian agriculture is to compete internationally , if Australian farmers are to be allowed to compete effectively with their competitors in these other countries, plant variety rights are essential unless there is a massive increase in public breeding allocations in this country. The variety and yield gap between countries which have plant variety rights and those countries which do not have plant variety rights is accelerating and Australian farmers are being left further behind.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important general point in respect of plant breeding in Australia is that much more money is needed. If we are to have improved varieties there has to be either a massive increase in public money, meaning money from governments at both the Federal and State levels, or a mixture of public and private money for plant breeding research. Plant variety rights are essential because without patent protection there is no incentive to invest other than in the breeding of hybrids-that is those varieties of plants which cannot reproduce themselves. It is not just a matter of farmers and the Government contributing on a dollar for dollar basis. There must be a massive increase in general government funds.

This is what amazes me about the ignorant, ideologically blinkered opponent group of plant variety rights of which the previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), was a wonderful example. Never before in this place have I heard any supporters of this view give any priority to or place any emphasis on the allocation of public money for plant breeding in this country. These people probably do not even know that plant breeding takes place. Yet simply because of their ideological opposition to allowing the farmers of this country the ability to compete internationally, public breeding funds suddenly are trotted out. But what will be their attitude when it comes to a choice of where public funds should go? It will be interesting to see in their speeches on the coming Budget and in other debates that take place in this House whether they believe funds for public breeding have any priority at all or whether this matter is conveniently forgotten when they get back to their trendy priorities again.

Let me be more specific with regard to plant variety rights and the needs of Australian agriculture. We need more varieties that are compatible with the variations in soil, climate, dry conditions, irrigation conditions and so on that exist in Australia. We can take the example of soya beans. I understand that to a certain extent soya beens grown in Australia are still based on varieties introduced here from overseas many years ago. These varieties have never been very successful and have been confined to certain areas. The same situation applied many years ago in the United States. However, now soya beans are grown from the Gulf of Mexico to the Canadian border and the represent the second biggest grain export earner for that country.

Let me refer to coarse grains and oil seeds generally. A terrible lack of breeding is taking place in this country because funds are not being made available for this purpose. Let me refer to irrigated wheat. I come from an irrigated area where wheat is being grown under irrigation. In 1962 I spent some time on irrigation farms in the United States. At that time the first of the semi-dwarf wheats bred for irrigation conditions had just been introduced. A variety called Gains yielded 100 bushels to the acre in the United States in 1962. In 1982 in Australia there is still not one variety of wheat that will produce 100 bushels to the acre. I can assure honourable members that the United States has not just stopped with the Gains variety which was first introduced in 1962.

Let us look at the lack of varieties in respect of lucernes and rye grass. On my farm at the moment I am sowing down some irrigation country. The three rye grass varieties we are using are all imported from New Zealand because no breeding takes place in this country. In the United Kingdom, supposedly because of a national list, restrictions are placed on a number of varieties. However, farmers in that country have a choice of nine varieties of perennial rye grass. One can go through the list and see how much worse off we are in this country. In terms of yield we are falling further and further behind our competitors. For example, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) and I had discussions with Mr Murphy, the Controller of Plant Variety Rights in Great Britain, who is a public servant and neutral in these matters. Murphy told us two months ago that there is no variety of wheat now grown in the United Kingdom older than 10 years because of the tremendous breeding improvement that has taken place. Yet in northern Victoria the most popular variety of wheat is still Olympic which was introduced in 1956 at the time of the Olympic Games. There has been no yield increase over that period.

Those who think that wheat breeding in this country is keeping up with wheat breeding in the rest of the world are ignorant. They do not know what is going on with wheat breeding in the rest of the world. The comments of Murphy and Valarie Sylvie of the National Institute of Agricultural Botany at Cambridge are contrary to the selective quotes that have been made by the Opposition. Valarie Sylvie in a paper on the influence of improved crop varieties and husbandry methods on increasing cereal yield said that over half of the dramatic increase in yield that has taken place has been due to breeding. She stated:
More than half that improvement--
She is referring here to wheat yields--
has resulted from varieties commercialised in the last 15 years. Consideration of the varieties currently recommended--
And she then names them-
shows that Plant Breeders are producing varieties with even higher yield potential.

She then goes on to say how this yield potential is increasing. So the longer we stay out of plant variety rights in this country the further our farmers will be disadvantaged in the international contest for markets. People on the Opposition side of the House have no idea of agriculture at all. They are denying the Australian farmers the opportunity to keep pace with the rest of the world.

I refer here also to the problems of overseas varieties not being allowed into this country until we have plant variety rights. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), who is at the table, gave a long list of such varieties. The fruit growers of my area are denied the opportunity to use new peach varieties and apple varieties because there are no plant variety rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that that will save the fruit industry?

—I am saying that they would have a far better opportunity to compete and more will be achieved than by this negative ignorant ideological attitude of the people on the honourable member's side of the House. An adequate breeding program, whether public or private, will never be developed for a whole range of smaller horticultural industries in this country because the industries in Australia are too small. The only way the horticultural industry can keep up with the rest of the world is to import those varieties, and this will only happen if plant variety rights are introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: One can look also at the limitations on public breeding finance in this country . Money is provided by the Government on a dollar for dollar basis for breeding whether for wheat, barley or other grains. One need only look at the very narrow limitations that are put on by farmer controlled committees in respect of research for those plant varieties to see that we have another argument here in favour of plant variety rights. Because of the narrow limitations of the breeding programs provided, which are concentrated on wheat, the wheat farmers of this country are denied access to a range of other coarse grains available to their overseas competitors. Very little money is available on a dollar for dollar basis for breeding programs for other grains.

The farmers of this country already are very generous in the amount of money they put up for public breeding programs. I have not heard of the doctors of this country putting up money on a dollar for dollar basis for medical research. Nor have I heard of small business in secondary industry putting up money on a dollar for dollar basis in the same way that the farmers of this country have put up money for research. If more money is to be available for breeding in this country it has to come either from money gained from the introduction of plant variety rights or from general government public breeding programs. I cannot see any honourable member on the other side of the House giving this matter any priority whatsoever other than while this debate lasts tonight.

If we were to put more money into public breeding-I would like to see that happening-we would still be denied many of the advantages that come with plant variety rights. It is incorrect for people to say that public breeding is reduced when plant variety rights are introduced. It is clear from evidence presented by a Bureau of Agricultural Economics study and from conversations I have had with plant breeders in a number of countries that the opposite is the case. If public breeding is reduced, it is reduced when Labor governments get into power. A Labor government is in power in New South Wales and it has reduced the availability of funds for public breeding. It will be interesting to see what happens in Victoria now that it has a Labor government. It will be interesting to see what happens if a Federal Labor government is elected. It will be very interesting to see whether these trendy supporters opposite of the anti-plant variety rights movement still talk about priority for public breeding once this debate concludes in this House.

There is no evidence that more money will be made available for public breeding by this country other than through plant variety rights. What is also of interest is that if plant variety rights are brought in, Australia will have a new industry. It will have more employment. Because Australia is in the southern hemisphere there will be opportunities for breeding programs in the northern hemisphere off-season. This is happening in New Zealand now. It will not happen here without the introduction of plant variety rights.

Let us look at some of the arguments that are used by this ideological group which opposes plant variety rights. Somehow or other people belonging to this group think that plants are unique. Why are plants unique and not animals? We have proprietory rights in relation to animals in the sense that we can obtain semen from bulls and can register stud breeds. I do not see any difference between patent rights for computers and proprietory rights for plants. What is unique about a plant? What makes it any different from something that either grows on this earth or is produced on this earth? Talking about ideological opposition to plant variety rights, how many honourable members on the other side of the House know that East Germany, Hungary and Russia have plant variety rights? Honourable members opposite see nothing wrong with a socialist country adopting plant variety rights. It is not contrary to the social philosophy of honourable members opposite to have plant variety rights.

Our previous speaker felt strongly about the point I am about to raise. He felt that the plant variety rights requirement that before a new variety can be registered it has to be uniform, stable and reliable, was something new and different. That is the basic requirement for every new variety that is developed , be it publicly bred or privately bred. No public breeder will have any variety released, approved or registered until it is uniform, stable and reliable. That applies irrespective of whether there is public breeding or private breeding. If honourable members opposite did their homework they would find that out.

Honourable members opposite also said that this legislation will reduce the number of varieties that are available to people. The opposite will occur because of the increased breeding that will take place as a result of the increased money that is put into plant breeding. The Opposition based its argument on the fact that in the United Kingdom, after plant variety rights were introduced, there was a reduction in the number of vegetable varieties that were classified as different. The truth of the matter is that when the United Kingdom decided to test all of the varieties-it made that decision when plant variety rights were introduced-it found that a lot of the so-called varieties that were thought to be separate were actually identical. Hence, it saw a reduction in the number of vegetable varieties available. Some honourable members have talked about restrictions. We will not have a national list in this country. There will be no restriction on the number of varieties that is possible for a particular variety. Honourable members opposite are not aware of this because they do not know the subject: There are tremendous restrictions on the number of varieties that can be grown commercially in this country now even though plant variety rights do not apply. A farmer can produce only certain varieties of wheat which will be accepted by the grain elevator boards or by the Australian Wheat Board. This applies to barley and to sugar also. Only certain varieties of sugar are accepted at the sugar mill. The fruit canneries will take only certain varieties of peaches or pears. Wineries will take only certain varieties of grapes. Good heavens, we have restrictions now. Restrictions have nothing to do with plant variety rights. They do have something to do with commercial requirements when producing commodities. That is a completely different subject.

Honourable members opposite also talked about the loss of genetic material. Once again, the opposite is the case. That is because of increased research. Honourable members opposite talked about gene banks. We are talking about a completely separate issue. It has to do with national and international agreements on gene banks. I am pleased that the Minister in his second reading speech made reference to the fact that international co-operation is increasing. What might be of interest to honourable members opposite is that the evidence available from countries that have introduced plant variety rights shows that in fact there is an increasing exchange of germ plasm material.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I am sorry but it is true. I can substantiate my comments with the results of studies by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and by Agricultural Canada which I have in front of me. The honourable member for La Trobe cannot do that. The results of the studies that have been made are in front of me in black and white. When the Opposition talks about officials of the Food and Agriculture Organisation it is talking about people who have been disowned by the Food and Agriculture Organisation. There is no authority in the comments made by the Opposition. The Opposition also talked about lower disease resistance, the greater need for fertilisers and the fact that some cosmetic varieties will be introduced to dupe the farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Opposition is internally inconsistent in its arguments because on the one hand it is saying that there will be fewer varieties because of restrictions and on the other hand it is saying that there will be more varieties but that notice should not be taken of them because they are cosmetic, they are just out to fool the farmers. Honourable members opposite are saying that somehow or other when varieties are introdued by public breeders they are perfect, that they need less fertiliser and that they never succumb to different diseases. I can assure honourable members opposite that in the public breeding that takes place a very high percentage of varieties released are subsequently withdrawn. Farmers will not use them because they are susceptible to disease. Because they are cosmetic they do not increase yield. Farmers are not fools. They are very hard-headed business people. Why say to a farmer: 'You need protection in selecting your variety of plants but you do not need protection in selecting a car, an animal or agricultural machinery'?

Once again I ask: What is unique about plants that is not unique about anything else in which people are involved? As other honourable members on this side of the House have said in relation to disease resistance, the basic thrust these days is to reduce the need for chemical control because of the cost et cetera. Therefore, farmers look for disease resistant varieties before they look for anything else when buying new varieties. I turn now to fertilisers. Good heavens , if one is to get a high yield one has to feed the plant well. It will need more fertiliser, just as a dairy cow needs to be fed well. There is a relationship between the amount of fertiliser that is used and the yield of the plant if the yield potential is genetically present in the variety. Honourable members opposite should not run away with the fond thought that a plant can be bred which will produce 100 bushels to the acre but will not need fertiliser.

Mention has been made of multinational concerns. Are you aware that we have some multinational organisations breeding here already, before the introduction of plant variety rights? They are breeding here--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Will you, Mr Deputy Speaker, draw the attention of the honourable member for Murray to the fact that he should address his comments through the Chair. He is using the word 'you' and is attributing to the Opposition a whole lot of arguments that-
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat . The honourable member for Murray is required to address his remarks through the Chair and other honourable members will refrain from interjecting.

—I am very interested in the comments of the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, in view of what he was told when we were together in the United Kingdom and his attitude now to plant varieties. Let us talk about multinational organisations. They are here already. They are here without plant variety rights. They are doing a very good job. Without them money would not have been put into the breeding of hybrid grains, which are essential if we are to develop a range of export commodities, coarse grains et cetera. But there is no evidence of domination by multinationals when plant variety rights legislation comes in. For example, in the United States, in the 10 years of PVR, only 17 per cent of the registrations of new plant varieties have come from the big six companies. I have been on some of these plant breeding places and spoken to people who, because of the added flexibility of PVR, have been able to start small companies. PVR gives greater flexibility for small breeders, not just large breeders, to get involved in the plant breeding industry. I am dismayed that the fate of Australian agriculture in remaining internationally competitive could be determined by people who have no knowledge of agriculture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole debate on plant variety rights has been laden with emotion, as we have seen from the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). People seem to get very emotive about this issue. Numerous groups and individuals have notified their opinions and their stand on the issue. The debate has taken place over a long time and many questions still remain to be answered. I believe that there could be merit in introducing some form of legislation in this area, but I believe that this Bill is so badly worded, with so many omissions, that it should be withdrawn and redrafted after being the subject of research by a select committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Among other things, the proposed legislation provides that applications will be received and considered for patenting whether the applicant is resident in Australia or not. I believe that there could be a danger in this provision. We have recently begun to review our industrial patent system. Top level inquiries in Australia have found that local innovation research and development programs have not been greatly stimulated by the patent system and that in some cases its influence may be negative. A Senate standing committee inquiry into industrial research and development noted in 1979:

The system is a supposed stimulant to capital investment. However, CSIRO considers that its (the patent schemes) influence has been minor and that the influence of tariffs and quotas, tax provisions, investment allowances, industrial export incentives and development grants are much more powerful and particular in their effect.
Australia's patent system may well be acting against the country's best interests.
We should note that. The report continued:

Once again, the absence of any clear policy . . . makes it difficult to know where our best interests lie . . . although there are many examples of patent monoply providing encouragement, the overall effect of the patent system on indigenous research and development could well be negative in a situation where most patents are issued to large foreign corporations and in addition many are bad.
The scource of that is a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and Environment entitled 'Industrial Research and Development in Australia 1979', page 135.

In Australia in 1978, 90 per cent of industrial patents issued were to overseas corporations. As a result of the Senate inquiry, the Minister for Productivity- then the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee)-announced in November 1979 the beginning of a departmental investigation into the Australian industrial patent system. At the same time, the Department of Primary Industry was drawing up plans for a plant patenting system. Throughout its published information the Department of Primary Industry repeats the same arguments used centuries ago for the initiation of an industrial patent system. Is the Department of Primary Industry aware of the general disenchantment with the patent system held by those people who have had most experience with it in industry? If PVR follows the pattern set by industrial patents, it will be nothing more than a piece of government regulation of the market place that will favour large corporations and lead to a massive exodus of Australian funds overseas in the form of royalties.
The Uniting Church in Australia Board for Social Responsibility notes in its opposition to the Plant Variety Rights Bill:

This provision opens the way for multinational petrochemical companies which have already taken over the seed industry under similar legislation in Europe and the United States of America to do the same in Australia.

It is interesting to note that reports from the United States of America, albeit a few years out of date, say that a few large companies dominate each of the major seed crops: For example, Pioneer and De Kalb, now owned by the chemical corporation Ciba-Geigy, and Pioneer in alfalfa, lucerne, seed; Asgrow, now owned by the chemical corporation Upjohn, and Burpee, now owned by ITT, in vegetable seed; Cargell, Funk-Ciba-Geigy again-Asgrow, now Upjohn, and Pioneer in sorghum seed; and as well Burpee-ITT-dominates the mail order business, and Ferry Morse- Union Carbide-is the major retail packet seed seller. In the United States of America, three corporations hold 80 per cent of the patents on beans; four corporations hold 45 per cent of the patents on cotton; four corporations hold 60 per cent of the patents on lettuce; four corporations hold 62 per cent of the patents on peas; four corporations hold 48 per cent of the patents on soya beans ; and four corporations hold 69 per cent of the patents on barley. That is a fairly strong monopoly.

Further, in Europe, the European Court's recent investigation into the European seed market has singled out three multinational companies in this connection- Shell Oil, Ciba-Geigy, and Sancoz. The trend is fairly distinct and, without getting hysterical about it, we should take note of it.
In a paper presented on Monday to a plant variety seminar held here and organised by the Liberal-National Country Party rural committee, Mr Hugh Roberts , a farmer, commented:

The reason that many multinational companies of all shapes and sizes are starting to move into the plant breeding field is simple-they believe and acknowledge that plant breeding will be for the twenty-first century what chemical engineering was to the twentieth century-no more, no less.
That may well be true. However, we should note that the statement is only an opinion expressed, no more and no less, and is not supported by any proof. It behoves us to be wary.

I cannot accept the statements that unless and until Australia gets a Plant Variety Rights Act, Australian breeders and growers will be denied access to newly developed material from overseas. It could be that because the proposed Act includes a provision that varieties existing prior to the introduction of the Act cannot be registered the new material is being withheld until we determine whether or not we shall have a Plant Variety Rights Act. Once that is determined, either for or against, the material will become available to breeders and owners. People will always seek markets to sell their goods.

Part III, Division 4, clauses 29 and 33 of the Bill are unacceptable to the Opposition. The statement that the Minister can attach special conditions to the granting of PVR if he or she considers it necessary in the public interest gives little confidence in the preciseness of the legislation. The wording of clause 33, 'reasonable prices in sufficient quantities', and 'ensure that reasonable requirements of the public . . . are satisfied', is vague and very imprecise. One wonders what criteria the Minister and his Department would use to determine what is reasonable in each case.

In Part III, Division 2, clause 20, tests of plant variety are discussed, and again the Bill is vague and imprecise. The Secretary to Primary Industry is to determine whether testing will be undertaken-but again according to what criteria? Will there be testing only if powerful industry groups lobby for it? Who will do the testing? What will the testing include? Will it include merit or just difference? How will merit be judged? Who will pay for the testing?

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not read the second reading speech.

—These are questions which must be answered. There are too many loose ends, and too many questions and not enough answers-and what anwers the Minister is giving us are too imprecise. The Bill is badly drafted, is far too general, and it leaves too many loopholes open to interpretation. It contains no real commitment to the public funding of plant breeding through existing institutions . There is community concern about PVR. In mentioning community concern, I suggest to the honourable member for Murray that PVR is not just for the wheat farmers. The vagueness of the Bill heightens fears about the consequences of PVR . For example, the basic criteria for registration under PVR legislation in all countries are that the cultivar should be new-distinctive-uniform and stable. The criteria for a new plant to be distinct, uniform and stable are not spelt out, so that there is no process fr certification and a new plant does not necessarily have to be better.

SPEECH.PARA: We would do much better to redraft the Bill so that breeders know exactly where they stand and so that less is left to chance. As I have said, we are not totally opposed to a PVR Bill. We are opposed to the terms of this Bill, and we believe that, in the interests of breeders, farmers, conservationists and those concerned about monopolies, we should have a select committee report on the whole issue and draft a Bill that does not need 68 amendments. Let us find out what the deficiencies are in our country and how best to meet them, in the interests of the farmers as well as the rest of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It is quite clear from what the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) said that she certainly has not read my second reading speech because many of the questions that she raised in her contribution were answered in that speech. I do not propose to deal with all of those points now. I do not wish to be unkind to her but it might have been helpful had she been in the House earlier this afternoon when I made a speech on the Plant Variety Rights Bill. A number of the points that she took up were answered then.

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up two of the points she made in her address. The Bill makes it quite clear that there will be no merit testing. That is not part of the PVR Bill. In regard to public plant breeding, I have made it quite plain that the Bill has no effect on public breeding. That will be a matter for the individual Budgets of the State governments which are involved in public breeding. The PVR Bill will not in any way affect such a decision. It can be a decision only of the government concerned.

In terms of contributions to the Bill, I make the point that this seems to have been lost by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) and others who spoke for the Opposition. The fact of the matter is that the Agricultural Council will be the final master of this Bill. I remind honourable members that the Agricultural Council is made up of six State Ministers, of all political colours , plus the Commonwealth Minister, so every careful consideration will be given to any plants or seeds covered by plant variety rights. Another point seems to have been lost by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and also by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). No present plants and stocks, whether they be native or bred, can be part of PVR. It is only when somebody breeds a new plant after the Bill is promulgated that he can apply for registration. There is no guarantee that he will get it; he will have to meet certain tests. Therefore the wild and extraordinary claims of the honourable member for La Trobe that the whole of the present plant and seed system will disappear into the hands of multinationals are just too ludicrous to contemplate .

I want to congratulate particularly the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I thought their contributions were excellent. They laid at rest many of the ideological fears that have been expressed by the Uniting Church in Australia and repeated in this Parliament tonight by certain members of the Opposition. They did the Bill a great service. For the honourable member for Henty to say that because of the great number of amendments to the Bill the Government does not know where it is with it is to lose the point. I laid the Bill on the table 11 months ago for the simple purpose of garnering these amendments. I have given every opportunity for public debate on the issue. Some State governments have done better than others in terms of fostering public debate and some have done better in fostering seminars and the like. Every opportunity was given to State governments, to organisations and to industries to come to the Government, to come to me, with proposed amendments. All the amendments that I have for this Bill contain the collective wisdom of all the people who have put this Bill to study. I laid the Bill on the table 11 months ago with that deliberate purpose in mind. To thrust confusion on the matter by saying that because I have these amendments the Government does not know where it is going with this legislation is to mislead the House and to misunderstand completely the purpose of the amendments.

There are a great number of amendments to move and I think we ought to proceed to the Committee stage straight away. Before we do so I wish to deal with the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, which was moved by the honourable member for Werriwa. He wants firstly to set up a select committee . We on this side of the House do not believe that there is any need to set up a select committee. All the work that could possibly be done by a select committee has been done by the various Ministers for Agriculture and me in drawing this Bill together. The House ought to recognise that this legislation is being introduced on behalf of the States; it is not for any Commonwealth purpose. The Government is introducing these measures only because they can be more sensibly carried out by Commonwealth legislation. However, it is the States which benefit from the legislation. I do not believe that we need to go into this great charade of setting up a select committee, which simply would create a further delay. This further delay is proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa because he could not convince the Caucus to allow Parliament to proceed with the Bill as it was. He failed in his advocacy and this is the means by which he scrambled out from underneath while still perhaps being able to claim that he is doing his best to get plant variety rights legislation. The truth of the situation is shown by his amendment.

The honourable member argues that the Bill will not meet plant breeding needs but the fact is that PVR will encourage breeding because rewards will go to the breeders who put in the effort. Breeders will be rewarded only for improved plants which meet the needs of the people. The market-place will determine whether a new breed of plant or seed, whether it be under PVR or not, is better than plants or seeds already available. Again I remind honourable members that registering for PVR is an entirely voluntary thing; people can breed a new plant without having it registered under PVR.

The amendment goes on to refer to the diminution of public plant breeding. I have made the point before that there is no evidence to suggest that there will be any reduction in public plant breeding. In fact, in New Zealand the evidence is to the contrary. Again I make the point that the main responsibility for public plant breeding will lie with the States and State Budgets. The amendment says there will be dangers to Australia's producing and marketing institutions. I cannot see any possible danger in this Bill. It is a nonsense to say that there are dangers to Australia's producing and marketing institutions. The honourable member for Werriwa did not explain what he meant by dangers or where the threat would come from. His argument on that point was inadequate. The amendment refers to inadequately tested new varieties. As I think the honourable member for Wakefield and the honourable member for Murray pointed out, it will be the farmers and the buyers of the seed who will be the judges of the new varieties. Despite the attempts of the Opposition to paint them as being silly, they are not. They are not silly enough to buy varieties that are not as good as those varieties already on the market. So we cannot agree on that either.

The amendment of the honourable member for Werriwa then refers to the preservation of plant resources. This is quite irrelevant to the PVR legislation . There has been and will continue to be considerable effort in Australia to keep such material together. The PVR legislation will have no effect on that whatsoever. To sum up, the Government cannot accept the amendment to the motion as moved by the honourable member for Werriwa.
