TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 1, before the definition of 'applicant' insert the following definition:
' ''Advisory Committee'' means the group of persons established in pursuance of section 5A;'.

I will speak briefly to the amendment. Honourable members will be aware that in the original Bill there was provision for an advisory committee. This amendment simply sets out to establish such a committee, which we have defined, in terms of its membership and composition, in proposed new section 5A, the insertion of which I will move at a later stage. The establishment of an official advisory committee is desirable to assist in the formulation of regulations under the Act and generally to assist the Registrar of Plant Variety Rights on policy matters, particularly the selection of the types of crops which warrant recommendation to the Australian Agricultural Council for inclusion in the scheme.

The original draft Plant Variety Rights Bill of 1979, the presentation of which was under the direction of the former Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair , provided for the establishment of a 13 member committee for this purpose. It was prescribed that the committee would not be entitled to any remuneration or allowances. It is my understanding that certain primary industry organisations objected to that provision and lobbied the Government saying that they were not really going to go along with it. Since that time they have had a second look at it. I know of many primary industry organisations which believe that it is essential that there be such an advisory committee. I refer to nurserymen, orchardists and certain seed producers. One of the major proponents, the industry committee for plant breeders' rights, is also of the view that there should be an advisory committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). This matter has been considered at length by both the Commonwealth and the States. It is believed that there is enough expertise and knowledge in the State departments of agriculture to enable them to be masters of their own situation. The Government does not believe that adding an extra advisory committee will advance the matter at all and rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Kerin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 3, page 2, after the definition of ''Department'' insert the following definition:

'' 'description' means a comprehensive botanical cataloguing of attributes as well as a quantative and qualitative assessment of the variety's characteristics from a commercial, environmental and nutritional point of view, where appropriate;''.

What the Opposition is saying, consistent with our second reading amendment and the general thrust of our position in the debate on this whole question, is that the word 'description' needs to be properly defined. We have been suggesting all through the debate that there should be some scheme of merit or performance testing, and, in terms of the actual description of the varieties being put to the Registrar for assessment, we say that the legislation should set out just what has to be described, that is, the qualities and characteristics of the allegedly new variety. Implicit in the amendment and consistent with the list of amendments that I am putting forward on behalf of the Opposition is the view that the applicant who is putting up the new variety should provide all the information. In other words, it is at cost to the applicant. What we are saying is that the word 'description' should be defined in the legislation as meaning a comprehensive botanical cataloguing of attributes as well as a quantatitive and qualitative assessment of the variety's characteristics from a commercial, environmental and nutritional point of view, where appropriate.

In my comments in the second reading debate I said that of course in respect of many varieties of ornamentals and flora culture there is simply no need for there to be commercial, environmental and nutritional description criteria or performance test at all. In these areas people are dealing with diversity and differences, and there is simply no need for that sort of description. That is why I am saying that there should be a description only where appropriate. If there were any problem the advisory committee, which the Opposition sought to establish by amendment but which amendment was voted against by the Parliament, could have provided advice to the Secretary, the Registrar or the Minister, again where appropriate.

We cannot see why the Government cannot not possibly accept this amendment. It is very important with respect to new varieties of cereals and food crops which farmers will buy to make money, that the commercial characteristics should be known along with their reaction to disease and the various climatic stresses. These things should be known. The applicant himself should incorporate the information in his description of the variety. As I also pointed out in my speech in the second reading debate, at present wheat breeders have to supply enormous documentation. They have to engage in many trials. They have to engage in comparisons with other wheat varieties before the variety is accepted by a State government and before it becomes a variety for varietal control purposes and then sells through the Australian Wheat Board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was not able to hear everything that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) said in relation to the amendment. I understand that this clause is the instigating clause, if I can put it that way, for a form of merit testing and on that basis I suppose it is reasonable for me to debate his remarks. The Government parties rural committee that I chair takes the view that the job of the Federal Government is to legislate as broadly and as loosely as possible within our constitutional framework. It takes the view that if any unevenness of opinion exists from State to State they should pick up such unevenness and act accordingly. Insofar as that is true it would seem to me quite an inane proposition to include new floral species, beautiful shrubs and trees as subjects of merit testing. If the Committee were to accept that proposition-I think that it holds a certain amount of merit-one would then argue that, considering the experience of other countries, one would question the whole matter of forms of testing. For instance , it is true to say that the form of merit testing which exists in the United Kingdom today-it includes advisory boards and other bodies which come to decisions under the system of royalty payments-is becoming bogged down. As you know, Mr Deputy Chairman, there is nothing worse than a system which becomes bogged down. If I might say so, nothing comes out at the other end. This is one of the problems with the royalty payments system which currently applies in the United Kingdom.

SPEECH.PARA: As I described during the afternoon, quite an issue has been made of royalties. As I understand the Bill which is before the Committee, no such question of royalties arises. That would rarely apply to the process here. All that will happen under this legislation is that an inventor will request a patent right on the production of a new species, seed or plant. If the request is acceptable to the Australian Agricultural Council-bearing in mind that under the terms of the Bill at this stage no old species are to be accepted-the patent right on that species will allow the breeder, having gone through the process that I have so described, to breed up the plant, species or seed that he has invented. When he has bred that up and has produced sufficient numbers to market it he will have the problem of pricing his community on the market. At this early stage no old species or seeds are included in the PVR legislation. In the early stages a breeder can put only his new species on the market according to the dictates of the market place. If the breeder puts too much kudos on his invention people will not buy it. If he emphasises its competitiveness-presumably with the idea that it is more beautiful, more productive or softer to walk on, depending on the species-perhaps people will buy it.

I remind the Committee of an example produced at a seminar held on Monday. The example was a new species of Brussels sprouts which was planted in the vegetable growing areas of England and selling at around 40 times the cost of the usual variety of Brussels sprouts. The fact is that in that instance the cost of the seed as a proportion of the cost of the production of the Brussels sprouts was relatively small. Those who took the gamble and paid more for that seed finished up a tonne to the acre-or whatever the blazes the final result was-better off in terms of cost. This is really what the Bill is about. I do not see much point in merit testing unless the State governments want to adopt unevenness of opinion. Having listened to Mr Amos from Tasmania and to others, I think that the State governments will decide that some form of testing should apply to certain varieties. I suggest to the Committee that one should not allow that line of thinking to intrude on the fact that the Federal legislation must be broad and general, and it is. I suggest, along those lines, there is not a great deal of merit in the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) has just put forward an argument that the United Kingdom, after 15 years' experience of its plant variety rights legislation, has reached the stage when its merit testing procedure is becoming bogged down. In view of overseas experience and the fact that the United Kingdom is running into problems, and because the Plant Variety Rights Bill lacks a clause covering description-that was outlined by the honourable member for Werriwa-it would seem to me that we should support the principle of withdrawing this Bill and having another look at it. It cannot be said that the way to avoid problems which have developed in another part of the world-it has occurred in the United Kingdom with merit testing-is to take away relevant parts of the legislation and hope that the system, through market forces, can overcome the problem of its own accord. I would like to see some evidence of that before voting for such a Bill. We are adopting legislation which just omits reference to areas in which problems exist overseas, rather than logically coming up with an answer to the problems. I think that is a poor way of bringing forward legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The definition as described by the Opposition should be taken into consideration. This is another reason that our argument should be seriously considered. We should not go ahead with legislation when solid arguments against it are coming forward both from the Opposition and the public. I have no doubt that when the farming community has a good look at this legislation and takes into consideration the problems that are involved it too will want us to take the line that we are taking. More time is needed to develop a proper Bill. I strongly support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa. I reject the arguments put forward by the honourable member for Wakefield. I do not think that by deleting a clause such as this, which basically deals with a type of merit testing, we will answer the problem of merit testing and the clogging up of the system overseas. I think that we need to have a further look at this legislation before we can possibly guarantee that it will work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said in his second reading speech that the purpose of the Bill was to make possible the granting of proprietary rights somewhat similar to a grant of patent rights. I tried to address myself to this in my remarks earlier today.
—But we couldn't understand you.

—I am terribly sorry about that. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) once told me that some people have difficulty in that area; it is to do with their intelligence. With due respect, if the honourable member would listen it might do him some good. As I pointed out previously, Australia has a Federal system of government and responsibility lies with various governments. The responsibility of this Government is to produce a system whereby patents can be granted. If merit testing is considered necessary, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) will have the very simple task of convincing the Premier of Victoria-to whom he no doubt has quite easy access, as a party colleague-that merit testing should be carried out. Similarly, any of the New South Wales members here can do the same in their State. It is a job for State departments of agriculture if it is needed, and it is a decision for State governments. It has nothing to do with the granting of a patent. I beg the Opposition to get back on to the subject of this Bill. Basically, it is contained in the first four lines of the Minister's second reading speech. We are now bringing in furphies and red herrings by getting into this area. If the honourable member believes in merit testing, he can convince John Cain or his State Minister for Agriculture and no doubt with his connections he should be able to fix it with no trouble at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the question of merit testing is an essential component of legislation concerning plant variety rights. I have very serious reservations about the concept of plant variety rights anyway. I am not satisfied, and I am surprised that members on the Government benches would suggest that they are concerned about the interests of rural producers, in particular that they would oppose the suggestion that when plant developers, plant inventors or variety inventors are seeking plant variety rights benefits, they should at the same time be given some responsibility to finance the merit testing of those particular new varieties. It is not sufficient, and it will not be sufficient, to have the distinct, uniform, stable requirements satisfied. In fact at present in the United States of America there are apparently 170 different patented varieties of soya bean. I am not sure whether they are all on the market but there are 170 varieties. It was suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that the question of testing should be the responsibility of State government departments of agriculture. At present it is estimated that it would cost $15,000 to carry out merit testing on just one new variety. If there are 170 varieties of soya bean and on average it cost $15,000 to merit test a new variety, it means that for soya bean alone, for those varieties that are already registered in the US, it will cost the various State departments of agriculture $2.5m. The suggestion that State government departments of agriculture should be responsible for that sort of expenditure, when massive benefits will be involved for those people who take out plant variety rights, is absurd in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: At present State departments of agriculture meet the expectations of many of our rural producers and provide them with advice about the relative merits of various crops. If anyone is to be responsible for undertaking the type of testing that should be undertaken, it should be those people who are to benefit most from acquiring plant variety rights. I speak not only in connection with those particular products. Some honourable members from the Government side suggested earlier that we leave it to the wise, sound and good judgment of rural producers. I am not questioning their judgment. I am satisfied that in their own game they are qualified and competent people. But there is no one in this House who can convince me that in the first place any farmer in Australia will find it possible to assess from his own experience 170 different varieties of soya bean. The suggestion is just damned ridiculous. I do not speak only in connection with those products where results are looked for in the first year of planting. What about plants that take some years to reach the point where they start to yield? It will be some years before we can judge the success of the very expensive advertising to which fruit trees, for instance, have been subjected to convince people that the particular qualities of one plant exceed all the others. Let the plant developers and plant inventors use some of their advertising funds for merit testing in the first place.

If the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) were genuinely concerned about rural producers in Australia he would be building into this legislation a guarantee that there will be merit testing, so that adequate advice can be given and that that merit testing will be contributed to by those people who will reap the benefits. Do not try to tell me that the people that the National Country Party members purport to represent will find themselves in a beneficial position as a result of this legislation. They will not. For example, there is no guarantee that any of the varieties on the list of overseas plants that have been refused to Australia because we do not have plant variety rights legislation will be suitable to the great range of environmental conditions that exist in Australia at the moment. In fact, there are very serious doubts that those people who have been seeking those varieties overseas are satisfied at this stage. There is plenty of evidence to suggest that the people who have been saying that they have not been able to obtain plant varieties overseas in fact are not completely satisfied that those varieties will do the job that it is hoped that they will do. We will find out. It will be very interesting. When this plant variety rights legislation goes through we will keep a check on that list provided by the Department of Primary Industry and we will see just how many of the varieties listed measure up to expectations. That is the justification for it at the moment.

Rural producers, horticulturists and ornamental plant growers in Australia are being sold down the drain. We are not providing them with any guarantee that, with the confusing array and multitude of plants that will be thrust before them accompanied by expensive advertising promotion, there will be someone in a position to give sound and wise advice about the relative merits. I congratulate the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for the time, effort and competence that he has applied to this matter. Compared with the comments that we have had from the Government side, his contribution would put him so far ahead that honourable members on the Government side would not even be able to see him. This amendment is of fundamental importance. If the Government is fair dinkum about rural producers, horticulturists and ornamental plant growers in Australia , it will accept the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) said that the members of my party are selling the rural producers down the drain. I think it is time the honourable member for Hunter looked at where the support for this Bill is coming from. The fact is that there is not one rural organisation that does not support this Bill. I listed all the organisations that support this Bill. If the honourable member for Hunter wants to call them mugs, let him do so.
—They would prefer merit testing.
—I point out to the chamber that no country in the world has merit testing.
—I am not talking about other countries. Do you deny that those people who support PVR would prefer merit testing?
—Order! The Committee will come to order.

—The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) talked about the experience in the United Kingdom. The fact is that the United Kingdom does not have merit testing. It has a grow-out provision to ensure that varieties are true to type in accordance with the claims that are made about them. It does not have merit testing of the type proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). The fact remains, and experience shows, that to this point in agriculture in Australia the farmers are not mugs. The honourable member for Hunter can call them mugs if he likes but they are not.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I take a point of order. I made it perfectly clear that that was precisely what I was not doing. I will not tolerate the Minister's suggesting that I called farmers mugs.

—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member for Hunter will resume his seat. I advise him that there is a proper procedure. He will have the opportunity to correct his remarks if he has been misinterpreted.
—I think he should withdraw.

—I do not wish to misquote the honourable member. If he is hurt by my suggestion that he called farmers mugs, I will withdraw it. To me, every implication was that that was what he was saying. The honourable member for Hunter and others on the Opposition side seem to be concerned that farmers are not able to make commercial judgments about the value of seed provided to them. Let me give an experience in my own district where we grow a lot of sweet corn. Three or four years ago 30 varieties of sweet corn were grown by a few farmers to test their merits. As a result of those tests we went into seed production and have been selling seed and providing a great deal of Australia's seed requirements. There are no plant variety rights that give us any particular rights to do that. It so happens that it is being done. Farmers will have that capacity to test for themselves any claims made about new seeds or plant varieties that come on the market-place. The fact is that to put merit testing into this scheme would choke it up in the way the honourable member for Hunter described. It would become an impossibility. The best test of merit is in the market-place. Let it go to the market-place. The Government does not accept the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), for whom I have a deal of regard, made the statement that he will not listen to anybody in this House if that person is trying to convince him about the Plant Variety Rights Bill. Let me describe the difficulty that the Government is in in relation to the Bill. Soya beans have nothing to do with the clause, Mr Deputy Chairman, but allow me to follow the honourable member for a minute. He referred to the fact that there are 170 species of soya beans in America. I think he is a little under; that there are more. The fact that we have none of the newer varieties of soya bean in Australia is probably the single most important example. We do not have these soya beans in this country, and we should, because we do not have PVR legislation. However, let us leave that aside.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty the Government is in, having some understanding of the ramifications of the Bill, is that so many of the opposing forces have no understanding of it. The honourable member for Hunter-I know him; he is a decent bloke, an honourable fellow-argued that State departments may have to test 170 varieties of soya bean. This demonstrates the complete lack of knowledge of so many people about this Bill, about the factors that are involved in strain variety selection of soya bean-or anything else for that matter. Does it grow in a neutral pH? Honourable members opposite would not know what a pH of seven is from a bar of Burfords. Does it grow at a high or low level of activity? Does it grow in high, medium or low rainfall? Does it grow in alkaline or acid soil reactions? Does it grow when moisture is a limitation because the subsoil is six feet below the surface or will this particular variety grow when the subsoil is only 18 inches below the surface?

State departments that want to test soya bean-I take up the honourable member's example-will not test 170 varieties. If they are agriculturalists they will know the areas and limitations. They know the limitations of the ones they can ignore . In Tasmania one would be lucky if perhaps 10 varieties of American soya beans were tested. In South Australia, where the rainfall and soil conditions are quite different, one might not have to test more than five. In a very kindly fashion I say that the problem of this debate is that so many people do not know what they are talking about and until they do I cannot see much chance of achieving cogent argument in this place. I do not set myself up as being a doyen in this matter but we have to know and trust the people who know what they are talking about. To do anything else is patently absurd and not to the credit of this chamber or the Parliament.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Kerin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, line 14, insert ', hybrid', after 'clone'.

This provides for the inclusion of hybrids in the definition of plant variety. Hybrids, which are important in some crops, have their own inbuilt protection in that they do not normally breed true and each generation of seed must be produced from a given parent stock. This amendment, however, will clearly permit hybrids to be eligible for registration in the scheme in those cases where a breeder wishes to take this action.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 3, page 2, after sub-clause (1) insert the following sub-clause:
'(1A) For the purposes of this Act, the meaning of-
(a) 'reasonable';
(b) 'significant'; and
(c) 'sufficient',
particularly as the words are used in section 33, shall be assessed by the Advisory Committee.'.
(4) Clause 3, page 3, after sub-clause (5) insert the following sub-clause:
'(5A) The Secretary may grant a right to a variety originated overseas, where such overseas legislation allows the registration of discoveries, on the advice of the Advisory Committee.'.

The Opposition feels very strongly about these amendments. The first amendment relates to clause 33 which is headed 'Protection of public interest in new plant varieties'. Throughout clause 33 appear the words 'reasonable requirements'. For example, the clause contains the words: 'For the purposes of this section, the reasonable requirements of the public', 'where there is no demand or significant demand', 'reasonable prices' and 'reasonable quality'. This wording appears throughout the clause. Value judgments have to be made about reasonable requirements. I am not quite sure who will assess what is reasonable or what is significant or what is sufficient. It seems to me that unless we have some definition or unless somebody advises the Minister, Secretary or Registrar, it will be very difficult to determine what is reasonable at law. That is why we are proposing that these words, as they are used in clause 33, should be assessed by the advisory committee. That is why we have moved an amendment to clause 3 which is the clause dealing with definitions.

Amendment No. 4 relates very closely to lobbying by orchardists and a broad range of agricultural producers. I accept that there is some problem in respect of constitutionality. Perhaps the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) can advise me in this regard. Many people are saying that discoveries should be able to be registered and given patent rights. I do not agree with that. I think that would be quite against the whole idea of patent rights. I cannot quite understand people putting a case on behalf of Australian native plants. An Australian native plant is a native plant. It is not new.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can't be registered either.

—No, it cannot be registered-it is not a discovery. I just cannot see any reason why an Australian native plant should be regarded any more differently than some basic genetic material such as a wild wheat strain or a wild maize strain or whatever. However, I am informed that there are some plant variety systems which register discoveries. If that is so and a horticulturist wishes to get in a variety that is virtually a discovery that is registered under a plant variety right overseas, I do not see why that Australian producer or orchardist should be denied such a variety. We believe that both of these matters should be incorporated in the Bill.

—The Government cannot accept the amendments and I will give the reasons why. The word 'reasonable' is to be used by the Registrar and it was chosen on advice from the Attorney- General's Department. We believe it is applicable in this case. It is very difficult to find words better than those advised to us. In respect of amendment No. 4, the situation is that if any overseas variety is a discovery it probably would be unconstitutional to register it. I think that is the point worrying the honourable member for Werriwa. If it were not a discovery the amendment would be unnecessary anyway. So the Government does not accept either of the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has very quickly moved over the protection of public interest section of the Bill and the definition of 'reasonable'. I think the reasonable requirement of the public is something that needs a little more consideration than the Minister has given. The Bill as it is worded is open to interpretation. The words 'reasonable ', 'significant' and 'sufficient' are very much open to the political and directional interpretation of government. Many cases can be brought forward in which there is no demand or no significant demand for plants of a certain variety. What is meant by the words 'there is no demand or no significant demand '? One would think that the words 'no demand' would be sufficient. Why do the words 'or no significant demand' have to be included? What is meant by that? For instance, as I said in my speech to the second reading of the Bill, companies which bring in vegetable varieties from overseas are allowed, because of the structure of farming today, to set up a tier structure whereby they can control everything from the production of the seed right down to the final product. How are we going to judge what is meant by 'significant demand' for plants of that variety? Are we saying here that provided the company makes seed available to certified growers and that those certified growers then satisfy the demand of that company for that product nobody else has a right to that product? Are we saying that that is a significant demand or is there a public reasonable requirement? There does not seem to be any logic in the wording. The wording, as it is at present, virtually involves a political decision as to what is considered to be reasonable. If the government of the day believes in the free enterprise private system a large company, with a tier system from top to bottom , might restrict certain seed to certified growers. It could direct the contract growers to buy from those certified seed growers. Would that be a reasonable requirement in the public interest? Is that considered to be a significant demand?

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer now to the words 'in sufficient quantities to meet demand' to meet the market. But what market? The market of the public interest or the market of that company? A situation has developed in agriculture today to which I would like to draw attention. Once upon a time a product such as potatoes was grown, boiled and offered to the public. The farmer was paid a dollar plus a bit of profit and that was all it cost the public. Under today's mechanism for potato production a company puts a product out to a certified seed producer, the certified seed producer than provides it to a contract grower, and that contract grower then puts that product into a store in Victoria. Three or four months later those potatoes are hauled all the way to Sydney where they are put through a machine. They are put into paper bags and taken all the way back again to the little shop right beside the factory. The public is paying $8,000 a tonne for those potatoes and the grower gets $140 a tonne. The total system we are setting up, which this legislation is going to protect, means that $8,000 of the consumers money has to be spent for $140 to get into the farmer's pocket. Are we going to protect that type of system right down the line and make it such that there is no competition whatever?

The amendment which has been moved indicates that for the purpose of the Act the meaning of 'reasonable', 'significant', and 'sufficient' needs to be clear. Does this legislation mean that under this Government the private enterprise system, as it is set up in this structure, will allow a company to put a case forward that the reasonable requirements of the public are being looked after simply because those products are going through the system and all the way back to the kids in the form of chips? Do we mean that if somebody else wants that product an advisory committee, the establishment of which is not provided in the Bill, will make a direction that the product must be made available to the public? I do not think that the legislation is clear enough. I do not think that the words 'reasonable requirement', 'significant demand' or 'sufficient quantities' are good enough. We are allowing individual people to make decisions sometimes outside this country about what is sufficient demand and what the requirement should be. I fully support the amendment. As I said in the debate on the second reading of this Bill, I think that the Bill at this stage, because of the way it is structured, needs to be looked at again in the public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) repeated some of the logic that he put to the House in the debate on the second reading of this Bill. He understands what he is trying to say from the point of view of his own electorate. I acknowledge that fact. But what he is really saying to the House at this point is that problems exist in his electorate now which have absolutely nothing to do with plant variety rights. On balance, he has to make up his mind whether plant variety rights would accentuate the difficulty faced by his electorate now. I am of the opinion, whether it be right or wrong, that plant variety rights legislation will make available to growers in his electorate a huge number of increased varieties. He may take the opposite view. I leave that comment with him because I do not think that he did his case much good when he described his problem today. His problem has nothing to do with the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I rise to speak in this debate is to ask the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) whether he said that interested groups should have access to international varieties. I think that is what I heard him say. I congratulate him if that is what he said. It is more than I expected to hear at this stage. Perhaps there is some hope for the Bill if the honourable member for Werriwa was sincere when he made that statement. I refer to clause 33 which is before the Committee. It does not have anything to do with clause 29 although when the honourable member for Werriwa was speaking earlier I thought it did. Clause 29 deals with certain conditions that may be imposed on the granting of rights where the public interest is involved. The clause before the Committee does not deal with that. Under clause 29 problems arising with plant varieties like prickly pear and lantana which grows in Queensland and a whole wide variety of beautiful garden species can be dealt with. These matters are covered by State legislation concerning weeds. Clause 29 gives the Minister overriding powers. He may seek to stop the seeded variety of kikuya entering the wet areas of Australia. For that sort of reason the Minister has carte blanche powers.

Clause 33 with which we are dealing now simply gives the assurance that sufficient quantities of plants, plant material or seeds of registered varieties are made available to meet the reasonable demands of the public for that variety . The Minister has touched on this point. I do not know how else the word ' reasonable' can be defined. As the Minister said, the word 'reasonable' has been used on the advice of the legal boys in the Government as the best word to cover the intention of the Government. I hope that no honourable member in the chamber questions the integrity of the Government in relation to the use of the word ' reasonable'. This is the best word that can be used. Honourable members opposite have my assurance as far as I can give it, that that provision will be abided by . I do not see any substance in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa to this particular clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), of course, does not have the same degree of substance as the earlier amendment. It concerns me that a rational and sensible suggestion of this kind should not be accepted by the Government. The terms 'reasonable', ' significant' and 'sufficient' which are used are subjective terms. Someone finally will have to determine just what those terms mean. The alternatives are that we have it assessed by the proposed advisory committee or perhaps, depending upon the response of the Government, by some other authority involved with plant variety rights; or it can be finally determined by the courts. If it is the wish of the Government to have an Act which will encourage litigation by people who may have cause to be offended by the way in which the provisions of the Act are applied then so be it. But here is an opportunity for the Government to avoid litigation, to remove the doubtful subjectivity that is involved in those terms and to ensure that a responsible authority will have the legal power to determine the meaning of 'reasonable', 'significant' and 'sufficient'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments made by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) sound fine except for the fact that the committee proposed in the Opposition's amendment will be given the grand power to decide what 'reasonable', 'significant' and 'sufficient' mean in terms of each and every application. It will be a semi-judicial body. All the Opposition is suggesting is that on every occasion we will have in place a committee, whose members will have legal training or legal advice to make decisions of this nature. If the committee comprised a group of nurserymen I doubt that they would have legal qualifications.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the Bill, the Secretary will have that right. I believe the Secretary will be the right person to make that decision. I cannot see how we can use any other words. The words that have been referred to are commonly used in Acts of Parliament. Words such as 'reasonable' and 'significant' are used when a number cannot be put on things. They are the type of words which I think fit this Bill because of its diversity. I do not think for a minute that we could have a group of plant-oriented experts sitting in judgment on the question of what is 'reasonable'. There is certainly no one better than the Secretary to decide that question. If the Secretary were not able to make that decision it would be left to a court of the land, and basically what the Opposition is suggesting is the creation of a new court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to pick up the points raised by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). This amendment has the effect of saying that 13 heads may be better than one head in many cases. I mainly wanted to speak on some of the points made by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) but he has now left the chamber. It is obvious that he did not hear my comments earlier this afternoon when I spoke during the debate on the second reading of the Plant Variety Rights Bill. I referred to the various measures that the Opposition sees as essential before it can agree to this Bill. We still believe a need exists for a select committee to gather a lot more evidence on the public record. Even if a committee were not formed the Opposition would still insist on amending the Bill to put it in the form of decent plant variety rights legislation for Australia's agricultural producers. Of course, we would like to see Australian producers and horticulturalists gain access to new varieties. I said that in my speech on the second reading of the Bill. It is a pity that the honourable member for Wakefield did not listen to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should point out to the House that in terms of the substance of the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) one can argue the merits of his proposal against the merits of the advice I received from the Attorney-General's Department and reach a conclusion. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 3, page 3, lines 11 to 20, omit sub-clause (6), substitute the following sub-clauses:

'(6) Where, for the purposes of this Act, the Secretary or another person ( including a court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal) is required to be satisfied that a plant variety in respect of which an application has been made is a new plant variety, that person shall, for the purpose of deciding whether he is so satisfied, assume-

(a) that all the plant varieties whose existence was a matter of common knowledge when the variety was originated were constituted by, and constituted only by, the plant varieties that were in existence at the time when the application was made; and

(b) that the only plant varieties that were in existence at the time when the application was made were the plant varieties of the existence of which at that time that person is aware after making such enquiries, and consulting such publications readily available in Australia, as that person considers appropriate.
'(6A) A reference in this Act to a test growing of a plant variety is a reference to a test involving-

(a) the growing, or the production and growing, of plants, or of 2 or more generations of plants, of that variety at a place that is, and under conditions that are, appropriate for the growing of plants of that variety;
(b) the observation of the characteristics, and the condition, of the plants grown at the various stages in their growth; and
(c) the recording of those observations.'.

The amendment has been distributed with the Bill. It relates to common knowledge . Common knowledge is to be based on the time the application is made rather than the time the variety was developed-an important distinction when, for example, with fruit trees there may be a lengthy period between initial development and application. It also will permit a degree of latitude in the interpretation of common knowledge by relating it to sources of information readily available in Australia. The amendment also defines test growing, which will be required in the case of overseas varieties.

Clause 4 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 4A (Extent of Act).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) After clause 4, page 3, insert the following new clause in Part I:
Extent of Act

4A. Nothing in this Act requires or permits the grant of plant variety rights in respect of a new plant variety unless the origination of that new plant variety constituted an invention for the purposes of paragraph 51 (xviii) of the Constitution.

This amendment relates to the powers of the Parliament to grant plant variety rights deriving from paragraph 51 (xviii) of the Constitution, which authorises the making of laws in respect of, among other things, patent of inventions. Thus , if a new plant variety were bred and the development of that variety amounted to an invention, the Parliament would have power to give rights. Rights could not be granted for simple discoveries; for example, when there is no element of invention. I might add that most overseas PVR schemes are wider than this and, as far as I am aware, all allow the granting of a right for discovered varieties . The purpose of this clause is to make it quite clear that the Parliament intends to give rights only where it has the constitutional power to do so.
Proposed new clause agreed to.
Clause 5 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 5A (Advisory Committee).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 3, after clause 5 insert the following new clause:
Advisory Committee
'5A. (1) There shall be an Advisory Committee of 13 people appointed by the Minister.

(2) The Advisory Committee shall consist of representatives of Australian agriculturists, plant breeders, botanists and/or relevant academic disciplines, State Departments of Agriculture, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, consumers and environmentalists.
(3) The Advisory Committee will-

(a) advise the Minister on general policy matters, the selection of crops which warrant recommendation to the Australian Agricultural Council for inclusion in the scheme by amendment of the Act, in the formulation of regulations under the Act and will assist the Registrar and Secretary on any other appropriate policy matter or matter under dispute where seen to be appropriate by the Registrar or Secretary; and
(b) review and report to the Minister on international trends in plant breeders or plant variety rights systems.'.

This amendment seeks to insert a new clause, clause 5A. I referred to this matter when I moved my first amendment, which sought the establishment of an advisory committee in terms of the definitions in clause 3 of the Bill. What I am seeking to establish now is a sort of advisory committee of 13 people, which the Opposition thinks should be set up. I have set out the powers of that committee. As this proposition has already been rejected by the Government, there is no sense in putting it to a vote again. However, despite what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said in answer to us previously, I stress that the original Bill drafted in 1979 under the direction of the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, included the requirement that there be an advisory committee. I stress that nearly every industry organisation to which I have spoken sees the need for an advisory committee and the main proponents of the PVR scheme in Australia also see this need. Frankly, farmers, horticulturists and other such people want to be represented in some way on a committee giving advice to the Government on the continued running and administration of any plant variety rights system. Many of the plant breeding systems for the various industries already have advisory committees, whereby farmers-they pay levies in some cases, and in other cases they do not pay levies -and plant breeders have access to the Government, to universities or to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, or whoever is concerned with plant breeding. That is why we say that there should be an advisory committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to repeat the reasons given earlier, we believe that in the time that has elapsed since the Bill was first introduced by my predecessor-debate that has gone on since that time-there have been numerous discussions on this Bill at the Australian Agricultural Council. Register of Plant Variety Rights

One of the contentions of many people both opposed to and in favour of this Bill is that changes to the eventual Act should be by way of amendment to the Act rather than simply by way of regulation. The Opposition believes, as do the people who have lobbied us on this matter, that such an important Act of Parliament needs to have some review and that there need to be amendments to the Act to give Parliament a chance to review the continued working and administration of the Act and to make assessments on, for example, the recommendations of the Australian Agricultural Council particularly for the inclusion of the species.

The second amendment to clause 10 refers to the Australian Agricultural Council . The Opposition wishes simply to insert the requirement that any decision by the Agricultural Council with respect to the declaration of a genus or a species to which this legislation applies should be by a two-thirds majority of the Council. It has been put to us by many people that any agreement by the Australian Agricultural Council should be unanimous. There has been quite a deal of debate about the word 'unanimous' with respect to the Australian Agricultural Council. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) says that he has never used the word 'unanimous' with respect to the workings of the Agricultural Council and plant variety rights. Whether that is so or not, it is the clear recollection of many people that the whole question of plant variety rights would not have proceeded unless the Australian Agricultural Council had come to a unanimous decision. In particular, Mr Hallam, the New South Wales State Minister, has taken great exception to the fact that the Bill was held up, mainly because of objections by Western Australia's Country Party Minister, until the 8 February meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. At that time, the Western Australian Minister agreed I understand with some reservations , that the Plant Variety Rights Bill should go ahead. There was reference also to the inclusion of species by regulation. Again that is what I understand; I am not privy to the deliberations of the Australian Agricultural Council. Even so, putting these things to the side, the Opposition does not believe that to insert the word 'unanimous' is very constructive. Looking at the composition of the Agricultural Council, I do not think we will ever get a unanimous decision on some of these questions. We feel that a two-thirds majority covers that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). As I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage, the Plant Variety Rights Bill is very important for plant breeding and for the provision of foods for the Australian people. As the House of Representatives is a people's House it seems important that any amendments to the legislation should come before this place and not be subject just to regulation. With regard to the majority vote of the Australian Agricultural Council, one can see that with a simple majority quite a small minority of the Australian people, as represented by the majority of Ministers, could approve inclusion in the Act of certain plant variety rights. That seems to be quite improper. It is vital that the majority of Australian people be represented and agree to the inclusion of plant variety rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to support both the Opposition amendments . I am concerned that the Parliament was advised by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) that this legislation was introduced largely as a result of a recommendation from the Australian Agricultural Council. The Australian Agricultural Council is purely a ministerial consultative body. It established a working party which investigated plant variety rights. After the Bill was first introduced in May of last year I wrote to the Minister asking for details concerning, for example, the types of plant varieties which had been excluded from Australia, which had been denied to Australia, as a result of our not having PVR legislation. I am not suggesting for a moment that the paucity of detail in the response from the Minister reflected the information which was available to him or to his advisers, but it could well have suggested that that was the amount of information available to the Minister and to the Government in connection with legislation which they were introducing. However, the people in the Minister's Department have now provided a lot of useful information in the kit made available. The Bill was introduced originally, I think, on 7 May last year. It was not until Thursday or Friday of last week that this information kit containing that fairly comprehensive list of things that had been excluded, was made available to me. In the first place the legislation resulted from recommendations from the Australian Agricultural Council. But that is not all of the picture. I contacted the Australian Agricultural Council and asked whether I could have a copy of the report of the working party. That was the body set up to investigate the proposal and make recommendations to the Minister. On the basis of those recommendations the Minister had legislation prepared, which subsequently was brought to the Parliament. As a parliamentary representative I was expected then, as I still am, to make my position clear by the way in which I vote-on the basis of a report, from a working party of a ministerial consultative committee, which has been denied me. That is not good enough by far . Our suggestion is that changes be made not by regulation but by amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second amendment proposes that the response of the Australian Agricultural Council should be expressed by way of a two-thirds majority. Under the Bill no requirement is imposed, by either the Government or the Parliament, on the Australian Agricultural Council concerning the way in which it shall arrive at the decision or recommendation that it is to bring forward. Apparently the Council is to have authority to determine the way in which its decision will be made. The Council could well decide that a unanimous vote would be necessary. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has already indicated how impractical that would be. Alternatively, the Council could decide that a two- thirds majority, or even a simple majority, would be required. However, when a ministerial consultative body is given powers and responsibilities in connection with legislation that members of this Parliament are expected to support, the Parliament itself should have greater input. Parliament should indicate to the Council, by way of the second of the amendments, that a two-thirds majority shall be required-not leave it to the council to decide. Certainly, any changes made should be by way of amendment to this legislation, so that we may consider them. There has already been too much of the kind of situation in which honourable members are expected to make decisions, as I have already indicated, on the basis of a report of a working party which is denied them on the ground that it is confidential. That should not be accepted by any member of this Parliament. It represents an inexcusable and intolerable situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the point made by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), I am sorry that I am not able to make available to him the working papers of the Australian Agricultural Council, which consists of but one Commonwealth Minister and all of the State Ministers responsible for agriculture. They are masters of all they survey, just as I am master of all I survey, and they do not take the view that the working papers they use in coming to a conclusion should be distributed- rather, that they should be held by the Council itself. There is nothing that I can do about that. I can only ask the honourable member for Hunter to have regard for the Bill itself and the position that the Council has reached in respect of its clauses. I ask the honourable member to try to accept the Bill on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot accept the two amendments that have been proposed. If it did it would be necessary to return to the Parliament whenever a change was accepted by the Agricultural Council. This legislation is really a creature of the States. We are but the vehicle for its passage. It will be used by the State governments and their departments of agriculture. I do not believe that the State Ministers would take lightly, having made a decision on a matter in accordance with what they believe to be their sovereign right, this Parliament's sitting over them with a shotgun. They would view that approach with concern. Therefore, on behalf of my State colleagues, I cannot accept the first amendment .

As to the second, which suggests that a two-thirds majority of the Council should be necessary in deciding these matters, with great respect I do not believe that it is appropriate for this Parliament to tell the Council how to run its business. Our imposing here, centrally, a requirement that there be a two-thirds majority would be received with great alarm by State Ministers of Agriculture. Therefore, I would have to reject that proposition also. If the Council decides to accept it, it is open to the Council to do so.

I turn now to the question of unanimity that has been raised by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin). I have never used the word 'unanimous', and in that proposition I believe I am supported by all of the State Ministers except the New South Wales Minister, who continues to claim that I used it. It is true that I delayed the Bill on one occasion, but I did so not because I was seeking unanimous acceptance of it, rather as part of the process of discussion and consideration. At a number of Agricultural Council meetings I have delayed progress on the Bill to accede to the requirements of several State Ministers, expressed in their own way. I tried to meet their requests and requirements before presenting the Bill to the Parliament. I regret that the Government cannot accept the two proposed amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Kerin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 10, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 11 (Plant variety rights not to be granted in respect of varieties previously sold).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 11, page 5, lines 12 to 22, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

'11. Where an application is made for plant variety rights in respect of a plant variety, those rights shall not be granted if there has been a sale of a plant, or reproductive material of a plant, of that variety by, or with the consent of, the breeder or a breeder, or a successor of the breeder or of a breeder, of the variety, and-
(a) the sale took place in Australia before the making of the application; or

(b) where the application is made later than 2 years after the relevant genus or species was declared by the regulations to be a genus or species to which this Act applies, the sale took place in another country earlier than-
(i) in the case of any variety of grape-vine, forest tree, fruit tree or ornamental tree-6 years; or
(ii) in any other case-4 years,
before the making of the application.

It is a requirement that a variety from overseas shall not have been on the market for more than a specified period prior to its registration in Australia. There are many valuable overseas varieties which are required now but which could be ineligible by the time the species is included in the Australian scheme . To permit these varieties to be registered, a two-year holiday from the time restriction is proposed in amendment No. 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should inform the Committee that the Opposition proposes to move amendments to the clause which the Government is now seeking to substitute. The procedure that the Chair will adopt is to put the Government's amendment first and then deal with the Opposition's proposed amendments. The question is: That the clause proposed to be omitted stand part of the Bill.
—The question now is: That the clause proposed to be inserted be so inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 11, paragraph (b), omit 'the regulations', substitute 'an amendment of this Act'.
(12) Clause 11, sub-paragraph (b) (i), omit '6', substitute '10'.
Amendment No. 11 seeks to omit the words 'the regulations'. As the Committee has already voted on that matter, I will not say any more. There is no sense in going through the same argument.

In respect of Opposition amendment No. 12, orchardists have been very vocal in their opposition to the six-year requirement and the Opposition is proposing a 10-year period. We think it is unrealistic to exclude from registration certain types of fruit trees, forest trees and ornamental trees which have been available commercially in another country for a period greater than six years. Many types of fruit trees require from seven to 10 years to reach the stage of commercial cropping so as to assess their potential value. A similar situation exists with most forest species and certain ornamentals. Accordingly, it is considered that the period of six years specified in the Bill for prior growth in another country should be extended to 10 years. The period of four years which is specified for other crops is probably adequate for commercial evaluation. I think I have made my point clear. It takes at least six years for the value of a fruit tree to be assessed. If this substitute clause is left as it is Australian growers will have to arrange for every variety that is covered by plant protection overseas to be imported into Australia so that they do not miss the one-in-50 chance of an outstanding variety. I think this will place an intolerable strain on our method of handling this influx, given our quarantine arrangements. If a plant variety from another country is not subject to a plant protection Act overseas then that variety should not be allowed to be protected in Australia. I have already covered this point as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should explain to the Committee that the Government has moved an amendment which is still under consideration. The honourable member for Werriwa has moved two amendments to the substitute clause that I think in some ways run counter to the Government's amendment. We have reached the stage at which there are amendments upon an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) who, in support of his proposal to extend the six-year period to 10 years , talked about the possible need for Australian orchardists to have to import stock even before it has been evaluated, I would just make the comment that I think Australian orchardists, agricultural departments and research institutes would want to import material as quickly as they can in any event to ensure that they have the genetic material available to work on in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: But I want to say some things more generally about the view that many small orchardists and growers in Australia have about the need to obtain material from overseas. One of the arguments that has frequently been put against plant variety rights legislation is that it supposedly plays into the hands of the large multinationals and will lead to a concentration of power in the agricultural industry. The point I want to make is that many of the small growers and small associations strongly urge the introduction of plant variety rights legislation so that they can have access to material from overseas. I want to quote some remarks of a few growers from around my area-the outer eastern region of Melbourne-who have put views on this subject. Mr Bill Aumann presented a paper at the Orchardists and Fruit Cool Stores Association of Victoria symposium in November 1979. Mr Aumann is an orchardist in my area. He made the point that overseas research stations and private plant breeders are nearly all patenting their new releases and will not supply these to Australia until legislation protecting their propagation rights is introduced. It is interesting that he said:
New Zealand growers placed nectarines on the Melbourne and Sydney markets this year.
That is, 1979-

These were superior patented varieties that are not available in Australia at the moment and if the Australian growers wish to retain and expand their markets , then the sooner they can grow these improved varieties the better.
He went on to say:

If the Australian grower is denied the opportunity to grow improved fruit varieties, the temptation to smuggle these varieties into the country (it has happened before) becomes very great and then we have the problem of no quarantine and the associated risk of bringing into this country diseases we definitely don't want, such as fire blight, Western-X, Plum pox, etc.

The point he made relates to something that was debated on an earlier clause- that is, the desirability or otherwise of merit testing. Mr Aumann made the point very clearly that the market is giving very accurate and very rapid information on which varieties are desirable in Australia and the extent to which Australian growers are slipping behind. I wish to quote the comments of two other gentlemen from the Victorian Cherry Association and the Silvan and District Growers Association, Mr D. M. Moon and Mr W. S. Barker. Those two associations operate basically in my electorate and the electorate of La Trobe. They represent a wide variety of small growers. In a joint letter Mr Moon and Mr Barker stated:
There have of course been improved varieties developed with public funds in Australia but naturally enough these tend to be high-value crops such as cereals .
Our initial concern is basically with deciduous fruit trees which are vegetatively propagated species and protected by PVR just as seed crops are.
In a letter to some local newspapers they made some comments about the work of the Victorian Department of Agriculture. They went on to state:

However, on the whole, the only overseas varieties available are those not protected by PVR or where the patent has run out. This, coupled with rigorous quarantine procedures and local field evaluation of varieties, although essential, results in long delays between release overseas and availability here .

For example, dessert peach varieties recently released here have been available for at least 10 years in the USA and in that country have largely been superseded by improved varieties. For the past two years, we have been competing in the market with top quality American varieties of nectarines grown in New Zealand under that country's PVR scheme but still unavailable to us.

The further body I want to quote is the Eastern Metropolitan Fruitgrowers Association. This body has also expressed a view on this subject in a letter to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). A copy was sent to me. In July 1980 the Association said:

As stated in the enclosed submission, we are of the opinion that the necessary legislation to introduce PVR to the Australian agricultural scene is long overdue and that it is now time to align ourselves with most of the other countries of the world who have this type of legislation and can take advantage of it by an interchange of varieties between countries subject to the necessary quarantine restrictions.
We believe that in this country, we are going to be left behind as far as an upgrading of fruit varieties is concerned, unless we have the PVR legislation introduced.

I believe that indicates that growers are very keen to gain access to genetic material from overseas as quickly as possible. They and their growers association will waste no time in ensuring that they import any material from overseas that looks even vaguely interesting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess the matter raised by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) amounts to a matter of judgment. The first thing to remember is that two years have to elapse before the six-year term applies. That would be a total of eight years as against the period which he was suggesting of ten years. It is really a matter of judgment as to which is the better. The advice we have-it seems to be accepted generally- is that the length of time which I am proposing is satisfactory. Therefore, I would have to reject the Opposition's amendment to my amendment. The other Opposition amendment which relates to the matter coming back to the Parliament to be altered by Act of Parliament instead of by regulation was dealt with earlier. I would not wish to press on the Australian Agricultural Council the necessity for the legislation to come back to the Federal Parliament when in its wisdom it believed that any species ought to be accepted. I have to reject that amendment also.

Proposed new clause agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20) Clause 18, page 9, at the end of the clause add the following sub-clause:
'(2) All applications shall be available in each State Department of Agriculture and the relevant offices in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory within 21 days of lodgement.'.

This amendment also relates to an earlier requirement that the Opposition asked for earlier, namely that applications be available in each State department of agriculture and the relevant offices. We believe that in terms of registers of varieties, and in terms of this clause, applications should be readily available to those people who are applying for plant rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For reasons given earlier, the Government does not accept the amendment. We believe that information will be readily available to State offices from State offices of the Federal Department of Primary Industry. This would simply be a duplication.

Clause 19 agreed to.
Proposed new clause 19A (Characteristics of plant varieties originated outside Australia).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13A) Characteristics of plant varieties originated outside Australia

'19A. For the purposes of this Act, where a plant variety in respect of which an application has been made was originated outside Australia, the variety shall not be taken to have a particular characteristic unless-
(a) a test growing of the variety carried out in Australia has demonstrated that the variety has that characteristic;
(b) the Secretary is satisfied that-
(i) a test growing of the variety carried out at a place outside Australia has demonstrated that the variety has that characteristic; and
(ii) the test growing of the variety carried out at that place is equivalent to a test growing of the variety carried out in Australia; or
(c) the Secretary is satisfied that-
(i) a test growing of the variety carried out outside Australia has demonstrated that the variety has that characteristic;
(ii) any test growing of that variety carried out in Australia would probably demonstrate that the variety has that characteristic; and

(iii) if there were to be carried out in Australia a test growing of the variety that would be sufficient to demonstrate whether the variety has that characteristic, that test growing would take longer than 2 years.

Before granting a right to a variety, the registrar must be satisfied that it is distinct, uniform and stable. It is possible that varieties developed overseas may display new or different characteristics when grown in Australia where soil and climate may vary significantly from the country of origin. Thus the overseas description of that variety may not necessarily be accurate when the variety is grown in Australia. Essentially, this amendment requires overseas varieties to be test grown in Australia. Two exceptions are proposed. The first is where the description is prepared at a place which has conditions similar to Australia. For example, a New Zealand variety of rye grass which is likely to be grown in south-eastern Australia might well be covered by this exemption. A further exemption to the requirement to test grow in Australia will apply when testing would take longer than two years. This would allow registration of valuable fruit trees or grape varieties which might otherwise be delayed by long periods of test growing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Clause 19A, omit 'a particular characteristic unless', substitute ' particular characteristics with respect to commercial, environmental and nutritional attributes unless'.
(22) Clause 19A, paragraph (a), after 'variety' (first occurring) insert 'at cost to the applicant'.
(23) Clause 19A, paragraph (a), omit 'that characteristic', substitute 'these characteristics'.
(24) Clause 19A, omit paragraphs (b) and (c).

These amendmends relate to the requirement by the Opposition to have particular characteristics. The word 'characteristics' appears often. Again, it relates back to merit testing, so there is no sense in going through those arguments. We would like some guidance from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) with respect to his proposed new clause 19A. Are these tests or further tests to be conducted at the cost of the applicant? It is our belief that 'at cost to the applicant' should appear in the Bill to put this matter beyond any contention. The Opposition would welcome the view of the Minister on this point. I do not know whether I should go through the arguments again with respect to the definition of characteristics which we see as being necessary in this clause. However, the Opposition seeks some assurance from the Minister, particularly with respect to the cost to the applicant for these further tests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, it is at the cost of the applicant. That is taken up in clause 45 (c), which we will reach shortly. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has moved amendments Nos. 21, 22, 23 and 24. To add confusion to the matter, the Government is prepared to accept one of the amendments but not the other three. Therefore we need to be very careful in our treatment of those amendments that are accepted and those that are not. The Government has to reject amendment No. 21 as proposed by the honourable member for Werriwa, because it is part of the inclusion of merit as part of the description of the new plant variety. The criteria for new plant variety are distinctiveness, uniformity and stability. The merit will be determined in the market-place. We have heard the arguments before and the Government rejects that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I can either accept Opposition amendment No. 22 or amend clause 45 (c) as was proposed in the list distributed earlier. In the interests of uniformity for passing the legislation I had better reject the honourable member's amendment and accept my later one. We can say no to the four amendments rather than confuse the Committee. Amendment No. 23 is again consequent on amendment No. 21. It relates to merit and therefore I must reject it. We have to reject amendment No. 24 for the following reason. Omitting the Secretary's discretion to waive test growing of overseas varieties places considerable strain on bringing in fruit trees because testing would take too long and could create unnecessary work for known varieties such as one from New Zealand.
