In order to meet the wishes expressed earlier by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) in relation to costs I have moved amendment No. 28-it has not been circulated-which deals with clause 45 (c). Referring to amendment No. 20, clause 32 states that a grantee is able to licence another person to sell or produce a protected variety. Clause 32, however, would allow the grantee to set whatever terms and conditions he saw fit on the licence. This could result in a conflict with the Trade Practices Act. I am proposing that this clause be deleted.

As regards amendment No. 21, if a grantee takes legal action against a person for an infringement of his plant variety right, that person, the defendant, may make a counter-claim and seek revocation of the right. Clause 35 (2) gives authority for such a counter-claim to be made. The amendment clarifies the grounds on which the claim can be made and gives the court authority to revoke the rights. Amendment No. 22 proposes that the new clause be inserted to make it quite clear that agents, be they solicitors, patent attorneys or private citizens, are free to act on behalf of others in regard to this legislation.

Amendment No. 23 is another procedural amendment which outlines the mailing procedures to be followed whenever the Secretary or the Registrar is required to forward a document to an applicant or grantee. Documents are to be sent by pre- paid post to the address supplied by the person concerned. As regards amendment No. (24), the aim with regard to funding is that eventually income from fees will meet the cost of the scheme. In the interim, costs are not expected to be great. The Government has agreed to accept total responsibility for funding until such time as the scheme becomes self-supporting. Accordingly, I am proposing that clause 42 be deleted.

I turn to amendment No. 25. To bring this legislation into line with other similar Commonwealth legislation it is proposed to increase the penalty for false representation from $500, as currently specified in clause 43, to $1,000 or six months imprisonment. As regards amendments Nos. 26 and 27, clause 44 provides for applications to be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of decisions on a number of matters, such as the granting, rejection or revocation of rights. Amendment No. 26 adds to the list of appealable matters decisions by the Secretary under subsection 20 (1) concerning test growing. Amendment No. 27 adds to the list of appealable matters decisions by the Minister under subsection 20 (1) concerning conditions on the granting of rights made in the public interest.

The final amendment relates to the question of costs, as raised by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), which was also a matter of concern to my honourable friend the member for Hunter. It is an amendment to clause 45. This amendment has not been circulated. It meets the requests of the honourable member and the concern expressed earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Minister made this matter clear earlier in the discussion. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) wanted this question put beyond any doubt. Consequently, the Opposition welcomes the proposal. With respect to amendment No.24, we agree to the Government accepting the funding. As the Minister has explained, the Commonwealth is acting as the vehicle for the States with respect to this legislation. In its initial stages, if the scheme is to work and if it is to be paid for in the way in which the Government has proposed, it is logical for the Government to accept funding.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to amendment No. 25, on an earlier occasion I said that the penalties in the Bill were laughable. I guess that we can now say that they are half laughable. It depends how badly one feels about six months in gaol. The Government will be aware that with respect to the meat substitution scandal the penalties were seen to be inadequate, with hindsight. Acts of parliament incorporate fines or penalties which, at the time, are reasonably appropriate. As the years go by, it is subsequently seen that they are not appropriate. The Opposition agrees to a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for six months, because potentially, if this legislation really works in the way that the Government thinks it will work-the Opposition has great doubts-there will be big money to be made. We have already said that we are apprehensive about what may happen with respect to litigation with small plant breeders taking on multinational plant breeders. We believe that clause 25 should be kept under consideration by the Australian Agricultural Council, or whoever it may be, because it may quickly prove to be quite inadequate.
Amendments agreed to.
Remainder of Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telegrams from Australia to the United States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What is the estimated volume of telegrams (i.e. exclusive of telex or on- line data systems) sent from Australia to the United States of America each year .

2. How are these telegrams transmitted to the U.S.A.; is it from a single outlet, for example, Australia, through Sydney, to a single point of entry in the U.S.A. or is it done directly from city to city (e.g. Perth to Miami).
3. Are telegrams transmitted by cable, by radio, or by a combination of media; if so, what are the details.
4. Who handles the telegrams at the U.S.A. end, and at what point do they accept responsibility (e.g. after the message is received at a central terminal, or before).
5. What sum is paid each year to the relevant U.S. authority for delivering telegrams originating in Australia.
6. What proportion of telegrams sent from Australia to the U.S.A. are not delivered.
7. How many complaints about non-delivery of telegrams in the U.S.A. are received by Telecom or Telepost.
8. In respect of complaints about non-delivery of telegrams, what action is taken to refund the sum paid by the sender and to recover moneys from the relevant U.S. authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. In the calendar year 1981, 192,942 telegrams were sent from Australia to the U.S.A.

2. International telegrams are passed through the Overseas Telecommunications Commission's Message Relay Centre, located in Paddington, Sydney, which has connections to OTC receiving offices in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, Telecom telegraph offices and Post Offices throughout Australia. Telegrams for the U.S.A . are directed through the OTC Message Relay Centre to four corresponding Message Relay Centres in the U.S.A.-three in New York City and one in Fort Lauderdale, Florida.
3. OTC operates services to the United States via both satellite and submaring cable systems. In the case of telegrams, about half of the traffic is directed through each of these two media.
4. The following four competing international telegram carriers in that country , with each of whom OTC(A) has operating arrangements:
RCA Globcom;
ITT Worldcommunications Inc.;
Western Union International Inc.*; and
TRT Telecommunications;
They have different delivery arrangements with a number of competing domestic carriers. Most traffic is delivered by the Western Union Telegraph Company (WUTC ) and Graphnet Inc.
Responsibility for delivery is accepted by the relevant U.S. international carrier when a message is delivered to its Message Relay Centre.
(*No connection corporately with Western Union Telegraph Company)

5. A revenue share of $US864,366 was paid in 1981 to the US international carriers for Australian originated telegram traffic. A share of this revenue would be paid, in turn, to the U.S. domestic carriers for delivery of these telegrams.

6 and 7. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) received 493 complaints of non-delivery of telegrams to the U.S.A. in 1981. On investigation it was found that 145 of these telegrams had been delivered without error. Non- delivery or late delivery occurred, in the U.S.A., in respect of 348 cases or 0. 18 per cent of all telegrams from Australia.

OTC has formally expressed its concern at this standard of service to each of its corresponding U.S. carriers during recent months, and undertakings have been given by each of these companies to endeavour to improve delivery standards.

8. Arrangements between OTC(A) and U.S. international carriers for the handling of telegram traffic are as prescribed in the recommendations of the International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee (CCITT) of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU).

Where error of service is determined, the charges are refunded in full to the Australian originator. Where appropriate, the cost of these charges is recovered from the relevant U.S. carrier in accordance with the above CCITT recommendations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Equipment Purchased Through United States Foreign Military Sales

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When equipment is purchased by a series of progress payments through United States Foreign Military Sales is interest payable on the total price of any purchase, if so:

(b) what was the interest rate, on average, for (i) 1979-80; (ii) 1980-81; and (iii) 1981-82.
(2) Does the interest rate vary over the life of the purchase; if so, for what reason and by what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Australia does not pay interest on its purchases under United States Foreign Military Sales arrangements as the progress payments required are designed to fully cover in advance, contractor and other US Government commitments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February, 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to evidence given before the Defence sub- committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in the inquiry into Defence procurement where Hose Australia Pty Ltd claimed it was excluded from contracting for the supply of fire hose for the RAAF by contract specifications that could be met only by a single overseas company.
(2) Were these specifications changed so that competitive tenders including those from Australian companies could be received.

(3) Have potential suppliers complained that the new specifications are cumbersome and riddled with procedural red tape; if not, why has his Department been unable to assess tenders in the 7 months since the most recent tender applications for this type of equipment closed.

(4) Were tenderers asked to take into account in their costings the fact that the tender specifications were so complicated that his Department might be unable to make a decision within a reasonable period after receipt of tenders.
(5) Will he examine the new specifications and request his Department to adjust them to make them acceptable to normal commercial practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was made aware of the essence of the submission by Hose Makers Australia Pty Ltd and approved the subsequent response to the Sub-Committee by my Department.

(2) The specification for hose used in operational applications was revised in Oct 80 to reflect the hose performance required by the Services and the tests by which conformance of their products can be demonstrated by any potential supplier.

Their comments were taken into consideration in revising the specification. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek Highway

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that the Highway between Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek, Western Australia has been out for three weeks and is still unusable, and to the hardship this entails for communities isolated without fresh food, vegetables and other supplies.
(2) Is he able to say what implications an untenable road system holds for defence and security not only for the Kimberley but for Australia.
(3) What funds have been made available to complete the sealing of this highway and when is work likely to be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. As a result of the above-average rainfalls in the area, the Perth- Darwin National Highway between Fitzroy Crossing and Halls Creek was closed to traffic from 26 January to 4 February. It was again closed from 9 February, although the road has now been conditionally opened to traffic with a mass gross weight up to 3 tonnes. The Western Australian Government has been airfreighting perishable foodstuffs and emergency supplies to communities isolated by the flooding.

(2) This section of road is currently below the National Highway standards. Construction of these standards which have been set taking into account the needs of all traffic will satisfy the needs of defence.

(3) The 1981-82 National Roads program which I approved for Western Australia last year included $6.4m expenditure for projects to make a major start on the road. The projects involve the construction and sealing of 91.7 kilometres of road and bridges over the Mary and Laura Rivers.
These works and future works are expected to reduce road closures due to flooding to a minimum and also improve the serviceability of the road for defence purposes.

The intention is to complete the sealing of both the Fitzroy Crossing-Halls Creek and Newman-Port Hedland sections of the National Highway by mid-1988. However, the achievement of this target will depend on the future level of National Road grants and the priority of works required on other National Highways.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Toxic Spray at Royal Australian Air Force Base Fairbairn, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has a toxic spray recently been used on the RAAF base Fairbairn, Australian Capital Territory: if so, (a) what was the name of the spray and for what purpose was it used, (b) what areas of the base were sprayed, (c) did some birds die after contact with the areas sprayed, (d) were those who work and/or live on the base notified that spraying was to occur and (e) have any persons reported any illness or medical symptoms which have been associated with the spraying.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Recently, there was a problem at RAAF Base Fairbairn brought about by birds perching in the aircraft hangars. The bird droppings on the concrete floors constituted a safety hazard to the personnel working in the hangars. To overcome the problem, a contractor used a chemical called Endrin, which was mixed with grease and applied with rollers to the rafters and other fixtures in the hangars . No toxic spray was used.

Endrin has a chloroform type effect on birds if ingested in sufficient quantity through their feet. Normally, however, the mixture irritates birds causing them to fly away before this stage is reached. Notwithstanding, some birds were found dead shortly after the treatment program commenced. This is thought to have occurred when small birds came into contact with a stronger mixture intended for larger birds.

All Service personnel working in the hangars were aware of the treatment program to discourage the birds' presence in the hangars. Moreover, no persons have reported to the Base Medical Flight with any apparent illness or symptoms which could be associated with the Endrin bird treatment program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 March 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he undertaken to control the incidence of direct selling campaigns using the telephones; if not will he be initiating any future action towards this end;
(2) How is it possible for such a sales company to have an unlisted number on their listing of numbers to be rung;
(3) Will he take action to see that unlisted numbers cannot be rung by selling companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. I might explain that Telecom is not a direct participant in telephone selling and canvassing. However, the question of direct selling campaigns is being considered by the Australian Law Reform Commission currently. It has issued a discussion paper on 'Privacy and Intrusions'.

(2) One means could be for the selling organisation to select an exchange prefix and then sequentially dial numbers within that prefix. Alternatively, numbers could be selected at random and some of them could well be unlisted numbers.

(3) No. There is no way technically for Telecom to prevent certain calls being made to silent line services. In view of the current deliberations of the Law Commission, any Legislative action designed to prevent such calls would appear to be an initiative that would emerge from the considerations of that body.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Report on Toxic Chemicals Used in Vietnam

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that the Minister has now tabled the 56 page 3rd and final draft of the Fleming Report, and in doing so stated that the ownership of the report is vested in Mr John Evans, a Scientific Adviser to the Vietnam Veterans Association in Australia, will the Minister now state what contribution to the report was made by (a) Dr Keith Fleming, (b) Dr Emile Rousseaux, and (c) any other person.

(2) In view of the Minister's statement that Dr Keith Fleming left the Department of Veterans' Affairs of his own volition, will the Minister now state (a) on what date did Dr Fleming cease duty as Chief Director, Medical Services, in his Department, (b) what was the last day of duty of Dr Fleming in his Department, (c) on what date did Dr Fleming take up his duties as Secretary for Health in the Northern Territory and (d) has Dr Fleming been on any form of secondment from the Department of Veterans' Affairs at any time since he left the position of Chief Director, Medical Services, Department of Veterans' Affairs to the date of preparation of the answer to this question, if so, what are the details.
(3) Can the Minister say what salary Dr Fleming is now receiving, and what his salary was at the time of leaving the Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As far as can be ascertained from the files, the circumstances leading to the preparation of the paper referred to, which, as will become evident, is not really 'the Fleming Report', were as follows.

In March 1980, after assertions had been made that material supporting claims by Vietnam veterans was not being taken into account, the then Secretary of the Department of Veteran's Affairs contacted the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Action Association inviting him to submit any scientific references or other material relating to Vietnam veterans and certain chemicals. The National President suggested that the information could be obtained from the scientific adviser to the Association, Mr John Evans.
As the information was not in a form which could be simply handed over, the Secretary arranged for Dr Fleming to visit Mr Evans to obtain the material.

Dr Fleming, with his administrative assistant, visited Mr Evans three times in 1980. during these visits Mr Evans indicated to Dr Fleming the sections of specific published articles which he considered to be relevant, occasionally offering personal observations.

Dr Fleming obtained copies of the nominated references. He collated verbatim extracts from these references including the personal observations of Mr Evans. Some of the references given by Mr Evans were not included, following discussions between them.

Dr Fleming's efforts were directed to assembling the material as a coherent paper. So far as is known, he made no contribution to the substance or content of the paper except in so far as the discussions between them helped to develop the presentation of Mr Evans' views. Dr Fleming's first collation was submitted to Mr Evans and discussed with him to see whether it correctly reflected the argument presented by Mr Evans. Mr Evans' suggested amendments led to the preparation of a second draft (of 82 pages double-spaced typing). Further discussion led to amendments and inclusions resulting in a third draft (of 56 pages single-spaced) which was not referred to Mr Evans. Work on the drafts ceased in August 1980.
In summary, Mr Evans provided information for assembling collation of references into connected argument and Dr Fleming provided the resources to put this argument on paper.

Dr G. E. Rousseaux wrote to the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 24 June 1980 drawing attention to published articles by Joseph T. Morgan and Theron G. Randolph. These were referred to the Department. Dr Fleming brought them to Mr Evans' notice, as they appeared to cover a specific matter better than the references Mr Evans had. They were discussed and included in the paper.
While Dr Fleming's staff provided clerical and stenographic assistance in the collation of the material, so far as is known no other person contributed to the substance or content of the paper.
(2) (a) 29 May 1981. (b) 29 May 1981. (c) I understand this was on 1 June 1981. (d) No.
(3) I am not aware of the salary Dr Fleming is presently receiving. At the time of leaving the Department of Veterans' Affairs his salary was $48,043 per annum.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Report on Toxic Chemicals Used in Vietnam

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports in the Australian on 8 and 9 March 1982 regarding the 56 page third and final draft of the Fleming Report on the potential effects of toxic chemicals used in Vietnam.

(2) Did Mr E. D. Letts, the First Assistant Secretary in charge of the Vietnam Special Studies Group in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, tell the Senate Science and Environment Committee at a hearing in Melbourne on 4 February 1982 that he had never seen anything other than a report of 80 odd pages.

(3) Can the Minister say whether Mr Letts was personally given a copy of the 56 page report by Dr Keith Fleming while Dr Fleming occupied the position of Chief Director, Medical Services, in the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
(4) Did the Minister's former Permanent Head, Sir Richard Kingsland, order the recall of the 56 page report following an appraisal of that report by the Department of Health.
(5) Will the Minister now provide the Parliament with the Department of Health' s critique, and any other Department's comments on the report; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister also undertake to circulate the 56 page report to all medical officers who are treating Vietnam veterans; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to these reports. As is indicated in the answer to Question No. 4188, the document in question is not a Fleming Report but is a compilation, made with Dr Fleming's assistance, of extracts from articles and references mainly emanating from Mr John Evans.
(2) Yes.
(3) Dr Fleming states that he cannot remember whether or not he gave Mr Letts a copy of the 56 page third draft. Mr Letts confirms that Dr Fleming did not give him a copy.

(4) No. At the time there was no circulation of the 56 pages of material outside the Department, except to the Department of Health as mentioned below. The previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs gave details of the background to the preparation of the material in a News Release, dated 30 September 1980. Certain senior officers of the Department's Central Office staff received copies and the Department of Health was asked to comment on the document.
(5) The Department of Health provided the following comments on the second draft:

This document consists of a long series of abstracts selectively cited from a variety of sources. They are assembled in such a way as to imply that veterans of the Vietnamese War were heavily exposed to a range of pesticidal agents which have serious acute and chronic toxic effects. Interspersed are comments which cleverly link the arguments. The uninformed reader could be led to believe that the interpretations drawn and implied are correct but this is not always so.

The title of the document is misleading since it in no way presents an unbiased assessment of potential toxicity of chemicals used in Vietnam, nor does it accurately demonstrate the potential for exposure of personnel who served during the hostilities in that country.

The references are in many cases out of date and have been superseded by more recent work which is largely ignored. Some are drawn from lay publications which have questionable scientific merit. For example, the author attributes the many known toxic effects of inorganic arsenic compounds to cacodylic acid-an organic arsenical-used in ''Agent Blue''. The key ''links'' between these two types of compound are in paragraphs 51 and 54 but neither is supported by review of the recent literature. Indeed the Merck Index reference, in paragraph 51 refers to work published in 1760 and 1927. Yet, recent work which shows that cacodylic acid has significantly different toxicological properties from inorganic arsenic compounds has been ignored.

Critical arguments often rest upon poorly supported documentation, anonymous references and the frequently used personal observation. Where an argument is not sustained by scientific work, it is filled by speculation which tends to lead the argument in a direction which has been predetermined by the writer. For example, in paragraph 56, suggestions based upon unsubstantiated observations of lay forest workers in Oregon are used to imply that toxic arsine gas was formed after Agent Blue was used in Vietnam. The document then discusses some of the known toxic effects of arsine gas implying, but not stating, that Vietnam veterans would have been exposed to arsine.

Facts are often misrepresented. This is illustrated by paragraph 72 which cites a 1960 publication. Its sensational title ''Cacodylates infrequently used today' ' belies the content of preceding paragraphs 62-71 which are extracts expounding the dangers of exposure to cacodylic acid. Similar examples abound and suggest that attempts are being made to confuse or misrepresent the literature.

Selective citation of references is used to suit some of the arguments. When discussing 2,4-D (paragraph 167) p. 127 of the I.A.R.C. publication ''Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man'' vol. 15 is cited. Subsequently this same document is ignored when discussing ''2,4-D and peripheral neuritis'' (paragraph 174). On the same page in discussion of this very topic the I.A.R.C. document states that by 1977 only three cases of peripheral neuropathy following spraying of 2,4-D had been reported.

The toxicological and medical content of the document is poor. Many of the interpretations reached are neither supported nor justified. Unwarranted accent is placed throughout on single cases which have been reported in the literature. This tends to give undue prominence to rare occurrences and consequently places in an unduly bad light certain chemicals which would normally be accepted as being of low toxicity when used according to recommendations. Undue susceptibility of individuals is stressed and tends to nullify the stringent precautions which are taken in respect of those chemicals with the aim of protecting even the most susceptible in our community. Signs and symptoms which could result from overexposure are described at length. Common and rare complications tend to be given equal prominence.

Although time has not permitted a detailed analysis and consideration of all of the arguments presented in this document, it is clear that it is a biased compilation of material which exaggerates the potential toxicity of those agricultural chemicals mentioned. If it were to be circulated as a Government document, it could be used to assail the credibility of those who work to design and enforce the necessary precautions for the responsible usage of such chemicals in agriculture.

Furthermore, this document is a clever presentation of facts, arguments and opinions which might be used to support complaints of a group of individuals who allege that they were suffering from a wide diversity of adverse effects as a result of exposure to such chemicals. Although I have been critical of the document in its style I must add that much effort has been devoted to its production and there is valuable information contained in it. It should be retained to alert those who may be required to produce defence material against such arguments which could be presented on behalf of a plaintiff. On no account should it be used as an information item since it is essential that a document used for widespread distribution should be totally unbiased.
The Department of Health also provided comments on the Agent Blue section of the third draft. These are quoted in full at the end of this answer.

In view of the Department of Health's comments it was considered essential to seek further authoritative balanced advice and the Department of Health prepared a series of information papers on pesticides used in Vietnam. Those produced so far deal with cacodylic acid, the bipyridyliums (diquat and paraquat), malathion and dieldrin. The first two, on herbicides, have been given to the Senate Standing Commitee on Science and the Environment. The other two, on insecticides , are available if and when the Committee requires them. The 56 page draft was not provided to any Department, other than the Department of Health, for comment .

(6) There are about 10,000 local medical officers who could provide treatment to Vietnam veterans. Such circulation has been considered unnecessary. Local medical officers have been advised by a newsletter of the medical officers who are the contact points in each State Branch of the Department of Veterans' Affairs for information on matter concerned with herbicides and Vietnam veterans .

To enable the contact medical officers to deal with claims based on alleged exposure to herbicides, a vast amount of information has been supplied. They have the Departmental bibliography which lists some 781 papers on chemicals used in Vietnam. The 56 page third draft referred to in the question cites 76 separate articles, works, etc., in some 134 footnotes; all but two were included in the bibliography. The omission of one apparently was an oversight, since remedied, and one was unable to be found. With the exception of the article just referred to, all but 4 of the 76 articles were sent to the contact medical officers in January 1981. The reason for the omission to send the 4 articles at the time is not known, but all 4 have been sent since. In addition, the contact medical officers have received copies of the Department of Health papers mentioned above and the report entitled 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study.'
The 56 pages of material have been sent to the contact departmental medical officers following their tabling in the Senate.
The Department of Health comments referred to in the answer to part (5) are as follows:
COMMENTS ON ''AGENT BLUE''

Usage in VietnamPara. 50 The rate of application of cacodylic acid as Agent Blue in Vietnam would have been higher than the rate used in the U.S.A. Recommended agriculture application rates vary but range from 3-10 lb/acre (Anonymous (1974) ).

Commercial Cacodylic AcidPara. 52 House quotes Brown (1972) who indicated that, in 1962, ''Agent Blue'' contained less than 0.1% trivalent arsenic (i.e. 1,000 ppm). The actual chemical constitution of this component and whether it is organic or inorganic is not stated but presumably it refers to arsenic trioxide in which arsenic is trivalent.

The military herbicide, designated ''Herbicide Blue'', contained the equivalent of 3.10 lb of cacodylic acid per U.S. gallon, present as the free acid and its sodium salt (Young et al. (1978)). The formulation had the following composition :
% cacodylic acid 4.7 sodium cacodylate 26.4 surfactant 3.4 sodium chloride 5. 5 water 59.5 antifoam agent 0.5

In addition, it apparently contained ''only trace quantities'' of inorganic arsenic (Young et al. (1978)). An earlier formulation, used in the period 1961- 1964, contained sixty-five per cent cacodylic acid and thirty per cent sodium chloride (Young et al. (1978)).
The presence of small amounts of inorganic arsenic in commercial cacodylic acid probably represents a residue of arsenic trioxide from which it is manufactured. (Midwest Research Institute (1975)).

Any assessment of the risk to humans posed by toxic agents depends on an accurate determination of the dose to which humans might be exposed. Hence it is of some importance that full details of the range of composition of 'Agent Blue' formulations be ascertained if at all possible.

''Manufacturer's Warning''Para. 53 The manufacturer's warning may well be a registration requirement for the product. It makes the significant point that cacodylic acid is absorbed by the body and can produce toxic effects in high doses, like many pesticides.

Cacodylate is converted to the toxic, inorganic, trivalent arsenic in the bodyPara. 54 The reference to sodium cacodylate (ref. 47: Merck Index 9th Ed. 1110) refers, in turn, to work published in 1760 and 1927. Apart from historical interest, such work has little current toxicological merit.

Para. 55 Apparently attempts to equate cacodylic acid with pentavalent inorganic compounds of arsenic. However, the underscored words, claiming in vivo reduction to trivalent arsenic compounds, refer to pentavalent inorganic compounds in the original context, not to organic compounds of arsenic. In addition, the work cited is outdated.

Current knowledge of the form of arsenic in various tissues is imprecise because of technical difficulties in differentiating between pentavalent and trivalent arsenic. The main problem is to prevent oxidation of trivalent arsenic after sampling. In vivo reduction of pentavalent inorganic arsenic has been shown to occur in dogs (Ginsberg (1965)) but not in cows (Peoples (1964)). The situation is further confused by the in vivo oxidation of trivalent to pentavalent arsenic which has been demonstrated in dogs (Ginsberg (1965)), rats (Winkler (1962)) and mice (Bencko et al. (1976)). Consequently, the statement of para. 54, published years before such work was carried out, must be considered with reservation.

Para. 56 Also quotes Neubauer (1947). On inspection it seems that Case 135 refers to an earlier case cited by earlier authors of a ''72 year old male with pigmentation and multiple ben. (?benign) superficial epitheliomas of the trunk, probably basal cell carcinoma, who had been exposed to arsenic drops and injection 10 years previously.'' Neither the form of arsenic nor the dosage is given. It is not possible to reach any valid conclusion on the basis of such a poorly documented, anecdotal case report.

Para. 56 seems to suggest that Neubauer himself did not regard pentavalent organic arsenic compounds as carcinogenic. As pointed out by Pelfrene (1976), Neubauer appears unconvinced by his work and his paper seems to argue against, rather than for, the carcinogenicity of arsenic.
Further consideration of this article is instructive as it is an indication of the controversy that surrounds this topic.

Neubauer reviewed 143 reports of cutaneous and a few visceral cancers that were attributed to arsenic. About 70% of these cases had received medicinal arsenic ( often as Fowler's Solution, 1% potassium arsenite) for the treatment of dermatological disorders such as psoriasis. This disproportionate number was not adequately persued. About half of the skin cancers were squamous arising in keratotic lesions whilst the rest were basal cell. The average time between the initial administration of arsenic and the onset of skin cancer was 18 years.

This review has been criticised on a number of grounds (Wildenberg (1978), Pelfrene (1976)). For example, some patients were not definitely known to have taken arsenic. The duration of exposure varied from 6 weeks to 36 years and periods of exposure were sometimes unstated. The total dose of arsenic was known is only 16 out of the 143 cases and doses varied from as little as 0.19 g to 70 and 121 g.
Thus, this compilation of cases by Neubauer cannot be regarded as a definitive work but it does have considerable historical merit.

Para. 57 The suggestions that cacodylic acid is slowly reduced to inorganic arsenic in the body predates and is inconsistent with later work which shows that cacodylic acid is rapidly excreted by man (Crecelius (1977)).

These studies show forest workers using cacodylic acid and related compounds for tree thinning operations in Oregon and Washington absorbed arsenic, particularly if safety precautions were relaxed. Much of the chemical appeared to be excreted in the urine in a relatively short time. In a study period of over two months there appeared to be no continuing arsenic accumulation but balance studies were not conducted. No evidence of arsenic toxicity was obtained (Wagner and Weswig (1974), (Tarrant and Allard (1972)). No human data are available on the tissue distribution of absorbed cacodylic acid from these or other studies.

Animal studies generally lend support to the view that organic arsenic herbicides are rapidly excreted by mammals (Dickinson (1972)). In the rat, cacodylic acid has a unniquely high affinity for rat erythrocytes which significantly prolongs its excretion. Even so, cacodylic acid is fairly stable in vivo and is not converted to inorganic arsenic since only 0.008-0.13% of administered 14C-cacodylic acid was converted by the rats to 14CO2 (Stevens et al. (1977)). Since the formation of inorganic arsenic would require two sequential demethylations of cacodylic acid, it can be inferred that little, if any, inorganic arsenic is formed in the rat in vivo. The bio-transformation of cacodylic acid in other species is unknown.

Comparison with the metabolic fate of other organic compounds of arsenic is relevant. Seafood organic arsenic compounds are known to be rapidly eliminated ( Schrenk and Schreibeis, (1958)) without biotransformation in the body (Crecelius (1977)). About 70% is eliminated in the first 24 hours after human ingestion ( West"o"o and Ryd"alv (1972)). Humans fed radiolabelled arsanilic acid excreted 84-94% in six days (Calesnick et al. (1966)).
Animal studies give similiar results. A substantial fraction of seafood arsenic is rapidly eliminated by rats (Coulson et al. (1935)), pigs (Munro (1976)) and monkeys (Charbonneau et al (1978)).

Para. 58 Selectively quotes House (1967) (ref. 49). The very next sentence reads 'S.S. Pinto and B.M. Bennet (1963) believe that it is a mistake to make a blanket condemnation of the use of arsenic without first looking at the data' ( House et al. 1967)).
Nevertheless, it should be stressed that chronic toxicity data for cacodylic acid are lacking.

Para. 59 Introduces the possibility of ''arsine'' production by reduction of cacodylic acid. The quote is based upon the subjective observations of untrained forest workers which Wagner and Weswig (1974 suggest may indicate the production of ''arsine'' gas. Trimethyl arsine does have a characteristic garlic-like odour (Vallee et al. (1960)).

Wagner and Weswih 1974 did not demonstrate arsine production and could not detect evidence for exposure to arsine by haematological investigation (full blood count) of two out of five exposed workers in Oregon. Again the results are inconclusive and do not confirm any hypothesis that ''arsine'' was produced in significant amounts after application of cacodylic acid in Vietnam.

Para. 60-64 Describes the acute human toxicity of the parent arsine, AsH3. The major toxicity of arsine is due to haemolysis, unlike inorganic arsenic compounds (Gosseling et al. (1976)). The outstanding features are haemolysis, chills, fevers and haemaglobenuria (Wintrobe et al. (1974)). In humans atmospheric arsine concentration of 3-10 ppm may cause symptoms in several hours , 10-60 ppm may be dangerous in 30 to 60 minutes and 250 ppm may be lethal in 30 minutes (Steel and Feltham (1950)).

There are very few accounts in the literature of chronic arsine poisoning. Bulmer et al. (1940) described a case involving smelter workers exposed to an undetermined concentration of arsine. ''The initial symptoms were persistent headache, followed by nausea, vomiting and shortness of breath on exertion. Puffiness of the face and eyelids, tingling sensations in feet, a garlic-like odour of the breath and an icteric tinge of the conjunctiva were noted in some cases.'' (Browning (1961) ).

Arsenic SafetyPara. 65 Introduces the concept of delayed effects of exposure to arsenic. The BMJ Leading Article from 1968 refers in particular to the carcinogenic potential of inorganic medications in former use.

Although the incidence of such skin cancers is still to be determined, it is thought to be relatively low (Wildenberg (1978) ). Studies of people from arsenic contaminated areas suggest a minimum exposure time of at least 5 years for the development of hyperpigmentation, 15 years for keratoses and about 20 years for the appearance of skin cancers. Furthermore, the latter do have a lengthy latent period, occasionally up to 30-40 years after cessation of exposure (Wildenberg (1978) ).

Cacodylic Acid-a toxic preparationPara. 66 Unsupported use of the term ''quite toxic preparations'' when referring to these compounds does not seem justified since it fails to take into account the known toxicological differences between organic and inorganic forms of arsenic.

The forest workers mentioned, of course, have already been referred to in para. 59. The cited study (Wagner and Weswig (1974) ) indeed does show that occupationally exposed forest workers do absorb arsenic compounds from the '' silvicides'' used and furthermore that this is largely and rapidly excreted in the urine in an undetermined form. The BMJ raises the important possibility that all of the absorbed arsenic may not have been excreted. Since the degree of their exposure is unquantified in the Oregon study, the degree of excretion of absorbed arsenic also is unknown. The important possibility of some bodily storage of arsenic can neither be proven nor disproven, although no evidence for arsenic accumulation or intoxication was obtained over the 2 month period of the Oregon study.

Once again, a significant omission has occurred from the quoted paragraph. In the quoted text, para. 66, line 10, reads after the word ''excretion'' ''The normal controls gave positive tests for small amounts of arsenic in both blood and urine, reflecting the fact that arsenic is a trace element in the ordinary human environment''. Although these words are not critical to the argument, their omission does conceal significant information. In fact, normal persons have been found to excrete between 0.01 and 0.06 mg arsenic per litre of urine and a few individuals as much as 0.2 mg per litre (Wintrobe et al. (1976) ).

Para. 67 The suggestion that cacodylic ''may be transformed into arsine by microfungal action'' is that of Wagner and Weswig (1974). The BMJ suggests that it is ''fortunate'' that none of the Oregon foresters experienced arsenic poisoning yet there is no evidence offered that arsine production did in fact occur after application of cacodylic acid in Oregon. As far as can be ascertained, the literature contains no reference to the generation of any arsine after the use of arsenic containing herbicides.
Here we see an argument developed by reference to another author's interpretations of a study which does not stand up to close inspection of the original work.

The final sentence, beginning line 8, ''So despite . . .'' is quoted out of context. The BMJ author, in fact, goes on to acknowledge that some arsenic compounds may have beneficial effects when used in small amounts as feed additives or for control of ''piglet scour''.

Cacodylic Acid leads to excess arsenic exposurePara. 68 The quotation from the earlier study of Tarrant and Allard (1972) again indicates that forest workers occupationally exposed to cacodylic acid and monosodium methanearsenate absorb arsenic which is excreted in the urine in a short time in an undetermined form.

Para. 69 The control group were studied for a significantly shorter period than exposed workers and Tarrant and Allard (1972) stated that ''no firm conclusions' ' can be drawn, although the large number of reports of headaches may have some significance. Design of the study was acknowledged to be deficient since the authors go on to state that-''The crew members were aware that they were part of a health study of an arsenic compound and, as a result, may have overreported symptoms''.
Once again, no conclusions can be drawn but the point is well made that forest workers using cacodylic acid do absorb significant quantities of arsenic.

Protection needed to use Cacodylic AcidPara. 70 Protective clothing is often required for the safe handling of pesticides. It is noteworthy that significant quantities of organic arsenic appear to have been absorbed by the forest workers despite the use of protective clothing, gloves and goggles.
Para. 71 The penultimate sentence, commencing line 12, ''Studies . . .'' again raises the important unresolved question of chronic human exposure to low levels of organic arsenicals.

Another important omission occurs in which the quoted authors attempted to place this very matter in perspective. The omitted final sentence reads ''In fact, in reference to the relationship to carcinogenesis of low dosage and chronic exposure to arsenic, one can find diametrically opposite opinions in the current medical literature'' (Wagner and Weswig (1974) ).
Para. 72 Merely confirms that the occupationally exposed forest workers absorbed and excreted organoarsenical herbicides.
Para. 73, 74 Importantly indicates that, with proper safety precautions, cacodylic acid was judged by Wagner and Weswig (1974) as safe for use by the forest workers.
Cacodylates infrequently used todayPara. 75 The subheading 'Cacodylates infrequently used today' is incongruous when the content of paragraphs 66-74 is considered.

The quotation from Dinman (1960) suggests that medicinal use of sodium cacodylate led to 'serious reactions'. The review of Neubauer (1947) indicates only one case (Case 135 discussed in para. 56) where 'cacodylates' were ' possibly' used. Vallee et al. (1960) mention sodium cacodylate as a common medicinal preparation but make no specific mention of toxic effects. In 1975, cacodylic acid was still in use as a popular tonic in some parts of Europe ( Midwest Research Institute (1975)).
It is worth noting that Dinman's review of chronic arsenic toxicity to humans is balanced and authoritative, but it is not referred to again even when this very topic is subsequently discussed.

A call to stop use of arsenic in pesticidesParas 76, 77 There is no doubt that inorganic arsenic compounds are quite hazardous and toxic to man and that such compounds found widespread agricultural usage, particularly before the introduction of modern synthetic organic pesticides. Although it is not stated which form of arsenic is under consideration, the abstracted Editorial presumably refers to inorganic arsenic compounds.
The citation of this abstract again emphasises the importance of stating the chemical nature of the arsenic compounds when considering arsenic toxicity.

Arsenic is ignored in the United StatesParas 78, 79 These extracts are from Satterlee (1960) which gives an interesting historical account which emphasises the suspected role of arsenic as a co-carcinogen and its widespread occurrence in the human environment.

Although the carcinogenic potential of arsenic will be discussed in a later section, the reference to the arsenic content of cigarettes is pertinent in demonstrating the ubiquitous role of arsenic contamination of the human environment. Arsenic has been recovered from tobacco in concentrations of 42 ug per cigarette (Satterlee (1956)).

Continued absorption of small amounts of arsenic leads to chronic poisoningPara. 80 Chronic arsenic poisoning can arise from chronic absorption of arsenic from any source and all routes of exposure are important from a toxicological viewpoint. Nevertheless, all exposure to arsenic does not invariably result in chronic arsenic poisoning.

In general, characterisation of human exposure (duration, degree) has been poor , thus impeding discussions of dose-response relationships. Furthermore, data are generally not available on the valence or form of the arsenic compound responsible for the poisoning episode.

Recent Cases of Arsenic Poisoning in SingaporePara. 81 The abstract is taken from a paper which describes acute and chronic arsenic poisoning arising amongst inhabitants of Singapore who consumed traditional Chinese herbal preparations. These were found to contain inorganic arsenic as arsenic sulphide (up to 12,000 ppm) or arsenic trioxide (107,000 ppm). The duration of consumption ranged from less than six months to more than 15 years.

Para. 82 Cutaneous manifestations of arsenic toxicity appear in those who recover from acute poisoning and those with chronic intoxication, usually within 1-4 weeks. Diffuse scaly desquamation occurs over the trunk and extremities with occasional hyperpigmentation. Hyperkaratosis of palms and soles can occur ( Wintrobe et al (1976)). As previously noted (para 80), little is known of dose- response relationships and the valence state of the arsenic poison is often not known. Thus, it is not possible to state whether trivalent or pentavalent arsenic, or both, produce such effects.

Para. 83 Nerve involvement from chronic arsenic poisoning is relatively infrequent and the symptoms develop slowly over a period of weeks. The peripheral neuropathy has the same sensory and motor distribution as beriberi. ( Wintrobe et al. (1976)). Numbness, burning and tingling are present and are followed by motor disturbances charaterised by fasciculations and occasionally gross tremors. As the disease progresses with prolonged exposure, ataxia and inco-ordination can develop. Neurological examination demonstrates impairment of vibration sense, touch, pain and temperature with 'stocking glove' distribution. Tendon reflexes are diminished and foot and wrist drop can occur in late stages. Cranial nerves are frequently involved (Dinman (1960) and references cited therein). Patients with peripheral neuropathy continue to have sensory disturbances and weakness for many months (Wintrobe et al. (1976)). Exposure levels required to produce such effects are generally unknown but are usually high enough to produce other symptoms. In fatal cases, the peripheral nerves often show fragmentation and resorption of myelin, with disintegration of axis cylinders (Wintrobe et al. (1976)).

Disturbance of central nervous system function include severe hearing loss and EEG abnormalities. Arsenic encephalopathy, manifested as drowsiness, confusion and convulsion can occur in both acute and chronic arsenic intoxication ( Wintrobe et al. (1976)).

Para. 84 The gastrointestinal effects of chronic arsenic poisoning usually are unremarkable and often subjective in nature. Persistent diarrhoea and cachexia develop in cases of chronic poisoning with criminal intent (Dinman (1960)). Hyperaemia and haemorrhages of the intestine occur in fatal cases (Wintrobe et al (1976)). Arsenical hepatitis with impaired liver function and cirrhosis has been observed in man. Dose-response relationships are difficult to estimate due to lack of controls, and the possible influence of heavy alcohol consumption.
Para. 85 Inorganic trivalent arsenic affects the haemopoeitic system causing anaemia and disturbed leucopoeisis. Aplastic anaemia can occur in severe cases ( Dinman (1960)).
Para. 86 Localised peri-orbital and ankle oedema are occasional consequences of arsenic poisoning (Dinman 1960). Renal tubular necrosis occurs in fatal cases ( Wintrobe et al (1976)).

Known cardiovascular effects of arsenic are peripheral vascular disease and electrocardiographic (ECG) abnormalities. Peripheral vascular disorders include 'Blackfoot' disease (gangrene) and Raynaud's syndrome.

Para. 87 Although the association of chronic iatrogenic arsenic ingestion with keratoses and dermal neoplasms (mainly squamous in nature) is well documented, the relationship to other forms of cancer is less well established.
Liver disease and chronic arsenic ingestion in AustraliaPara. 88 Once again, the cases cited relate to chronic arsenic toxicity subsequent to long term ingestion of arsenic-containing medications.

As previously mentioned and as acknowledged by the articles' authors, chronic arsenic poisoning is an uncommon but well documented cause of hepatic disease. Pathological investigation reveals centri-lobular fatty deposition in mild cases . Necrotising hepatitis occurs occasionally and may lead to cirrhosis (Dinman ( 1960)).

As recognised by Cowlishaw (1979), arsenic induced primary liver cancer is exceedingly rare. Rare cases of liver hemangioendothelioma have been associated with inorganic arsenic (Roth 1957), Rennke et al (1971), Regelson et al (1968), Lander et al (1975).
In view of the large numbers of people that have been exposed to arsenic via drinking water, occupational exposure or medical use, these associations may be by chance (IARC (1973)).
The relevance of these case reports and of the particular subtitle reference to Australia is obscure.

Primary Liver Cancer in VietnamPara. 90 This quotation would appear to be an attempt to implicate arsenic in the alleged increased incidence of primary liver cancer in Vietnam in the period 1962-1968.

The quotation is misleading. The very next sentence of the IARC monograph discounts the validity of the claim, viz ''However, limitations in the reporting of the study make impossible an adequate assessment of the possible relationship between the incidence of liver cancer and herbicide spraying in South Vietnam''. (IARC (1977)).

Arsenic Poisoning in Moselle VintersPara. 91 The form of inorganic arsenic used as a vineyard insecticide here is not clear. It may have been lead arsenate (as claimed in para. 95) but a recent report indicates that the ''Bordeaux Mixture'' in use at that time was fortified with calcium arsenate. (Ivankovic et al. (1979 )). Arsenic trioxide has also found use as an insecticide on grapes (IARC (1973) ).

The exposure of the vineyard workers was particularly heavy because of dermal absorption, inhalation of insecticide dust and ingestion of contaminated wine. The duration of exposure was not documented but it was prolonged, occurring in the period 1925-1938.

Although this study gives a fascinating account of inorganic arsenic poisoning amongst these occupationally exposed workers, its deficiencies severely limit the interpretations that are possible. The study was uncontrolled and the workers were exposed to other toxic substances such as tobacco smoke and alcohol in an unquantified manner. Selection bias cannot be excluded.
Para. 92 would seem to suggest that arsenic trioxide, As2O3, was the inorganic arsenic insecticide used. Of course, more than one of these may have found use.

Para. 93 The controversy over the role of arsenic as a carcinogen remains unresolved. Warburg's hypothesis has been criticised on the grounds that the concentrations of arsenic which occur in vivo are much less than is required to inhibit cell metabolism in vitro (Frost (1967)).
Para. 94 As previously discussed the debate on the role of arsenic in the aetiology of cancer has been prolonged and often confused.

Para. 95 The use of inorganic arsenic insecticides was formerly widespread in the U.S.A. (Metcalf et al. (1962)). The German vinters would seem to have suffered particularly heavy exposure not only in their workplace but also through drinking contaminated wine. Subsequent analysis have shown that, in 1938 , 43% of 336 samples of wine from the area contained more than 5 mg/l of arsenic (Koelsch (1958)). Although the degree of their exposure from this unique route is uncertain it could be presumed to have been heavy, at least in some cases.

In comparison, consumption of drinking water containing arsenic (mostly 0.4-0.6 mg/l) has been shown to cause chronic arsenicism in Taiwan. The incidence of peripheral vascular disease ('Blackfoot disease') and skin lesions ( hyperpigmentation, keratoses and skin cancers) were linked to the total intake of arsenic (Tseng (1977)).
Para. 96 Suggests that exposure was sufficiently heavy to produce manifestations of toxicity long after the use of inorganic arsenic was banned.

Para. 97 The majority of workers who subsequently developed carcinomata had been symptomatic of arsenic poisoning for years after 1935 i.e. for up to 7 years before the use of inorganic arsenic was discontinued. Latent periods for the development of such skin carcinomata of the order of 20-30 years are reported ( Neuman & Schwank (1960)).

Para. 98 The high incidence of lung cancer (12 out of 27 cases autopsied) is striking and possibly suggestive of a causal relationship between the workers and their inorganic arsenic exposure. Nevertheless, this study was uncontrolled and remains inconclusive.
The incidence of ''hyperkeratoses'' (5/27; 4 SCC, 1 BCC) is even less than that of a later similar study (9/16) (Braun (1958)).
Liver, Respiratory TractPara. 99-105 There is no firm evidence that heavy exposure to arsenic increases the incidence of other forms of cancer in man ( IARC (1973)).

Para. 106 The stigmata of chronic arsenic poisoning in all of the cancer cases autopsied emphasises the severity of exposure. It could be suggested that heavy exposure, sufficient to produce the features of chronic arsenic toxicity, led to the development of cancer but, since the study lacks controls, such an interpretation is unjustified.

Peripheral Vascular DamagePara. 107 Peripheral vascular disease is a recognised feature of chronic arsenic toxicity. Peripheral ischaemia due to chronic arsenic toxicity in Taiwan (''Blackfoot disease'') has been particularly well described (Tseng (1977)).
Skin ChangesPara. 108 Available studies consistently point to a causal relationship between skin cancer and heavy exposure to inorganic arsenic (IARC ( 1973)).

In Vivo Arsenic Concentrations and the Autopsy FindingsPara. 109 Available human studies have suggested that inorganic arsenic is excreted, mainly in the kidneys , and is not stored in the body. Inorganic trivalent arsenic is eliminated (60- 75% in urine, few per cent in faeces) within one week. (Mappes (1977); Tam et al . (1979)). Consequently, the absence of arsenic from the tissues of these workers whose exposure had ceased some 8-14 years previously is not surprising. Hence, the absence of detectable levels of arsenic in tissues does not rule out exposure at some previous time. It is known that substances can exert delayed effects (e.g. beryllium) and need not be present in tissues in high levels at the time that pathological changes subsequently develop (Bencko (1977)).
Para. 110 As previously mentioned, there is no evidence which positively relates gastrointestinal malignancy with heavy arsenic exposure (IARC (1973)).
Para. 111 Pesticides by their very nature are toxic and all care should be exercised in their use.
Para. 112 Arsenic rarely is a cause of hepatic cirrhosis in man (see para. 84). No data is given in support of the claim.
Arsenic and Australian Troops in VietnamPara. 113 This paragraph is critical to the argument under development. Yet it relies upon unsupported personal observations.
The implication is that Agent Blue is synonymous with inorganic arsenic as used in Moselle. This is unsubstantiated.
The ''accidental defoliation'' incident warrents clarification. It presumably offers direct evidence of exposure of Australian personnel to Agent Blue. The degree of this exposure is not indicated.

The opinion that the amount of ''trivalent arsenic'' exposure in Vietnam exceeded that of the Moselle vinters is unsupported. Since cacodylic acid and its sodium salt are pentavalent, ''trivalent arsenic'' may refer to the ''trace quantities'' of inorganic arsenic that Agent Blue contained. The argument that this contaminant gave rise to chronic heavy arsenic exposure as in the German Vinters would seem subjective and difficult to sustain.
Whilst it may be possible to estimate the duration of possible exposure to Agent Blue in Vietnam, the actual degree of this exposure would seem indeterminable.

Furthermore, if as is suggested, such heavy exposure to trivalent arsenic did occur in Vietnam, there should be medical records of cases of arsenic poisoning amongst Australian and American personnel who served in Vietnam. Signs of chronic and subacute arsenic poisoning such as the characteristic cutaneous manifestations begin to appear after only a few weeks of exposure (Wintrobe et al. (1974)).
Delayed Occupational LesionsPara. 114 The toxicity of inorganic arsenic compounds is well recognised.
Para. 115 Note that use of inorganic arsenic insecticides led to both acute and chronic arsenic poisoning.
Para. 116 Merely reiterates points already made (see paras. 82, 108).
Para. 117 As previously stated, the role of arsenic in the aetiology of internal malignancy remains unclarified. (Reymann et al. (1978)).

Paras. 118-120 As with the earlier study (Roth (1958)), this study also lacks controls and so should be interpreted cautiously. The suggestion that the high incidence of various carcinomata was attributable to inorganic arsenic remains unproven.
Note that most (i.e. 13/16) workers who developed carcinomata also suffered the cutaneous manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Skin and Visceral Changes Follow Long IngestionParas. 121-122 Primary liver cancer associated with intake of inorganic arsenic medications would seem to be particularly rare in view of the large number of people having been so exposed.
The 2 cases reported here involved the chronic consumption of arsenic trioxide for more than 20 years.

Haematological Aspects of Arsenic IntoxicationPara. 123 Both inorganic and organic arsenic compounds are capable of inducing blood dyscrasias and marrow suppression in humans. The effects are usually reversed within 2-3 weeks of cessation of exposure (Kyle and Pease (1965), Westhoff et al. (1975)).

Leukemia Following Arsenic PoisoningPara. 124 Another unique case report. The development of aplastic anaemia and then AML may have been unrelated to arsenic. Although inorganic trivalent arsenic was formerly used in leukemia therapy, an oncognic effect on the haemopoetic system cannot be ruled out. Confirmatory data are lacking.
Ocular Effects from ArsenicalsPara. 125 There is no supporting data for this complication of effects and the chemical form(s) of arsenic is not distinguished .

Various uncontrolled case reports suggest that both inorganic and organic arsenicals may produce a variety of toxic effects to the eye. (Klevay (1976) and references cited therein). Some of these cases involved the treatment of syphilitic patients with organic arsenic compounds and it is unclear to what extent neuro-ophthalmological effects of syphilis were a compounding factor. Optic atrophy is a side effect of the use of the anti-parasitic organoarsenical drug tryparsamide (Neujean et al. (1948) ).
According to Klevay (1976), high doses of some derivatives of phenyarsenic acid produced blindness in rhesus monkeys (Longley et al. (1942) ).

Studies with commercial cacodylic acid herbicide formulations showed that it was 'essentially non irritant' when topically applied to the rabbit's eye ( Midwest Research Institute (1975) ). Chronic eye studies are lacking in animals and man.

Differential DiagnosesPara. 126 The chemical and laboratory findings in arsenic poisoning are not specific and the diagnosis relies upon chemical detection of arsenic in the hair or urine (Wintrobe et al. (1974) ).

Para. 127 Along with other toxic metals, arsenic is a recognised cause of peripheral neuropathy. Additional causes are other poisons (drugs, organic chemicals), deficiency states and metabolic disorders, specific inflammatory states and metabolic disorders, specific inflammatory states and infections, vascular diseases, genetically determined disorders and the idiopathic polyneuropathies (Wintrobe et al. (1974) ).
Para. 128 Inorganic arsenic is a known cause of aplastic and hypoplastic anaemia . Organic arsenicals occasionally produce marrow hypoplasia as an idiosyncratic effect (Wintrobe et. al. (1974) ).

Dow Chemical Company Paper on Close Relationship to Cancer Emphasis of the author's affiliation with the Dow Company has no inherent merit and is inconsistent with the citation of other references. The long involvement of this company in pesticide production is well known.

Paras. 129, 130 This retrospective epidemiological study aimed to correlate the chronic occupational exposure of workers engaged in production of arsenic containing pesticides with observed mortalities. In the process, various forms of inorganic arsenic were used, including trivalent compounds. The estimated total inhalation exposure to arsenic ranged from 42 mg to 29.7 g over periods ranging from one day to years.

Analysis of deaths of those workers identified revealed that respiratory cancer was the cause of death in 28 of 173 exposed workers (16.2%) and 104 of 1,809 unexposed workers (5.7%). The increased mortality from respiratory cancer showed a positive dose-response relationship with the degree of exposure. Futhermore, mortality from malignant neoplasms of lymphatic and haemopoetic tissues, except leukaemia, were also higher in exposed (3.5%) than the non-exposed groups (1.4%) , but no clear interpretation was drawn.

Subsequently, it was revealed that 16 out of the 28 lung cancer deaths occurred in workers of lesser exposure over less than one year. (Blejer & Wagner (1976) ) . These later authors suggested that a no-effect level with regard to increased mortality from respiratory cancer ''might lie in the very low microgram range of arsenic per m3''. (Blejer & Wagner (1976) ). However, if the workers with less than one year's exposure are excluded from the study, no deaths from respiratory cancer occurred amongst those workers with daily time weighted average doses of over 40 years up to 90 ug/m3. Futhermore, no consistent dose response relationship existed below this level.

This significant study has been criticised independently on a number of other grounds. Only men who died during employment or following retirement from the company were included and, consequently, both groups could be biased samples ( Samuels & Howarth (1975) ). The presence of trivalent arsenic confounds interpretation of the effects of pentavalent compounds (Samuels & Howarth (1975) , Pelfrene (1976) ). Workers were exposed to other toxic agents in an unquantified manner e.g. lime sulphur (Pelfrene (1976) ) and lead (Wildenberg ( 1978) ). The full influence of cigarette smoking was not determined (Pelfrene) ( 1976) ). On statistical grounds the calculation of expected respiratory cancer deaths, based on proportionate mortalities, was unreliable (Samuels & Howarth ( 1975) ).

Nevertheless, in keeping with other substantial epidemiological evidence, the authors further implicated arsenic exposure from the production of inorganic arsenic insecticides in the aetiology of respiratory cancer. No conclusion can be drawn with regard to the potential carcinogenicity of trivalent versus pentavalent arsenic compounds since exposure to both forms occurred. The data are inconclusive, like the previous data from the use of inorganic arsenic pesticides (paras. 91-111). The significance of such a study for any exposure to arsenic that may have occurred in Vietnam is obscure since the form of arsenic and the duration and method of exposures were vastly different.

Cancer Induction is Concentration DependentPara. 131 The diagram relates to the production of skin carcinomata in mice topically treated with mixtures of tar and arsenic. The diagram is purported to demonstrate a critical synergistic concentration of arsenic in the tars. The chemical composition of the mixtures is not stated.

Since the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon present in tar are well known carcinogens, carcinogenicity of such mixtures is not surprising. The possible role of arsenic as a co-carcinogen is not classified by this study.
Any relevance to exposure to pesticides used in Vietnam is extremely marginal.
Biochemistry The title is inappropriate to the content.
Para. 132 The presumption that all forms of arsenic are converted to arsenite in vivo is contrary to later studies (see para. 55).
Cacodylate Effect in MicePara. 133

The presence of ''numerous mitoses'' in the early mouse studies hardly fulfills the histopathological criteria for ''cancer''. The inconclusive nature of Neubaer's compilation of reports has already been pointed out (see para. 56).
Chronic feeding of cacodylic acid to mice over 18 months at 121 ppm in the diet has been shown not to cause a significant increase in tumour incidence (Innes et al. (1969)).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Following the establishment of the Australian Caption Centre to provide closed captioning of television programs for people who are deaf and hard of hearing, when will (a) specification be issued for sub-titling on the approved Teletect system and (b) captioned programs be available to television stations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In February 1980, my predecessor authorised experiments in data broadcasting transmissions while stating that the position would be reviewed in three years. No Australian standard for data broadcasting can be established until the review is completed. In the meantime, however, in order to give the hearing impaired the opportunity to benefit from existing technology, I announced on 12 March 1982, that a data broadcasting system known as UK Teletext was the most practicable system available for prompt implementation of a closed caption service. This does not prevent stations from using different data broadcasting systems for closed captioning during the current experimental period.

(b) The Australian Caption Centre (ACC) in Sydney is in the process of establishing itself with the assistance of a substantial grant of funds from the Government. Its function is to produce captions for programs supplied to it by television stations. The ACC is expected to be operational towards the end of 1982 and will begin captioning using the UK Teletext system.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport: Expenditure on Travel and Subsistence

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the 23.9 per cent increase in expenditure proposed on travel and subsistence, Division 655, Sub-Division 2, Item 01, for 1981-82 explanatory notes, will he detail in which sections of his Department it is expected the increase in travel and subsistence expenditure will be the greatest .
(2) Are all sections in his Department expected to increase their travel and subsistence expenditure by the amount of 23.9 per cent referred to.
(3) Which expense is expected to be incurred as a result of staff previously located in Melbourne, now being located in Canberra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An accounting for the increased funds provided for travel and subsistence in 1981-82 is contained on page 19 of the Department's Explanatory Notes, under the heading 'General Comment'. Apart from the additional provision to cover cost increases, the largest areas of increase relate to
(a) an expanded training program of operational and technical courses to meet staffing shortages in specific critical areas ($442,844)
(b) additional costs related to the selection and recruitment of staff to fill positions vacant in several operationally important staffing categories ($440, 000).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the actual revenue from miscellaneous items referred to on page 6 of his Department's estimates of expenditure and receipts 1981-82 explanatory notes, was $486,711, not $1 million as estimated by his Department for 1980-81.
(2) If so, what were the circumstances of this major short-fall in revenue and will he detail the principal items that resulted in the short-fall.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The nature of the miscellaneous revenue item is such that major fluctuations in the level of receipts occur from year to year due to the varying levels of income that arise from sale of obsolete and surplus equipment and saleable publications (including collection of sales tax), from the hire of Departmental equipment and facilities at the Vehicle Emissions Laboratory, and from receipts in respect of appropriations of former years.

The estimates for this revenue item are therefore basically formulated upon the level of receipts of the previous year after taking into account any known variations. The reduced level of receipts in 1980-81 is reflected in the 1981-82 estimate of $600,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to Division 655, Sub-Division 2, Item 11, Airways Facilities Maintenance, Materials and Services, of estimates of expenditure explanatory notes of his Department, what were the circumstances that led to the underspending by $860,000 in the last financial year arising from the non- delivery of maintenance spares.
(2) What was the nature of the maintenance spares that were not delivered and when is it expected that they will be delivered.

(3) What were the specific stock items, referred to in the explanatory notes, that have been depleted and will the additional stocks being purchased in 1981- 82 restore stock levels to desirable levels.
(4) What are the principal categories of items on order and proposed to be ordered as spares and other equipment associated with this item of expenditure for 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The underspending in 1980-81 was as a consequence of two main factors
unexpected delays were experienced in the receipt of maintenance spares on order from suppliers
some accounts for the rental and maintenance of control lines and teletype lines were not issued due to industrial action affecting Telecom accounting arrangements.

(2) Delays in delivery occurred across the whole range of items purchased. In view of the large number of purchase orders issued by my Department each year, I am not prepared to authorise the extensive use of scarce manpower resources that would be required to extract the information requested.
It is expected that the majority of spares not delivered in 1980-81 will be received and paid for in 1981-82.

(3) & (4) As there are in excess of 65,000 items listed in the Department's Vocabulary of Stores, extensive staff resources would be required to extract sufficient detail to itemise a reply to the Honourable Member's question.
