QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Minister for Foreign Affairs' answer to question No. 491 ( Weekly Hansard, 10 June 1981, page 3487), will he now state whether (a) Australia is still a signatory to the Technical Cooperation Program, and the Basic Standardisation Agreement, (b) Australia is currently conducting chemical and biological defence research in Australia or any territory under Australian control and (c) any other country is currently conducting such research in Australia or in any territory under Australian control.

(2) If Australia is still a signatory to the Program and Agreement referred to in part (1) (a), (a) how many service or Departmental personnel are involved, on a full-time or part-time basis, in servicing Australia's interests and obligations pursuant to those agreements, (b) what is the military rank or substantive Public Service grading of each of the personnel concerned, (c) how many of those personnel are involved in any way with information relating to chemical and biological defence and (d) what is the frequency of the exchange of information on (i) chemical and biological defence and (ii) all other matters, between Australia and the other States who are parties to those agreements.

(3) If the answer to parts (1) (b) and (1) (c) is in the affirmative, is he able to state (a) the type of perceived threats for which that defence research is being carried out and (b) which (i) academic institutions and (ii) private business interests are collaborating in such research.
(4) If he is not able to provide the information sought in part (3), what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.

(b) A small number of people, mainly scientists, at Materials Research Laboratories, Melbourne are employed on investigations into chemical defence. Australia has not, is not, and has no plans to become, engaged in research into the handling of disease producing biological agents.
(c) No.

(2) (a) The Technical Cooperation Program (TTCP) and the Basic Standardisation Agreement are arrangements allowing an interchange of information over a wide range of subjects of Defence interest. TTCP has, for example, between 60 and 70 technical meetings each year. Many of them are attended by defence scientists from Australia or our overseas defence scientific representatives and almost all require some participation of Departmental officers in briefing, attendance or reporting. Thus the overall participation of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and the Services is diffused throughout these organisations and is not easily quantified. It is inherent in TTCP that no participant is dedicated to TTCP alone but brings to the cooperative activity his expertise and results from Australian Defence programmes. As at September 1981 at least 135 officers at several levels in the Second and Third Divisions of the Public Service are directly involved in TTCP activities in part time capacities. None participate full time. Forty-five Service officers are directly involved in the Basic Standardisation Agreement of whom nine are employed full time on their work.
(b) This information is not obtainable within the limits of available resources .
(c) Ten civilians and one Service officer are directly involved on a part time basis.
(d) Meetings in each specific field of interest are held at a frequency of about 12-18 months. Correspondence and data exchange between meetings is on an as required basis.

(3) (a) Research on defence against chemical agents is not conducted in response to a specific perceived threat, but rather in relation to the potential threat. The threat to Australia of chemical or biological warfare is considered by many to be low, yet the damage caused by these agents is almost universally acknowledged to be horrifying. We would clearly be remiss if we could not protect ourselves effectively should the need arise.
The Government has acknowledged its responsibility to ensure that Australia is properly defended and that the Australian Defence Force is properly protected against chemical and biological weapons.

For many years it has been the policy of successive Defence Ministers to maintain the skills necessary to advise on the means for protecting Australians, both military and civilian, from chemical warfare attack.
It is a matter of government policy, stated publicy on a number of occasions, that the development, production or stockpiling of chemical weapons is not undertaken or planned to be undertaken.
(b) None.
(4) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

(d) UH-1 participation in an Army parachute display at the Queanbeyan Racing Club 'Defence Force Racing Meeting' on 17 April 1982; and
(e) Caribou and UH-1 aircraft involved with an Army parachute display and wet winching demonstration at the Canberra Festival on 15 March 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Equal Employment Opportunities: Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department have an equal employment opportunities program; if so, (a) how long has the program been in existence, (b) what are the aims of the program, (c) what is the Department's assessment of the success of the program in achieving its aims, (d) how have, or are, the aims of the program been, or being, met, (e) is the program aimed at covering the whole Department, or merely a section of it, (f) what are the procedures for union consultation and involvement in the program, (g) what involvement does the Equal Employment Opportunities Bureau of the Public Service Board have in the program, and (h) has the program changed in its priority rating within the Department since its introduction.
(2) If there is no program, on what basis was this decision reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Industry and Commerce does not currently have a specifically designated Equal Employment Opportunities Program, but has a general policy of support to equal employment opportunities initiatives.
The Department has actively taken steps toward implementing certain initiatives in this area, namely:

ensuring that all training courses are non-discriminatory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Army Helicopter for Civil Purposes

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was an Australian Army helicopter used to ferry the 1982 Miss Moomba and others to the race meeting held at Flemington, Victoria, on Saturday, 6 March 1982.
(2) Was the Moomba Committee required to pay for use of the helicopter, if so, what was the cost of the charter; if not, why not.
(3) Did armed forces personnel take part in other Moomba festival activities; if so, what were they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An Army helicopter was used to ferry the 1982 Moomba Queen and her chaperone from Swan Street Army Depot to Watsonia to attend the Army Display and Fair. They were then both conveyed from Watsonia to the Flemington Race Course.

(2) The Moomba Committee was not required to pay for the use of this helicopter as the attendance of the Moomba Queen at the Watsonia Display and Fair was at Army's request. The helicopter which was tasked with supporting the Watsonia Fair was the only means by which the Moomba Queen could attend the Fair and honour other commitments. This activity is conducted annually in conjunction with Moomba.
(3) The information required was provided in answer to Question No. 4052 ( Hansard 17 March 1982, page 1118).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it the intention of Australian National to provide fast passenger services between Whyalla and Adelaide on completion of the standardisation of the Adelaide to Crystal Brook Railway; if so, when is it anticipated that the service will commence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question of introduction of fast passenger services is a matter for the commercial judgment of the Commission in the light of circumstances existing at the time. I understand that the Commission does not currently propose to introduce a fast passenger service between Adelaide and Whyalla when the standardisation of the Adelaide to Crystal Brook railway is complete.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Attorney- General's Department are examining means whereby the repatriation legislation can be amended, following the Nancy Laws and Colin Simpson decisions.

(2) Is it also a fact that on Tuesday, 2 March 1982, Mr Derek Volker, the Minister's Permanent Head, made an attack on recent administrative law reform which requires that reasons be given for decisions made by the repatriation system in respect of claims made by ex-service personnel.
(3) Will the Minister categorically deny that the Government is seeking to disadvantage ex-service personnel by either or both legislative and administrative changes to the repatriation system.

(4) If not, will the Minister give Vietnam veterans an assurance that any proposed changes to the repatriation system are not designed to disadvantage them in any claims they make as a result of exposure to toxic chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. On 2 March in a talk to the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-servicemen and women, Mr Volker said, in respect of reasons for decision, 'We are seeking to reduce the complexity of reasons for decisions prepared by determining authorities and to reduce their length, especially in those cases where claims are being accepted or appeals allowed.'

He referred to other action taken to speed up the processing of claims and appeals and went on to say, with reference to the complexity of Repatriation legislation 'We have some concern that administrative law changes in recent years may be running counter to a fundamental of the whole Repatriation system that claims should be resolved expeditiously and with the least amount of red tape or inconvenience to the ex-serviceman or woman.'

(3) and (4) On 25 January 1982, in an address reported by the media, I made it clear that the Government would not be proposing any amendment to legislation in the light of the High Court decision Law v Repatriation Commission. Ex-service organisations had been informed. There has been no change in the Government's attitude since then and there is no intention to take any administrative action to disadvantage ex-service personnel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 18 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the initial landing attempt at Mascot of Masling Flight 422 from Williamstown, N.S.W. to Mascot on Monday, 15 March 1982, aborted; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Masling flight was about 5 km short of Runway 16 when a Boeing 747 was cleared for take-off on the same runway.

The 747 was slow to commence the take-off and, 27 seconds after the clearance was given, it was again cleared for take-off. The 747 then began to roll and the Masling flight was advised to continue the approach, however, the pilot elected to go around.

ATC reports that the required longitudinal separation was maintained throughout . The occurrence was not considered to constitute an air safety incident and was not reported by the Masling pilot or Air Traffic Control.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will Qantas Airways Limited be operating a flight between Australia and Zimbabwe later this year; if so, on what commercial basis has the decision been taken to fly on this route.

(2) In view of the fact that Qantas has suffered large financial losses in its previous year of operations, is the decision to fly to Zimbabwe economically viable; if not, will the Federal Government subsidise Qantas against any loss incurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Qantas is examining the feasibility of operating services to Zimbabwe, but has not yet made any formal proposal in the matter. The approval of the Zimbabwe Government would be necessary before services could be operated to that country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are certain parts of Antarctica considered to be an integral part of Australia.
(2) Are there any historical sites, buildings or places on Antarctica which are part of the Australian Heritage.
(3) Who was Sir Douglas Mawson and what part did he play in the exploration of Antarctica.

(4) Is there any building, cottage or other construction in the Antarctic Territory which was built by and belonged to Sir Douglas Mawson; if so, what is the condition of the building or construction.
(5) Does the Government intend to maintain, restore or repair buildings of historical significance in the Antarctic Territory.
(6) What would be the cost of restoring Sir Douglas Mawson's cottage.
(7) Does the Government intend to provide better facilities in the future in order to allow our citizens to visit this part of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia exercises sovereignty over all of the islands and territories situated south of 60*S latitude between 45*E and 160*E longitudes, except for those islands and territories between 136*E and 142*E longitudes. Under the definition of 'Australia' given in the Acts Interpretation Act the Australian Antarctic Territory, being an External Territory, is not considered to be an integral part of Australia.

(2) There are a number of objects, sites and structures in the AAT classified as Historic Monuments under the Antarctic Treaty. One of these, the main base hut of the 1911-1914 Australasian Antarctic Expedition, now known as Mawson's Hut, was placed on the Register of the National Estate by the Australian Heritage Commission in November 1978.

(3) Sir Douglas Mawson laid the foundations of Australia's activities in Antarctica. His many contributions began in 1907 as a member of Sir Ernest Shackleton's British Antarctic Expedition when he was a member of the first party to climb Mount Erebus and of the three man party which was the first to the South Magnetic Pole. He subsequently organised and led the Australasian Antarctic Expedition of 1911-14, using funds from private and government sources . The expedition established bases on Macquarie Island, the Shackleton Ice Shelf and at Commonwealth Bay, where it constructed headquarters, later known as ' Mawson's Hut'. The expedition also mapped over 1,000 km of new coastline, collected valuable scientific data, was the first to transmit radio messages from Antarctica and was the first to attempt use of aircraft in Antarctica. Mawson himself achieved an extraordinary feat of endurance and courage when he walked nearly 200 km alone in appalling conditions to return to Commonwealth Bay after the death of his two companions and the loss of most of their equipment. He was knighted for his efforts on this expedition.

In 1929-31 he led the British Australian and New Zealand Antarctic Research Expedition (BANZARE) which explored and mapped much new territory south of Australia and claimed British sovereignty for the area. This territory was later ceded to Australia and New Zealand.
Sir Douglas Mawson became a leading member of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition's (ANARE) Planning Committee after it was established in 1947.

The first permanent station on the Antarctic continent other than in the Antarctic peninsular region was established by Australia in 1954 and named after Sir Douglas Mawson. The fifth of May this year marks the hundredth anniversary of the birth of this great Australian. My Department, with the co-operation of other bodies, is undertaking several projects to mark the occasion.
(4) and (5) I refer the honourable member to the answer to an earlier question on notice (No. 1746) on page 2946 of Hansard 17 November 1981.

(6) It would take approximately 12 personnel two summer seasons to restore Mawson's Hut. The cost for equipment, clothing, food and salaries would be approximately $300,000 per annum, in 1982 dollar terms. However, the shipping necessary to support such a restoration program cannot be provided from existing resources as all available ships are fully utilised in supporting the higher priority science and rebuilding programs. If restoration work was to begin immediately it would be necessary to charter an additional ice strengthened ship from a northern hemisphere source. This would cost about $3 million for the two seasons. While the matter is under review, the current planning is to defer restoration until the rebuilding program is past its peak later in the decade and excess shipping capacity becomes available.

(7) The Government has no plans to provide facilities for tourists to visit the Australian Antarctic Territory. The very high cost and hazardous conditions associated with life in the Antarctic, together with the extreme fragility of the environment, render the area unsuited for normal tourist activities.
